answer: A long time ago when I was in third grade I had a friend @PERSON2 who's mom was in a bad mood. She never laughed and she never smiled. Every time I saw her I would smile at her and all she would do was frown and keep walking. At first I didn't know she was a grouch i just thought she didn't like me or something.When @PERSON2 told me his mom was a grouch I started to laugh and laugh. He asked me what was so funny i told him that i thought his mom didn't like me or something because every time I see his mom I would smile at her and all she will do is frown and walk away. That made my friend laugh we were cracking up so hard that we got in trouble in class. The next day @PERSON2 and I were eating lunch at school when he says to me <hey your pretty good at making people laugh>. I said <no I am not my jokesare horrible>. He said <@CAPS1 lets put them to the test go up to some one new to this school>. I said @CAPS1 so we went around the whole school looking for a new student unfortunately we couldn't find one we heard the bell ring and we ran to our class. We sat in the back of the classroom its only @PERSON2 and I and anempty seat between us. We were excited because our teacher @PERSON1 was going to show us a movie. @PERSON1 got the front of the room andclass today I have an announcement we have a new student in our class say hello to @LOCATION1. @ORGANIZATION1 walked through the door. @PERSON1 told @ORGANIZATION1 shecould sit in the back in between @PERSON2 and I. She sat down turned to the both of us and said hello. @PERSON2 gave me a look that said tell her the joke and @CAPS3 him a thumbs up. I turned to @LOCATION1 and said hi I'm @CAPS4 do you want to hear a joke. @ORGANIZATION1 said yeah sure. I started <@CAPS5 knockshe said <who's thereI said <booshe said <boo who?I said <oh don't cry I am right here>. At first she didn't laugh because she didn't get it but duringthe middle of the movie she said <ohhhh I get itand she started to laugh. @PERSON2 turned to me and said <I told you so>. @PERSON2 got this crazy idea that if I spent the night at his house that I could make his mom laugh or at least make her smile. I said <@CAPS1 sounds like a plan>. I asked mt mom if it was @CAPS1 if I could spend the night at @PERSON2 house she said <yeah just make sure its @CAPS1 with his mom>. @PERSON2 asked his mom she said it was @CAPS1. When I got to @PERSON2 house the first thing we did was play video games. When it was dinner time we all sat down at the table to eat @PERSON2 and I were on one side and his parents on the other. When we started eating @PERSON2 told me to tell the joke to his parents i said @CAPS1. So I said to them <@CAPS5 @CAPS5>they replied <who's thereI said <boothey said <boo who?I said <oh don't cry I am right here>. His parents started to laugh and laugh and they keptlaughing for like five minutes. @PERSON2 turned to me and yelled it worked his mom asked what worked. @PERSON2 explained everything to them. His mom told usthat her mom had recently died and that's why she was in a bad mood. After dinner we went to bed and fell asleep. The next morning when my mom came to pick me up she asked me how the sleep over went. I said it was fun I made people laugh. She said @CAPS1 but laughter isn't going to help you clean your roomall i could say was gosh darn it.

Softball has to be one of the greatest sports alive, and playing softball in college has always been a goal of mine. I love the physicality of the game, the sweat, and the camaraderie with teammates. The memories made on the field are what truly last a lifetime. I had been part of a local team, Hood Stars, for almost four years, where I had formed strong bonds with my teammates. However, as my fifth year approached, I faced a decision. Should I stay comfortable with my current team or challenge myself by trying out for a more competitive team?  After much contemplation, I decided to take a chance and try out for the new team. The nerves were overwhelming as I approached the field, but the warm welcome and friendly demeanor of the new teammates put me at ease. Laughter filled the air, and I knew instantly that I had made the right choice. The friendships I formed with this new team were invaluable, and I realized the importance of stepping out of my comfort zone to grow both as a player and as a person.  While I had cherished memories with my original team, softball is ultimately about building connections with others and enjoying the game together. I am grateful for the opportunity to have met these wonderful new friends and experienced the joy of playing softball with them. In the end, it's the laughter and camaraderie that make the sport truly special.

Some people like making people laugh, I love it. I will do most anything to get a good laugh. I will make fun of my self, do insanely stupid things, and sometimes hurt myself (not in any serious way). When I was little I didn't really understand laughter. For some odd reason I could never tell the difference if people were laughing at something or laughing with it. I was kind of "special" in some areas as a kid (I still am today). Still at the tender age of five I loved making people laugh, and being special I would do even crazier things for a laugh. Mind you I was kind of a spaz, and a really big spaz. I was the most hyperactive five year old you will ever meet. For example one time I hit myself in the head with a hammer, another time I was dancing around in class with a pencil in my hand, stabbed myself in the head with it, and needed stitches. One of the craziest times though was a couple days before I had to take pictures and I wanted to go play outside, my mom knowing how "special" I was (I got it from her) wouldn't allow me to. The expert persuasive kid I was back then convinced her to let me go outside. Before I could even reach the street I fell head first on to the corner of the sidewalk leaving a huge mark and completely ruining the pictures. Although that might make some people laugh, this is a story about laughter not me being a spaz.  Now that you know that I love making people laugh, I'm "special", and that I'm a complete spaz I can get on with the story. Well I was in kindergarten and I loved school because I got to hang out with my friends and play with blocks, that might sound stupid but I was in kindergarten. The only thing I didn't like about kindergarten was bully's. Surprisingly I have never had a bully except kindergarten, but this was a bad bully. He would give me wedgies at story time and the whole deal (which was the best time to do so because the teacher could couldn't see). I still know the bully too, but he's no bully anymore, he's a goody two shoes now which I think is odd. Anyways, kindergarten was a very good year for me except one day (and every day I got a wedgies). That day is what this whole story is about, it's why I told you I love making people laugh, why I told you I'm "special", and a spaz, everything in the story circles around this one day, *dramatic pause* in kindergarten. It started out like any other day in kindergarten. I woke up, did my daily routine, hopped in the car, and headed to school. When I got to school I grabbed my daily binder and patted the education sign like a mall cop would pat the observe and report sign. I did all my work and colored (which was basically all my work). It came around break so we ran around the play ground and got are little snack. When we finished getting the last few drops out of our juice boxes we headed over to story time. We were all in the little circle (which was more like a deformed oval) listening to the story, right when I would get into the story and lose my guard I would receive an excruciatingly painful (for a five year old) wedgie. The story was almost finished and our five year old attention spans were wearing thin and we were getting all excited. The story finally finished and we were standing up, and this is where my memory starts to fade. I cracked a really funny joke and the whole kindergarten class erupted into laughter, me being a "special" spaz that can't tell if people are laughing at me or with me burst into tears. I remember balling my eyes out at the drinking fountain trying to hide my tears. One of the teachers tried to help me by telling me that they were laughing at my joke. It took me a couple minutes to stop crying but a little longer to realize the were not laughing at me.  To this day I still get reminded by classmates about that day, of course I can laugh about it now but that was in kindergarten, I'm in ninth grade now and for people to remember that is kind of crazy to me. It was a negative experience then, but it turned into a blessing in disguise. It made me grow into a better person, I can tell the difference of laughter and also be okay when people do laugh at me (doing dumb things to make people laugh at me is actually my forte). So remember, being "special" could sometimes be the best thing about you, what makes you who you are, what makes you great, what makes you grow, what makes people laugh.

I hang out with my friends, and the one thing we do best is laugh. Sometimes, we laugh for no reason at all. We find humor in running into trash cans, talking about our meals, or imagining funny scenarios like doing laundry in colorful aprons at a laundromat. One memorable incident involved my friend sliding into a trash can in the school hallway, creating hilarious sound effects that still make me chuckle. We also share inside jokes, like the idea of wearing rhinestone-studded aprons to do laundry together. Even discussing a disappointing frozen dinner can turn into a comedic moment. What I cherish most about my friends is our ability to have a great time together, no matter the circumstances. If we ever have a disagreement, we quickly make up because the reasons are usually trivial. For me, friendship is all about having fun, being silly, and sharing laughter with those who truly understand and appreciate your quirks. Looking back, these carefree moments spent with friends will always be cherished as the best days of my life.

Well, I went downtown to meet someone one cold, dark night, feeling a bit lost along the way. After a confusing bus ride, I finally figured out I was downtown. When I called the person I was meeting, they laughed at me for getting lost. Later, when I went to the store, I ended up getting lost again, but my friend called to guide me back. Despite their teasing, we had a good time hanging out. The night was filled with laughter and jokes about me getting lost, but in the end, I realized the importance of having friends to rely on in unfamiliar situations.

My best friend, @PERSON1 and I have been close ever since we were @NUM1. We met through @CAPS1 @CAPS2 lessons at our local dance studio. We've stayed close throughout the years because we've always done similar activities. We're very different from each other though. I'm more out going, I like to speak my mind and I'm more carefree. @CAPS4's the opposite. @CAPS4's very conservative and @CAPS4 can take things too seriously. But either way, we manage to even each other out. Finals week had just gotten over, and @LOCATION1 and I had been planning a sleepover all week. We just needed time to relax and have some time to ourselves. When I had gotten home from school, I gave her a quick call. "@CAPS3?" @CAPS4 answered. "@CAPS5, @CAPS12 time did @CAPS16 wanna hang out?" I asked. "I was thinking @NUM2?" "@CAPS6 good!" I quickly hung up the phone and gathered up my gear. I grabbed my toothbrush, pillow, pajamas, and my blanket. I put my shoes on and headed back out the door. My dad dropped me off with all of me gear. I had brought my pajamas, my pillow, and an extra blanket. I walked up her sidewalk to her door, knocked, and waited. Only seconds later did @CAPS4 answer it with a big smile across her face. @CAPS4 lead me down to her basement where @CAPS4 had all the junk food set out ready for us to attack. @CAPS4 had gone to the store earlier that day and had bought everything. @CAPS4 had set it all up on her old pool table that nobody used. There were chips, cookies, sodas, candy, chocolate, and pizza. I set my stuff down on the chair in the corner of the room and we feasted. Of course, we could eat all the food. We simply weren't big enough. After eating for almost an hour straight, we laid on her basement floor trying to gain composure. We started laughing at silly little things that came up on commercials on her big screen @CAPS7. Eventually, we got to talking about how each of our finals went. "I did soo good on all of mine! I'm gonna get ALL A's" @PERSON1 bragged. @CAPS4 has gotten straight A's every year since middle school. "I think I did pretty @CAPS8 too, not so sure about a @NUM3 though." I said as I was laying upside down on the floor. "@CAPS8, we'll just see tomorrow!" We finally decided to move ourselves over to the couch on the opposite side of the pool table, so we could face the @CAPS7. It was already @NUM4 in the @TIME1 and we were still on a sugar high. We switched back and forth from watching some old scary movie, and the top @NUM5 music videos of the week. That had passed some time and before we knew it, it was @NUM2 in the @TIME1. @PERSON1 and I were laying on opposite ends of each other. Occasionally, one of us would get some chips or candy from the table. We grew tired to the point where we couldn't keep our eyes open. No one even had enough energy to turn off the overhead light. We fell asleep fast. When I woke-up the next @TIME1, @PERSON1 wasn't laying across from me anymore. @CAPS4 was sitting in the corner chair where I had set my stuff. I looked at the clock, and it was already @NUM4:30 in the afternoon. I looked back and @LOCATION1, @CAPS4 seemed somewhat upset. I shifted around under my blanket so I could face her. "@CAPS5..." I grunted, while I was stretching. "@TIME1." @CAPS4 said abruptly. @CAPS4 was holding a folded piece of paper in her hand. "@CAPS12's up?" I asked, sitting up on the couch. @CAPS4 crumpled up the piece of paper and threw it at me. I picked it up from my lap and unfolded it. It was her report card. I looked up from the paper to see her hands covering her face. I walked over to her kinda amused by how upset @CAPS4 was. "@CAPS16 got a @CAPS13... and @CAPS16're crying?" I asked.

Laughter is essential in any relationship, whether it be with friends, loved ones, or colleagues. It helps to lighten the mood, relieve stress, and bring joy to those around you. Sometimes, all it takes is a good laugh to turn a bad day around. When someone is feeling down or struggling, a little bit of laughter can go a long way in cheering them up. It's important to make an effort to laugh every day, even when things seem tough.  Sharing a laugh with a friend or partner can strengthen your bond and create lasting memories. Seeing the people you care about smile and laugh can bring a sense of happiness and connection. Laughter can also help you cope with difficult situations and make life more enjoyable, even in the face of challenges.  In any relationship, laughter is a key ingredient for building a strong and positive connection. It can help you navigate through tough times and keep the bond between you and others strong. So, take a moment to chuckle, giggle, or laugh out loud - it's good for your soul and for those around you. Remember, a little laughter can go a long way in making life brighter and more enjoyable.

I believe that with all people laughter, and having a sense of humor, is something that generally everyone has in common, everyone loves to share with others. Among young teenage girls, laughter is a commodity that is infectious but always wonderful. It's the purest kind of joy we have, it's somethings that brings humans together. It's the beginning and end of friendship and unity. Laughter can ring out and lift the spirits of those that really need it. A simple laugh can make the worst day a little alright. We all know that feeling of dread, and sadness. The kindness, generosity, and good of laughter is one of the few things that are right nowadays. Even in poverty, depression, and oppression the simple joy of laughter can wash away a person's worries for a split second and fill us with utter warmth. @PERSON1 and I have been the best of friends since we were ten-years-old, and laughter has always been our strongest element. @PERSON1 and I have a knack for making each other burst out in laughter when all we want to do is be angry or just cry. We've decided that apart, we're just a little funny, but with our powers combined we could make anyone laugh. We use that power on each other when we're having bad days, or we simply need some cheering up. I think if it wasn't for laughter we wouldn't even be friends anymore. It really is what brings us together as best friends. We'd be different people. Even if I drifted from her we'd always be cracking jokes, making each others guts hurt, and tearing up from laughing so hard. My first impression of @PERSON1 was of her stomping down to our neighborhood park to yell at her sister, whom I had been playing with at the time. It would be a very self-explanatory reason of why I didn't like her at first. Luckily, after going to @PERSON1's house with her sister, @PERSON1 and I found that we had many things in common, and we were only four months apart. That childish kind of cajoling held our friendship together, for it was a bit rocky at the beginning. Always fighting, and arguing about things that now, we look back on and laugh at our adolescent stupidity. Either one of us would be popping off with dumb little comments at each other when neither of us wanted to apologize. One time she proceeded to tell me that I couldn't hear her because I had a big bug in my ear. Now we can remind each other of things like that and have a good ole time laughing about it. We were mere @NUM1-year-old's then. Now, almost @NUM2, we rarely fight, but we always laugh and make the best of what we've got with our poking fun. Laughter was definitely the band-aid in the beginning of our rickety friendship. @PERSON1 has a gift to make anything funny at any time. She says the wrong (but hilarious) things, but always at the right time. Laughter is now a necessity between us, it's what keeps our friendship so strong. I think of what the human race would be like if laughter was not a factor in everyday life. Everyone knows that it wasn't a good day if you haven't laughed or let alone smiled. People would be dull, and just unhappy. Laughter heals people from sickness, it gives us the feeling that maybe everything is going to be okay after all. I truly believe that it's healthy for you. With a flip of a switch, laughing can bring within us an ecstatic, and serendipitous feeling. People take it for granted and use it for wrong when it's meant to spread the word of happiness. We're lucky to have a gift of such natural joy. Can anyone even explain, in detail, the feeling laughter truly brings us? I think not. It's like describing the scent of something. You just can't do it. The words aren't there. I think of those poor and miserable people that have forgotten what it feels like to laugh, and it's very sad. I strive to laugh every single day, and make at least one other person laugh. What is a life without a diamond in the rough like laughter? It's no life at all, for laughter will always be your shelter on the pursuit of happiness. Laughter truly is a universal language that brings people together, heals wounds, and spreads joy in the darkest of times. It is a gift that should be cherished and shared among all, for it is the essence of human connection and happiness.

Laughter, one of life's greatest gifts. Have you ever laughed so hard that you cried? What about laughed so hard you can't breath, or noise no longer escapes from your lips? I am the type of person that can laugh at something so stupid that when I get done laughing, I don't even know why I started laughing in the first place. I can laugh so hard that nothing comes out at all! It's amazing what laughter can do to a person's heart. The way it makes you feel, the way it makes you act. It's so contagious, and it happens all around us every day. You are never too old for laughter, it happens to the best of us, young or old, it doesn't matter. Laughter has no age limit. One time my friends and I stayed up until three in the morning. We were so delirious and kooky, we acted like crazy people. Now we have the type of relationship where we can laugh at almost anything. Literally almost anything... As we were staying up, we drank lots of soda and had sugary foods to fuel us for the night. We made up songs, we danced around the house, and it felt like we laughed for hours! I laughed until tears were flowing out of my eyes, and I couldn't get a breath out of my heaving lungs. When it gets to the silent laughing, it's even more funny because that person can't control it, and they look so hilarious rocking back and forth with a silly expression on their face, not making any noise at all. Have you ever just laughed for what feels like a lifetime? How did you feel after that "lifetime" of laughter? It almost feels like something as powerful as the sun just warms over your heart and soul. When I laugh, I feel all the happiness and emotion flow throughout my entire body. It's one of the greatest feelings in the world, I really can't think of a greater feeling than the warmth that laughter brings. It's so great when you and a friend, or group of friends can sit back and enjoy the laughter you share. Even when you're feeling down, maybe need some cheering up, you can always depend on a laugh to pull you through. No matter what mood I'm in, if I hear someone laughing, it's hard to not join in. Laughing is so contagious! It affects us in our everyday lives. I bet you that you cannot go one day without hearing someone laugh, or you not laughing yourself. I probably laugh about five hundred times a day, if not more. I love hearing people laugh, it brightens my mood and also my day. I would most definitely say laughter is very important and beneficial for a relationship. I mean imagine the world without laughter. Boring, right? My advice, laugh like you heard the funniest thing in the world. Laugh like there is no tomorrow. Who cares if people think it's dumb. You'll feel much better after you have that tear-induced, hard to breath, silent but oh-so therapeutic laugh. Laughter really is the shortest distance between people!

Laughter is a vital part of our daily lives, bringing joy and light-heartedness to our interactions with others. Whether it's sharing a joke with friends, enjoying the antics of our pets, or experiencing the simple pleasures of nature, laughter is a universal language that connects us all. One memorable moment of laughter for me was a day spent at the beach with my friend and our horses. As we galloped along the shore, feeling the wind in our hair and the salty sea breeze on our faces, we couldn't help but laugh at the sheer exhilaration of the moment. Even as the day came to a close and we prepared to head home, the memory of our laughter and the shared experiences with our horses stayed with me, reminding me of the importance of finding joy and humor in every day. Laughter truly is the best medicine, and I am grateful for the moments of lightness and happiness it brings to my life.

Starting a story out with two 5-year-old boys named Jack and Max can already be considered a comedy. Those are the names of my identical twin cousins Jack and Max. I can honestly admit that they are two of the funniest kids I know. My uncle isn't exactly the most intelligent human on earth, but by the way he named his children, it's apparent that his sense of humor is a little bit off, but he's a really hardworking man. Occasionally, my mom does him favors by taking the twins off his hands for a little while because they can be a handful. Weekends are specifically better to have them over because of my hateful stepsiblings who hate me, my brother, my sister, and even my mom. The amount of tension in the house isn't a healthy amount, so a couple of 5-year-olds running around livens it up a little and makes us all laugh together as a family.  It must have been a Saturday in July when my mom was home, and we were building onto our house when the twins came over. My mom was getting quite furious at their insanely high energy levels; she appeared to be on the verge of ripping out all her hair. My stepdad needed to go to the hardware store for nails and child locks, and I decided to tag along with him. I thought it would have been a great idea to take the twins with us just to relieve my mom of the loud mouths for a few minutes.  We loaded up the car, and I drove down the highway, amused with the twins in the backseat playing with the ponies and laughing at the people stopped at red lights. We all sang songs like "Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star" and the ABC's until we arrived in the hardware store's parking lot. Jack finds it pretty hilarious to run down the aisles and hide behind items on the lower shelves, while Max enjoys pretending he's a ninja and getting everyone confused.  Eventually, the twins were being too obnoxious, resulting in my stepdad and me catching them and holding them as captives in the seat belts of the shopping cart. It was helpful but didn't do as much justice as we had hoped. We continued along on our adventure in search of the child locks, and we found them down aisle 4.  There was a large man standing in front of our destination, and when I say large, I don't mean muscular or tall... I mean he probably has a few too many TV shows he watches daily and maybe a few too many favorite snacks. His hair was long and sandy blond, he wore a dark purple tie-dye shirt and slip-on sandals. Jack apparently hadn't realized how inappropriate it is to talk about a person in a rude fashion, especially when they can hear you. He said, "Wow, look at that lady! She's so huge!" and Max laughed outrageously and agreed. "Yeah! She's as big as our whole car!" I panicked a bit and tried to get them to be quiet; however, the twins paid no attention to me. They were much more excited to see the man on the tall ladder and were giggling and laughing along with him. They were quiet for a moment, then gasped and exclaimed, "She's as big as a fire truck!" The man turned around and glared at me; I apologized at least five times and started to take the boys out of the aisle when the man on the ladder hit a button to make the ladder move.  I was walking behind the larger man when the ladder made a ridiculously loud beeping sound, like that of a construction vehicle. The boys screamed in fear and shouted frantically, "Run as fast as you can! Hurry! She's backing up, and she's going to squish you on the floor!" The man laughed, even the man they were making fun of, but I was so embarrassed that I just took them to the car and waited for my stepdad. I tried to explain to the boys in the car that only big trucks beep when they are backing up, but unsurprisingly, they didn't listen to a word I said.  My stepdad only took approximately five more minutes before he came jogging out the door with the nails, the child locks, and a gigantic smile plastered on his face. I thought about what had happened in the store, and I chuckled quietly until my stepdad hopped into the truck, then I started laughing profusely. When I returned home, I told my mom what had happened; she laughed for a while, and I laughed even harder and quite a bit longer than I had before. I went to sleep with a fairly massive headache that night, but I think it was worth laughing all day for.

When I meet new people, it's always an exciting opportunity to potentially form meaningful connections. Friends are important in life, and while some may come and go, true friends are the ones who stay by your side through thick and thin. I vividly remember the day I met a special girl named @PERSON1. From the moment we started talking, I felt a deep connection with her. It was as if fate had brought us together, and I knew that she was someone I wanted to share my life with.  As our relationship blossomed, I realized that my feelings for her were more than just friendship. I knew that I wanted to protect her, to cherish her, and to be there for her in every way possible. When I looked into her eyes, I could sense the pain she had experienced in the past, but I also saw a glimmer of hope and trust. I made a promise to her that I would always be there to mend her broken heart, to be her rock in times of need.  I reassured her that she was the one I had been searching for, the one who completed me in every sense. I pledged to stand by her side, to support her, and to love her unconditionally. She accepted my offer with joy and gratitude, knowing that I was different from anyone she had ever met before.  Our love grew stronger with each passing day, and I realized that she was not just a friend but a soulmate, a partner for life. Together, we faced challenges, celebrated joys, and built a bond that was unbreakable. She brought light into my life, turning my dark days into moments of happiness and warmth.  I made a vow to her that no matter what obstacles came our way, I would always be there for her, holding her hand and guiding her through the storm. Our love was like a beacon, shining bright in the darkest of times, reminding us of the strength we possessed together.  In her, I found my paradise, my world, my everything. She held the key to my heart, unlocking a love so deep and profound that I knew it would last a lifetime. Our love story was not just a tale of romance but a testament to the power of true love, of two souls finding each other in a chaotic world.  As we journeyed together, I realized that our love was a rare and precious gift, one that I would always cherish and protect. She was not just a friend â€“ she was my angel, my shawty, my wifey, my everything. And as long as the stars shone in the sky, our love would continue to illuminate the darkness, a guiding light for each other's hearts.  In her, I found a love that was pure, genuine, and everlasting. And I knew, without a doubt, that she was the one I had been waiting for, the one who would always have my heart. Our love was a story of hope, of faith, and of unwavering devotion. And I was grateful every day that she had come into my life, bringing with her a love that was truly meant to be.

People always say laughter is a big part in a relationship. In my opinion, I am not so sure, but my grandmother says laughter is always a huge part in a relationship. Makes you feel good when you make your best friend, parents, boyfriend, or girlfriend laugh. It is the best feeling ever because you know how to put a smile on that person. Have you ever been walking around a store and you spot two couples laughing, having fun? I have and sometimes I feel like being in that same place. My grandmother always tells me her stories about her and my grandpa when they were young. She always says "laughter plays a big part in our relationship." She was 17 and he was 18 the first time they met. Everyone always said they were never going to last, but the only way they could find out is to wait and believe. She felt like singing every time she heard his name. She said she would walk into their shadows with him. She felt like all her problems would go away every time she had the chance to hang out with him. Every time she could think about him she would smile and laugh. That's how happy she felt about him. Can we call it love? I say it was, sometimes I wish I was in love like my grandmother is. She seems so happy every time she talks about him, but I still don't know if laughter is what kept them together for so long. I see a really huge smile on my grandmother every time she says, "he didn't have the brightest head in the world, but he always knew how to put a smile on my face." Because she says that he wasn't so smart but he knew how to make jokes and make her laugh. A question she asked me once "do you think of two couples when you see them laughing, having a good time?" The first thing that pops into your head is that they know how to have fun and don't let anything get in their ways of laughing and having a good time. My grandmother says that the thing that kept her and my grandpa together was laughter, because if you don't know how to make the other person laugh you don't know if you could have a good time with that person. When my grandparents are mad at each other it never lasts too long because my grandpa always knows how to make her laugh. Maybe if they didn't know how to make each other laugh than maybe they wouldn't be together still. I understand now my grandmother fell in love with my grandpa because of how he made her laugh. In a relationship you always have to know how to put a smile on the other person, because if you don't know then pretty sure things will not work out. My grandmother was right, laughter does play a big part in their relationship. They always know how to make everything better by making jokes or by doing something funny. I can never be mad at my grandparents because they know so many tricks to make myself laugh. That's what makes our family relationship stick together, and other families also. I finally get it, laughter is a big part in a relationship.

"Laughter is the best medicine." The phrase almost everyone has heard before. But it's true! I've had days when all I could think about was how life sucked, or at least seemed to. The days when you feel like everything is going wrong, and nothing could make it worse... And that's when one of my best friends will make me laugh. I'll laugh so hard I'm on the verge of peeing my pants and my eyes water. I'll laugh so hard no sound comes out, my sides cramp and I fall on the floor. They make me laugh so hard, sometimes I think that even if I was in a coma, they'd say something so funny that I'd sit straight up in the hospital bed and laugh the huge belly laugh that sometimes escapes me.  There was this particular time when one of my friends and I were feeling more giggly than usual. It tends to happen a lot when we're together, but this time was way different than the others. We staggered to her house flushed and giddy at how funny everything was. You know how it is when you and your best friends get so tickled by each other? Those times when you glance at your friend and as you've begun to calm down, you see her pinched expression from trying not to laugh, and you lose it all over again. If you've ever had the pleasure of experiencing these silly moments, try imagining that feeling for hours at a time. I'm pretty sure I developed a whole new set of abdominal muscles that day, if that gives you any idea how hard we were laughing.  Anyway, we stumbled into her house, trying to get serious, since we did have to do at least some of our homework. Of course we were starving after all that laughing, so she told me and another friend that we could get some cereal. Just regular milk and cereal, right? There's nothing special about eating (besides that it's freaking delicious). But on that day, everything was out of the ordinary, especially the milk. It was the most amazing milk I'd ever tasted, and I love milk, so that had to mean something. "This milk is so good! I love it!" my friend exclaimed. I swear she was about to choke on her own spoon, she was eating so fast. "Are you kidding me with this? What kind of milk do you buy?!" I blurted out. For some reason that milk was really extraordinary, and it was seriously blowing my mind. "Oh, I don't know. Two percent?" she looked at us incredulously, a curious eyebrow raised at our inquiries. Her expression made us all fall apart in peals of laughter. Now whenever one of us brings it up, we still laugh like it just happened.  At one point, it happened. She peed her pants, and not just a little. It wasn't the idle threat rushed out, the "I'm going to pee!" squeal. No. She actually peed herself, and I still can't even remember what I said to make her laugh that hard. All I know is suddenly (scaring me half way to death), she yelled out, "I love you guys! THERE's a lot of love and laughter happening here!" I whipped around and saw her, red-faced and open-mouthed, supporting herself against the counter. She looked like the freaking queen of comedy all bent over like she was. Her eyes were closed tight, crinkling at the corners, a few stray tears escaping as she tried to hold in shrieks of (apparently) crippling laughter. It took me a second to realize what was going on, and then I was totally straight out laughing at her; pointing and laughing shoulder-shake laugh, and it only made her laugh harder. Still laughing, she did a penguin-type run down the hall to the bathroom, where my other friend was. She, in her wet jeans and with a red, tear streaked face, burst through the bathroom door, looking slightly bewildered and amused with what had happened. So naturally, we laughed at the sight of her, in her comically delirious state. Who wouldn't have?  The fact that we always laugh at each other and ourselves is why I love my friends. It's great when you have people that you can laugh about everything and nothing with. She is practically a walking ego boost because she laughs at every joke, and my other friend is pretty clever when it comes to thinking of them. Personally, I love laughing, especially with (and mostly at) my best friends.

One time when I was skateboarding with my friend, I got really mad and wanted to stop skating. His mom tried to convince me to keep skateboarding. She laughed and said I will never be good enough to skate, but then she mentioned that I have improved more than some of the people she knows. That made me feel better, and I started skateboarding every day from then on. When I think about that day, I still laugh. Skating can be fun in many ways, and people can skate for fun or for competition. There are different ways of skating, and people have their own unique styles. There are many different kinds of skateboards, and the way people ride them varies. Some skaters make me laugh because of the way they skate. Despite that, I continue to enjoy skateboarding and appreciate the different styles people bring to the sport.

"Laughter" A good relationship is built on trust, right? That's what I've heard my whole life, but as I've grown and really started thinking for myself, I came up with my own kind of survival guide, if you will, to good relationships for anyone. Sure, trust is important, but it isn't the only key factor. I've learned that laughter is just as important to not only starting a relationship but also keeping it full of life. One person in my life helped me really understand that and be able to have that relationship with them. My mom and I have such a great bond and way of understanding with each other, other girls I know don't always have that with their mothers, I am very fortunate.  Sure, we have hard times just like any family, but we are able to laugh it off with time and start anew. It helped me realize, "Laughter is the shortest distance between two people." Having a great bond with my mom is so important to me, we have not always run so smoothly though. From about age ten to thirteen, I was a bit troubled in the sense of not wanting to show my emotions, I just wanted to stay quiet. Then seeing my mom as someone who was strong and beautiful, I have to admit I was a bit worried she would think I was a disappointment. I guess I was afraid to show who I really was to her.  Whenever she would joke around with me I would take it all too seriously, and whenever we would fight about small things I thought she would hate me forever. I know now I was silly to think that, but I'm actually glad we went through that. I think that's part of what made us stronger, like how there would be no rainbow without the rain or how there would be no happy ending if all was well throughout your whole life. Little did I know the light at the end of the tunnel was just around the corner.  One night after dinner, my mom had informed me that it was my night to do dishes, unlike usual I completely forgot and went to my room to listen to music and eventually fall asleep. My mother came into my room upset and frustrated. She said, "Why did you ignore me? The dishes need to be done now." I jumped out of bed without a word and began walking to the kitchen. She followed me into the small bright room, "Are you alright, it's okay that you forgot. I'm not mad." She exclaimed. Again not a word escaped my lips. I was afraid to say anything, the only sound that came from me was a sigh of relief when I turned back around and noted her absence. When I was finished with the dishes, she pulled me into my room. I tried reading her face, she looked worried. She explained to me the relationship between her and her mom that she so desperately wanted to have with me. She told me about how they would laugh together over silly things and how they promised each other that when they got into fights they would stop themselves, take a deep breath, then laugh. "Laughter is the best cure for any sad feeling or bad day, as grandma would always say."  She helped me experience that by tickling me and joking around. For the first time in my life, I wasn't nervous and I spoke my mind. As we sat there and chuckled ourselves to sleep I knew things would be different from here on out, and they were. We now have made that promise to one another and we are able to have wonderful smiling memories together now. Now at fifteen years old, I can honestly say without question my mom will always be my best and truest friend. Our bond, our way of getting over tough times, and the way we can laugh off all stressful things in life makes me feel as if I can get through anything. I've truly realized the meaning of the saying, "Laughter is the shortest distance between two people."

Laughter is truly a precious gift that can bring people closer together and create unforgettable memories. My boyfriend is not only my partner but also my best friend, with whom I share countless moments of joy and laughter. One late evening, as he playfully pretended to get pulled into tall grass and then "lost" his shoe, we ended up spending hours searching and laughing until our stomachs hurt. These are the moments that I cherish the most, the times when we can just be ourselves and enjoy each other's company. Laughter truly is the best exercise for the soul, and I am grateful to have such a wonderful friend in my life to share these moments with. With friends like him, every day is filled with smiles and laughter, making life so much brighter and more enjoyable. Laughing together is a bond that strengthens our relationship and creates memories that will last a lifetime.

Laughter is a key component of relationships, creating a strong bond between individuals. It brings joy, lightens the mood, and helps people connect on a deeper level. In my own relationship with @PERSON1, laughter plays a significant role, as we share jokes and funny moments that bring us closer together. Without laughter, a relationship can feel dull and unfulfilling, which is why I prioritize humor in my interactions with others.  Not only do humans benefit from laughter, but animals can also be a source of joy and amusement. My cat, @CAPS1, and horse, @CAPS2, bring laughter into my life with their playful antics and unique personalities. Whether it's watching @CAPS1 zoom around the house after eating or seeing @CAPS2 playfully interacting with other horses, their presence brings a smile to my face.  Ultimately, laughter is a universal language that transcends barriers and brings people, and even animals, together. It is a powerful tool that can strengthen relationships, improve mood, and create lasting memories. In a world full of stress and challenges, the ability to laugh and find humor in everyday situations is truly a gift that should be cherished and embraced.

Everyone enjoys laughter, which stems from happiness and joy in one's life. Personally, my niece brings me immense joy and laughter. At two years old, she exudes happiness and carefreeness, which is infectious. Playing with her and watching her giggle uncontrollably, especially when she hears a silly song from her cookie jar toy, never fails to make me laugh. Recently, my nephew joined the family, and seeing my niece burst into laughter at his antics brings even more joy and laughter into our lives. These moments remind me of the power of laughter in bringing happiness and creating precious memories. Laughter, often sparked by simple and innocent moments, is truly a reflection of the joy and contentment in our lives.

Laughter has a unique way of bringing people together, creating bonds and shared memories that can last a lifetime. Even in the midst of a bad day, moments of humor and laughter can turn things around, making even the most frustrating situations into unforgettable experiences. Such was the case during a hunting trip that started off on the wrong foot but ended with uncontrollable laughter. From forgotten clothes and missing guns to broken eggs and a muddy truck, every mishap only added to the comedy of errors that unfolded throughout the day. Despite the setbacks and disappointments, the camaraderie between friends grew stronger as they faced each challenge with humor and resilience. In the end, what could have been a disastrous day turned into a collection of hilarious moments that brought the group closer together. Laughter truly has the power to turn even the worst situations into cherished memories that will be retold and laughed about for years to come.

"@CAPS1 figure something out to do! I am really freaking bored!" @CAPS2 explained as all of us relaxed next to his dark blue @CAPS3 parked outside of my house. The @ORGANIZATION1 was young, and we were eager for some excitement.   "Gather around, guys, I have a plan!" I exclaimed. "@CAPS1, I have an idea that will be hilarious and adventurous." Excited, @CAPS6 chimed in, "I'm up for anything, let's hear it!"   I proposed a mischievous plan involving buying cheap saran wrap from town and setting up a prank at a four-way intersection near my neighborhood. Everyone loved the idea, and @CAPS2 volunteered to drive into town to get the supplies. We pooled our money and eagerly awaited his return.  After a short wait, @CAPS2 texted us that he was ready at the intersection. We quickly made our way there, with excitement building as we approached the spot. Working swiftly, @CAPS2 and I wrapped the saran wrap around trees on opposite sides of the street, creating a makeshift barrier.  As we waited for a car to approach, adrenaline pumped through our veins. Finally, a car sped down the road and plowed through the saran wrap, coming to an abrupt halt. Laughter erupted as we watched the chaos unfold.  However, our laughter quickly turned to panic when the enraged driver emerged from his car and began chasing us. We sprinted back to my house, but @CAPS6 got caught by the angry man, returning with soda all over himself, much to our amusement.  As the night came to a close, we all settled in for the night, still chuckling at the day's events. It was a memorable and hilarious adventure that we would never forget.

Interesting flight. It was the 13th of this December, after a long day with some crying and lots of goodbyes, I was finally in the airport, waiting for my plane to Paris. I've been in that airport so many times... I love traveling but it's always exciting to go on a vacation, even though I do it with my parents pretty frequently. Today was different, this wasn't a vacation. It was going to be a whole year, and my parents weren't going to be there. Just the thought of being away from them and all my friends in Paris for such a long time made my stomach sick. Especially because in Paris, I was going to be meeting my host parents that I never saw before, and I was wondering if they were going to be normal people or a pair of completely weirdos.  Once in the plane, I sat with a young girl that was in Paris studying architecture and going back home for winter, while I was just leaving for a year. She asked me if I spoke English, and I said, "I try to." She laughed and looked nice, with a big smile, and was pretty too. We started talking and I could feel how nervous and anxious I was. She asked me if I was okay and I told her about being a foreign exchange student for the next year and my concerns about it, like meeting people or missing home. She told me, "You will be fine, don't worry about it... I wish I had that chance when I was your age," and then changed the subject.  After a long conversation, she started reading a magazine and I put on my music. When we were about to get to Paris, she suddenly screamed so hard that made me jump, and we laughed for a long time. She couldn't even talk to me to explain why she screamed because everybody was looking at us, and that made it even funnier and kind of embarrassing too so we could not stop laughing. Then she told me that the guy in the picture of her magazine went to high school with her a few years ago, and they were together for some time but since graduation, they didn't know anything about each other. He was now working at a bank and making good money, really good money... She was going crazy talking to herself and asking why in the world she stopped talking with him. That good time with her, even if I haven't seen her again, made me really happy, and by the time we got off the plane, I was more confident and almost forgot about all the nervousness that I had before.  After two months here, everything is going perfectly, and I'm sure that even if it was just a few laughs and not a really long time on that plane, when I go back to Paris, I will think about her, and I'll count that moment as my first good experience. She made a difference in my journey and helped me feel more at ease about the year ahead.

In many relationships I have had, there has always been laughter, love, sadness, anger, and complications. Although there has been one person I had a relationship with that did not involve laughter and it was rather boring and sad. I would spend tremendous hours of my time just to get one little giggle or sound of laughter out of him. He was a rather gentle soul and could never harm a fly, but still could not laugh even though he was happy. I would ask many times over and over, "Are you sure you're happy because you don't seem like it? I never see you smiling or laughing, all I see is a frown," I told him with a sour face. He replied back, "Yes, I am happy, but just because I don't laugh doesn't mean I am not. And besides, with that silly grin on your face, how could I not be happy?" With that reply, I simply shrugged and began again. "Then why can't you laugh?" He replied back in a drowsy voice because he was getting tired of the same topic every day. "It's not that I can't laugh, it's that I choose not to," he said. I asked, "Well, why on earth would you do that?" He sighed and huffed, really getting tired of the topic. "Alright, if you don't stop this," he said in a gentle but strained voice, "I'm going to have to stop being so nice to you, and I just might not talk to you for the rest of the year." But of course, he was only joking. He could never not be nice to me, and besides, he was my best friend; he couldn't not talk to me. The topic was dropped and never brought up again until the day I saw him.  It was a cold day when I walked out of my house one morning to go to school. I saw a big moving rental truck outside of his house and instantly knew that he had not lied to me but rather did not tell me that he was moving away. I began to think that it was because of me always asking him why he would not laugh, but that would be a silly reason to leave. I went over to his house, not caring if I was late or never did show up for school that day, I had to figure out why he was leaving. Once I got to the porch of his house, he was walking to the door, and I blocked the doorway so that he could not go any further, making sure that if he wanted to get the box of clothes to the truck, he would have to answer me. I asked him, and he said, "My father got a promotion at work, and now we have to move to New York." I began to cry as he told me this. I was young, about eight years of age, and he was twelve. I knew I was not going to get to see him again, so I made sure that before I left for school that day, we would hang out before he left. That night at the park, he told me willingly without me asking him.  "@CAPS1, I know you have always wondered why I don't laugh," he said and went on, "Like I said, it's not that I can't laugh, it's that I don't want to. When I was young, I was teased because of my smile." I didn't understand; why would anyone tease him? So I asked, "Why, though? Why would someone tease you? You're nice," and he replied, "Because before my new teeth grew in, my old ones didn't look so great." And once again, I was still puzzled; his teeth looked good to me, so I asked again, "Then why don't you smile now? Your teeth look fine to me." He said, "I would, but I don't know. After being teased for so many years, I just didn't feel the need to. And now, well... I could smile, and truth be told, I want to." I said, "Really!?" with too much excitement. "Yes, and the only reason is you. You're about the only person that makes me want to smile. It's because of that grin you always have, you're always so happy. I just couldn't admit it to myself, well because you're a girl, and to me, I guess having a girl make me want to smile and being my only friend that is younger than me makes me feel a little weak." I didn't understand this at the time, but now that I am older, I do, and I am so glad that I had that one night to see his smile and many phone calls to hear his laughter. I once heard that laughter is the shortest distance between two people, and quite frankly, it is absolutely true because after

These days you don't really need a reason to laugh. Laughter just radiates out of some people as frequent as a breath of air. I believe that everyone has someone they can laugh with because everyone has someone they enjoy being around. One of the people I enjoy being around most is my best friend @PERSON1. No matter what the situation, whenever we are around each other we end up having fun. Laughter can turn a bad day completely around. One of my most recent examples of the power of laughter happened just a few weeks ago. One of my, "friends", tried to play a cruel joke on me that ended up being a bigger mistake than she could have imagined. Once I had figured out that this person whom I once trusted was trying to spite me I became overwhelmed with my emotions. At one point I actually considered attacking this girl right in the middle of every one in school. Thankfully I used my better judgment to run away from her, and hide instead of hurt her. Half of the class period progressed and I was still very upset and unprepared to confront her. So there I stayed safe in hiding until my best friend found me. @PERSON1 had come to comfort me after she got wind of what happened. She talked to me until I calmed down and my tears stopped. She made me feel much better. Her just being there for me, and being able to reminisce in the fun times we had together and the laughs we shared, seemed to make all my problems disappear. Eventually she convinced me to go talk to my, "friend", who as it turns out was ashamed of herself for her actions. We were able to make up and return to a somewhat normal life. To this day and more than likely for the rest of my life I will believe that laughter is the best medicine. I guess I'm lucky in that I have found the best person in life for me to share all of my laughter with. Every body has to have a somebody. Laughter truly is a powerful tool that can mend relationships and heal wounds.

Friends are not always easy to find, but with a smile and a laugh, a friendship can blossom. I didn't expect to make a new friend when I moved to a new town, but that's exactly what happened during my sixth-grade year at @ORGANIZATION1. In a class where I learned about riding unicycles, I met a girl named @CAPS3 who would become my best friend. Our bond was formed through shared laughter and silly moments, like falling off the unicycle together and laughing until we couldn't breathe. These moments of joy brought us closer and laid the foundation for a strong friendship. Now, we cherish the memories of those early days and continue to share laughter, believing that it keeps us young at heart. Laughter truly has the power to forge deep connections and create lasting friendships that enrich our lives.

It was a normal bright and warm summer day, going into my fifth grade year. My older sister and I had been playing all day with my other neighbors that were around our age. One of those neighbors happened to be a boy. We could not find anything to do. It was too hot out to just go walk around in the sun, so we decided that it would be cool to play in the shade with the new slingshot my dad had made. He made it out of an old swing set seat and I thought my neighbor would really enjoy it. We all headed into our garage to get it. My sister offered to get it down for me since she was taller and it was hanging up pretty high, but I refused. It was my idea to show him so I would be the one to get it. As I was in total concentration, stretching and reaching to grab it, I noticed everyone around me giggling. My concentration got weaker as I begun to wonder what they were all laughing at. I stood there confused for a minute before I had found out what happened. My sister pulled down my pants.. in front of our boy neighbor. I picked my pants up off the ground, looked straight at my sister, and started beating her with my flimsy loose fists. I ran straight to my room, crying all the way there.   My sister came in a few moments later trying to bribe me out from under the covers with the last two fruit roll-ups. She sat on my bed waiting for half an hour, I didn't budge. She did not say anything but I could feel her eyes piercing me through the sheets. Later that night I finally came out. My sister kept on apologizing but it didn't matter to me because I was upset with her, that's all that mattered. The whole next day passed and nothing had changed. She was still apologizing and I was still in the ignoring mood. My dad came up to me and told me that she was terribly sorry and upset too because I was not talking to her. I thought in my head, "how could she be upset.." but I realized I had not treated her right, even though I wasn't happy with her.   After hearing what my dad had said, I decided that it wasn't worth it. I went and talked to my sister for the first time in days. She told me that she didn't mean to hurt my feelings, she was just messing around. After talking about it for a while I concluded that I got so upset because she did it in front of our friend. We joke around like that all the time, but it's never in front of anyone besides family. I was scared that it would have frightened our neighbor friend away, but he was back to play in a few days so I had nothing to be mad about.   Even though I was embarrassed, I admitted that it was pretty funny. We had a good laugh about it and were no longer enemies. I learned that dwelling over the past gets you nowhere and you have to learn to laugh things off. Ever since then, every time it is brought up, we laugh so hard tears role down our face. I would not have considered it a good thing when it happened, but I do now. It is another memory that my sister and I share and can reminisce about. The more laughable memories you share, the closer it brings you to someone.

Making someone laugh is truly a wonderful feeling. It not only brightens their day but also uplifts your own spirits. I believe that spreading joy and laughter is one of the most fulfilling things we can do for others. My mother, who has a fantastic sense of humor, always finds a way to make me smile, even on my darkest days. Laughter has a magical way of easing tension, breaking the ice, and fostering connections between people. It is said that laughter is good for the soul, and I couldn't agree more. It is like a healing balm that brings people together and creates a positive atmosphere. My mom's laughter is contagious, and whenever she is feeling down, I do my best to cheer her up by doing something silly or telling a joke. Seeing her smile again brings me immense joy and reminds me of the power of laughter to heal and uplift. Laughter truly is the best medicine, and I am grateful for the moments of joy and connection it brings to my life.

"Laughter is the key to the soul." Whether you are having the worst day of your life, or the best day of your life, laughing can always make it better. I was sitting in class one day, and was bored out of my mind. Then, a shy, quiet kid, all of a sudden started laughing! They couldn't stop! It was like they were on "laughing gas." They laughed so hard they couldn't breathe. Now this made me laugh, and then my best friend sitting next to me laughed. Soon enough the entire class was laughing! So even though some of the people in the class might have been bored, or had a bad day, the laughter was spread throughout the room, making it a better day. Laughter spreads like wildfire, and it makes everyone happier. And when you are happier, you are healthier. So with that, a relationship must have laughter in it, in order to work. When you ask someone what they like about their boyfriend or girlfriend, if it is a good relationship, they will almost always say, "he/she makes me laugh." Because when you don't have laughter in a relationship, you end up in more fights, more disagreements, and more disappointment. The more you laugh the more you can live a better life and enjoy life more. Have you laughed today? Laughter truly is the best medicine for the soul.

Their are many joys in life, some more relevant than others, and some so obvious you'd be stupid not to notice them. Have you ever sat on your porch or stared out the window to watch the sun rise, pondering your life and its unusual qualities? Reflecting on all the memories, laughs, sorrows, pain, love, and hate. It's common to think about what could be changed, or if you'd leave it as is, feeling complete without regrets.  Despite the tears and pain, there have always been laughs to outweigh the sadness. I've learned that unexpected things will always happen, no matter how much you plan. Happiness isn't hard to achieve - keep an open mind, a light heart, and find joy in the world around you.  There are many things that keep me going - love, laughter, new beginnings, old endings, and the endless possibilities of the universe. I remember a time when I felt lost and unhappy, but looking at the stars one night, I realized there was so much more to experience if I kept going.  I strive to be a better person, to have a bright future with a deep love story to share. I want to find peace, protect animals, and work towards a cleaner, healthier planet. Even though I am small, I know my actions can make a difference. I aim to leave a positive impact on this shared home of ours, creating a better world for future generations to enjoy.

As I waited in the car, anxious to meet my best friend and man I'm in love with, I started to laugh. Not because something my mother or brother said was funny, or because I saw something funny, but I was nervous. I'd talked to him countless times on the phone, many text messages, and emails. But I was still nervous. I knew him better than I knew most people, yet my anxiety seemed to be making me lose my sanity.  As our black rental sedan pulled up to where he was waiting outside of where his family lived, I got more nervous. What if he wasn't actually the way I thought he was? What if he didn't like me? What if I didn't like him? As soon as he stepped into the car, smiling brightly at me, my nervous laughter and my anxiety all melted away. I smiled back.  "Hey, John," he said.  "Hey, Mark," I said, butterflies in my stomach. I was smiling broadly still, he reached out and cautiously took my hand.  "How was the drive?" he asked, lightly squeezing my hand.  Good, and nerve-wracking," I replied, nervous laughter bubbling up again.  "But you're here now, and I'm very happy you are," he said, smiling. And for the rest of the car ride to the restaurant our conversation flowed so smoothly I thought I was dreaming. Here him and I were two guys in love with one another, a new thing for both of us, and we were happy as can be. The whole car ride we held hands and talked, I felt like I'd known him my whole life. Not just the year and a half I'd known him.  We arrived at the restaurant all too fast and all of us got out of the car, I was famished and so was he. But we had to wait for a table for a half-hour before we sat down. Once at the dinner table my mother, who was very happy I found someone I loved so much and knew of our love, started regaling us with tales of my childhood. It was one of the most embarrassing moments of my life. I was bright red for almost the entire time she told these stories. Some of which I remembered, others I did not. Mark laughed and joked with me about all of them. Which made my nervous laughter come out as actual laughter. It also helped that he was holding my hand under the table.  After we ate dinner and dessert we went to the nearby mall for some shopping and to just hang out. My mom and brother went one way, and Mark and I went another. We bought some clothes together and finally ended up in a book store. My favorite book store. Back in my favorite section, young adult fiction, I noticed Mark staring at me.  "What?" I asked stupidly. He smiled deviously.  "You just look very... In your element," he smirked.  "Huh?" I said, in mock confusion. He just smiled and took my hand in his again. "No problem," he said, squeezing my hand. He pulled me closer to him, we were the only people in this area of the store. "Mind if I'm a little forward?" he asked. I shook my head no. He leaned in and kissed me very gently on the lips, I blushed a bright red and started to giggle after our lips parted. He quirked an eyebrow, I knew what he was thinking just by the look on his face.  "That felt fantastic," I said, putting my fingers on my lips. I had a silly grin on my face.  "Good," he simply said, kissing me again. "I love your laugh, love," he told me, I was on cloud nine, I was truly in love with somebody and I felt great! I'd never been this happy before. Except maybe the first time I went to Disney World. But this was definitely better, because it could last much longer. Which it has, since we've been together ever since. Both our gazes fixed on our future together. Now whenever I remember that I start to giggle happily to myself. Yes I get a stare every once in a while, but I don't care. Laughter is the thing that helped bridge the gap between him and I. Making us the closest we've ever been.

Sometimes I wonder why people laugh. People laugh when something is funny or when things are awkward and they aren't sure what else to do. Often people laugh when they are embarrassed or offended. I, actually, find myself laughing for no reason on occasion. If I can make someone laugh I usually feel very accomplished. I think it personally shows emotions out loud. But, in some cases, you laugh uncontrollably at yourself. Every year, since I moved here six years ago, my two cousins and my sisters and I have gone "cheese ball caroling" with our grandparents around Christmas time. Even after my grandpa died in 2014 and my older sister left for college. On the twenty-first of December, we go secret Santa shopping one at a time with one of our grandparents while we make the cheese balls by hand. After all five of us have gone, we wrap the cheese balls and put a ribbon on them while we practice our carols for that evening. We always make a list before we start the caroling. First thing on the list is the people who's houses we are going to go to that night. Second next to each family's name is the number of cheese balls we will be delivering to that specific house. Third is what song we are going to sing to them. Usually, there is about twenty-five to thirty people on the list. All of which are family members and really close friends or people from their work. We always have a really good time with it too. No fighting or bickering or anything like that. It's really nice to just be with the family and catch up. Usually, it's been about a year since we have all been together at the same time. Last year was the first year we went caroling without my older sister. She went off to college the year before, leaving me the oldest grandkid there. At first it didn't seem any different, but as the day went on I could feel it taking its toll. With her being gone and my grandpa no longer being around made the pressure build uncontrollably. I started to relax a little when we got started and just tried to have fun. My grandma yelled to me to grab the list and add a name. At first, I didn't think anything of it. Later she told us we had to come up with a special song for the family. And that's when it hit me. The name looked and sounded familiar because I used to go to school with a boy with the same last name. That's when I asked her to verify if it was the same family. Sure enough, it was. I had had a crush on this boy since I could remember. We lost contact after I had found out he liked my cousin though. I knew it was going to be extremely awkward to have to sing in front of him, not to mention embarrassing. I remember thinking "Oh great, this is just what I needed. This is going to be awesome." We did our rounds and everything went very smoothly. We were having tons of fun, making jokes and laughing at absolutely everything. Then it came time to go to "his" house. We all choked up. The girls had heard many things about how cute and dreamlike this boy was so they were all nervous too. We were sitting there in the truck telling ourselves he won't be home, and even if he was it would be fine and we would be fine. I think that was the longest walk to a house with that short of a walkway ever. My grandma rang the doorbell and we positioned ourselves to be ready to sing when the door opened. To our dismay, he answered it. We froze! We were like gargoyles gawking at him. He gave us a weird look and said "Are you going to sing or just stand there?" with an evil little smile. I did attempt to sing, but nothing came out. That's when the youngest cousin starts singing happy birthday. That was not the song we had planned for this house, and it was not his birthday. In the middle of the second "happy birthday to you" we all start cracking up laughing, and I don't mean giggling or a small laugh. We were all laughing hysterically to the point where we could not breathe, and he shut the door. I know if we would have just stood there it would have made that memory a lot more dreadful, but because we all were laughing, we can look back and laugh at ourselves for it. Laughing is a good way to release inner emotional pressure I realized that night. It's a memory I'm sure we will never forget. I have done something like that on multiple occasions but that was definitely number one on my list of "what were you thinking" moments. I wouldn't change anything about it.

It is important to embrace moments of humor and laughter in our lives, as they can bring joy and lightness to even the most challenging situations. So, let's remember to always find reasons to laugh and share our funny stories with others, as laughter truly is the key to complete happiness.
