Laughter and exuberance are key elements in any good relationship. Being able to be giddy and joyful with someone close to you is a sign of comfort. It often can bring people closer and help to solidify their friendships. Your true self is shown in your humor. Two years ago when I was in seventh grade math class at school, I was chosen to be in the special math group along with just three other classmates. Being in this group simply meant that we would be teaching ourselves advanced math using only textbooks, while our teacher would teach the rest of the class an easier math curriculum. The group was almost like an elite club. Our other classmates looked upon us with jealousy because we got to sit in the back of the classroom together, never had to do any homework, and were never called upon out of the blue to answer questions in front of the whole class. Being the immature seventh graders that we were, we abused this incredible opportunity that we had. I became fast friends with the three other people in the group. Their names were Sarah, Jack, and Emily. Sarah and I were already friends, but it was working together in the group that really brought us closer together. I also became close with Nathan and Emily. To this day, Sarah is one of my very best friends and I still keep in touch with the other two. We were all very different from each other. Nathan was caught up in the popular crowd, Emily usually hung out with the really smart kids who were into chess and reading books, and Sarah and I were just normal. However, we all had two important things in common; our sick sense of humor and our intelligence. We each felt that the work we were teaching ourselves was much too easy. We breezed right through the book and never really had any questions. In doing so, we always finished our assigned work quickly and had more than half of the class left to just sit there, eat, and goof off. "@ORGANIZATION2 guys, I don't feel like doing math today. I'm beat," I complained as we walked into the classroom for math right after lunch. "Me neither," Sarah replied. "I say we just sit there and make it look like we're doing work." We made our way to the table in the back where Nathan and Emily were already sitting. They had their books, pencils, and spirals out, but sat there with vacant expressions. Sarah and I joined them in sitting and we all exchanged disgruntled looks. "Hey, I was talking to Nathan earlier and he said that we don't have to do any work today. We can just sit here and hang out," I lied, not even bothering to hide my smirk. Catching on, Nathan and Emily grinned. Emily turned around and pulled a brown paper bag out of her backpack. She began to pull food out of the bag and offered it all up to us. I immediately grabbed the miniature chocolate pie. Midway through eating it, I dipped my finger in the gooey chocolate and wiped a big blob of it on the window behind Sarah. Nathan noticed and immediately started to chuckle. "Sarah, what's that?!" he exclaimed, loud enough for everyone in the class to hear. Our teacher and a few classmates glanced over briefly, but got back to the lesson instantly. It really wasn't funny at all, but the four of us dissolved into giggles. "Hey guys, I had this crazy dream last night," Emily said as the laughter died down. "I went to this camp thing, and Mr. Johnson was one of the camp counselors. He was wearing khaki pants and a white shirt with blue pinstripes. Oh, and he also had a clipboard!" We stared at her blankly and then burst out laughing once more. The funny thing about it, was that Mr. Johnson often substituted for our teachers, and he wore that exact outfit each time. But the even funnier thing was that it really wasn't funny at all. We were just desperate for a good time, we found chocolate blobs on windows and khaki pants to be hilarious. Our laughter died down and we sat there in silence. Suddenly, Nathan leaned back in his squeaky swivel chair and it immediately broke, dropping him right to the ground. To anyone else, it would have been funny. However, we each sat in silence, staring at one another. It wasn't that we were embarrassed for him or felt sympathy, but simply ironic that obsolete things sent us into fits of giggles, while a substantial, laughable event made us simply sit there. I don't think I'll ever forget the group. Though it was a waste of time, we had many good laughs. We may not have learned a lot about math, but we learned a lot about each other.

Many people believe that laughter always brings benefits, but the reality is that laughter can sometimes have a different impact. When I think of laughter, I think of smiles, happiness, and positive memories. However, there was one memory of laughter that did not bring joy. I was tasked with confronting my father about his alcohol addiction, and it was a difficult and emotional experience. As I poured out my heart to him, hoping for a serious conversation, he simply laughed it off and dismissed my concerns. This moment of laughter brought tears instead of happiness. It was a stark reminder that not all laughter is lighthearted and joyful. Despite this painful experience, I learned the importance of speaking up and standing up for what I believe in, even in the face of laughter and dismissal. Laughter may not always bring happiness, but it can serve as a catalyst for growth and self-discovery.

Laughter filled the room as my parents sat me down to break the news. I could sense the gravity of the situation as they exchanged glances before finally revealing that they were getting a divorce. The atmosphere shifted, and I could see the pain in my mother's eyes and the turmoil in my father's posture. It was a moment that shattered my young understanding of family dynamics.  As I tried to come to terms with the impending changes, I couldn't help but feel a wave of sadness wash over me. The thought of my family breaking apart was almost too much to bear. How would my little brother, at just four years old, comprehend this upheaval? The confusion and heartache were overwhelming.  But amidst the tears and the impending sense of loss, my mother offered a simple yet profound piece of advice - to remember the good times and to find solace in laughter. It was a light in the darkness, a reminder that even in the face of hardship, there were moments of joy and connection that could sustain us.  As I reflected on the memories of laughter and love that we had shared as a family, I felt a glimmer of hope. Despite the challenges ahead, I realized that as long as we could hold onto those moments of joy, we would find a way to weather the storm. My mother's wisdom became a beacon of light in the darkness, guiding us towards healing and resilience.  In the end, I understood that laughter was not just a fleeting moment of joy, but a powerful force that could help us navigate even the darkest of times. And with that realization, I knew that we would be okay, that we would find our way through the pain and emerge stronger on the other side.

Laughter, the sense of pure happiness. You are in the moment and nothing else matters, all your worries and stress fall away leaving you with your true happy self. Have you ever had those moments when everything seem too much? Then a friend says something that makes you laugh, once you're done laughing you start to cry because it felt so good to laugh. Or when you laugh so hard you fall to the floor and can't get up for what seems like hours? Yet looking back you forget what was so funny. Laughter is magical, behind love. Those two seem to go hand in hand. When you love someone, not just your boyfriend/girlfriend but your friends and family too, you know how to make them laugh or cheer them up, how to have fun with them, and that brings you even closer together. When I'm with my friends, the one thing we seem to do most is laugh. We laugh about anything and everything that is even slightly funny. It brings us closer together, sharing a moment of joy. The six of us are very close and will be friends after high school is over, even if we go to colleges thousands of miles away. It is because we have shared so many happy memories. Laughter is important in a relationship. We trust each other and can share anything with them even our most important secrets. This story is how we came to be so close. Brightly colored fancy dresses and killer high heels were splayed out across the room. Open soda cans and chip bags. The faint smell of nail polish, flowery perfume, and deodorant lingering in the air. Laughter and giggles bubbling throughout the room with the occasional squeal. Pitch black outside but light and warm inside. Six of us lounging around the room. Smeared makeup and deflating hair. Sweatpants and baggy t-shirts. We all went from looking our very best to... not, within a few minutes. Yet not one of us cared. We when looking at each other we were able to look past appearances had fun with each other, not their looks. We had just gotten back from the dance. None of us had dates but we still managed to have the time of our lives. "Did you see him! He was dancing with her!" "I wouldn't really call that dancing...." she made a pelvic thrust, we all burst into a new round of giggles and shouted stuff like, "Hey, get a room!" We gossiped about what we saw, who was with who, pretty dresses, hot guys, creeper guys, slow dances, the music, even our drinks - we hid our cups so we would know which one was ours when we wanted to use it again. We had all been friends, but recently we had been becoming closer. Starting to move from friends to best friends. It was at least midnight. Everyone was exhausted but was forcing themselves to stay up with caffeine and sugar. You may ask why, but I'm not really sure. Maybe because we always seem to have so much to talk about, because we enjoy each other's company, or just because we can, so why not? "I think we need a picture, a picture of the six of us." I said. "Yes!" "Okay!" "Are we doing it now? I'm a mess!" "I've got just the thing!" someone takes off running upstairs to grab something. "Where should we sit?" "On the bed?" "Okay, but scoot over fatties" "Hey! I'm not fat, I'm festively plump!" We all cracked up to the reference of Elf as we started to squeeze into a corner of the squishy full-size bed. Someone's mom arrived back into the room. She was carrying an old Polaroid camera that printed out the picture immediately after you took it. She gave the camera to her mom and jumped onto the bed. We all squished together, barely enough room to breathe. "One...Two...Three!" Click! The picture came out. "Let's take one more while the first is developing. Again, one... two... three!" Click! Click! "Cheese!!!" We all screamed in unison. The bed broke! We had broken the bed! We all sat there clinging to each other in total shock. "Your bed! You guys are faaaaat..." someone said while trying to contain a giggle. Suddenly we were in hysterics. Even someone's mom was laughing. We were one big throbbing pile of laughter. Only the corner of the bed had broken so we were all pulled down into that corner. Then someone started tickling, it was war. Every girl for themselves. It was a mass of bedsheets, wiggling fingers, bare feet, biting and a whole lot of laughing. "All the pictures have developed." The first one showed us sitting

Laughter is indeed an important part of anyone's day. Humans like to laugh and make others laugh as well. I remember a time when I had to take a writing test, much like the one I am taking now. The topics were so vague that choosing one was a challenge. After some contemplation, I found humor in the irony of having to write about laughter when none of the topics interested me. I decided to write about myself laughing at the situation, which I found amusing. As I wrote, I couldn't help but laugh at how ridiculous the task seemed. I worried that the grader might not appreciate my humor, but that only added to the irony and amusement of the situation. Different people find different things funny, but the beauty of laughter lies in its abstract nature. Despite our individual interpretations, laughter is a universal joy that brings people together. So, no matter how you perceive it, laughter is undeniably funny.

Someone once told me that laughter is the key element of comfort. I believe that laughter is one of the most important parts of any relationship. It's what brings people together. A perfect example; about two years ago in the middle of fall, I was crying about my dog passing away. My ex-boyfriend tried everything to make me feel better but nothing was working. I was so hurt I told him I just wanted to be alone and he understood. As he was walking away he slipped and landed in a puddle. The way he fell reminded me of the cartoon Spongebob, when Spongebob slipped on a banana and fell hard. I looked at him and his entire back-side was drenched. His cheeks were cherry-red with embarrassment. I just busted out laughing, I couldn't help it. He saw that water had gotten all over me, then he started laughing. That was a moment of comfort brought on by laughter. Whenever we had a problem, we could always laugh it off. That's actually how I met him. I was hanging out with a couple of my friends and we decided to go see a movie called Step-Up. There was this one scene where one of the characters said, "That was so funny, last time I heard that I laughed so hard I fell off my dinosaur," then the other character looked like he was going to cry. I thought that was so funny. After the movie was over my friend suggested that we go back to his house. When we got there, he was waiting on the steps for my friend. My friend stood back a second then said, "aw were you waiting for me little one." He replied with, "That was so funny, last time I heard that I laughed so hard I fell off my dinosaur." I laughed so hard I almost went to the bathroom on myself. He and myself were the only ones laughing and we just clicked. If he wasn't funny I can honestly say I would've never been with him. I love laughter. I believe it's the easiest way to trigger the best emotions. Laughter truly is the best medicine.

One time when I was spending the night at my friend's house, she wanted to sleep outside in a tent. She was on the phone with her boyfriend and I was on the phone with mine, and both of them were best friends. It was like two best friends dating two best friends, and we were closer than ever. My boyfriend had to get off the phone because he had work in the morning, so my friend was just chatting away on the phone. I started saying really funny things and she just started laughing so hard that she snorted, and at that moment, she was still on the phone with her boyfriend. I couldn't help but burst into laughter at the sight of her laughing so uncontrollably. To make things even funnier, she ended up laughing so hard that she peed herself while still on the phone with her boyfriend. It was a hilarious sight, and I couldn't contain my laughter. When I saw what had happened, I couldn't help but exclaim, "Oh my God, you peed yourself!" This only made us laugh even harder. Eventually, her boyfriend had to intervene and suggest that she take care of the situation. After they got off the phone, she was understandably embarrassed. I couldn't blame her; it was definitely a memorable and comical night.

@ORGANIZATION1 is one of the many joys I love to share with people. I absolutely love to laugh, I don't know where I would be if I didn't laugh. She was holding her food in her other hand, she felt the bottom of my plate and said it was really hot so she passed it off to @PERSON1 who wasn't paying attention and he didn't have a good hold on it and my pizza dropped on the floor, pizza side down. It was so embarrassing everybody was looking at us. After that embarrassing moment, @PERSON1 realized that he forgot the churros, so he told @CAPS1 to go get them. All three of us realized his mistake as soon as @CAPS1 left, cause @CAPS1 is a klutz and we probably jinxed it by saying @CAPS1 is probably going to drop them. We were a little surprised that she hadn't dropped them yet, as soon as we thought that and she set them on the table, one of the churros fell off the table and rolled out of the package. We were laughing so hard that we couldn't breathe. @CAPS1 was so embarrassed by her mistake that she turned bright red. We felt bad for poor @CAPS1, but we couldn't help but laugh because of how funny it was. She knew it was funny but she didn't want to laugh at herself. One of the things I usually say is if you can't and aren't willing to laugh at yourself then you aren't having fun. That's why I believe it is so important to laugh cause you gotta learn how to have fun when it is in a situation that you need to laugh at yourself but yet aren't wanting to. That's one of the biggest ways to have fun is by laughing, because you know you made a small silly mistake that you think everyone in the world saw, all you need is to laugh it off. But you won't cause you feel too embarrassed or too ashamed to admit that you made a little mistake. Sometimes it's your job to go over to them, pat them on the back and tell them that everybody makes mistakes, you gotta learn how to be silly in a tough situation, and that nobody is perfect. Tell them to laugh it off, it helps and you will feel better once you realize that when life knocks you down just get back up cause that's what life is all about. That's the only way you can learn from your mistakes and from life as well. Laughter is really important; the more you laugh, the better you feel and the better you feel, the more fun you will have. Laughter fixes everything; it is a bandage for the little things that happen in life. Laughing with others, especially in moments of embarrassment, can help build stronger bonds and create lasting memories that we can look back on with a smile. So, let's keep laughing, embracing our imperfections, and finding joy in the little mishaps that make life colorful and fun.

I once heard "laughter is the best medicine." I believe that is true. I could laugh all day long, finding anything and everything funny in the world. Laughter is important to me, without it, life would be boring. Sometimes laughter is good and comes from the heart. Other times it can be cruel and mean. I like to avoid the cruel and mean laughter, and just stick to the good laughter. When one of my friends is laughing and smiling, it makes me want to know what they're laughing about, so I can laugh too. Birthdays are fun, laughing usually comes with fun. I remember my twelfth birthday, I decided to have a party at my house. I wanted it to be very special so I invited my closest friends and my cousins. Family always makes everything special. My cousin and I are pretty close, she was born nine months after me, so we are both the same age for a little while. We always have a good time, both of us acting crazy and always laughing. For my party my mom made rainbow sherbert punch, it was delicious. Everyone had fun, and soon the party was over, but my cousins were not leaving until the next day so we continued the party. I was in the kitchen getting more punch, my cousin came in and wanted some more too. I poured both of us a glass. "This is so good!" my cousin said. "I know that's why I had my mom make it" "Do you wanna hear a joke?" "Sure." she said. "Okay, there once was a kid named butt itches, he was really sick and one day died, his mom cried to the doctor,"Oh my poor butt itches!" "And you wanna know what the doctor said?" "What?" she asked. "Scratch it!" she had just taken a drink of punch when I said that. She spit the punch out of her mouth while laughing, it got all over me. Usually when someone spits, or spills something on you, you get mad. I started cracking up laughing, and so did she. "Oh my gosh! That's so gross." "But I could not stop laughing. The joke was not that funny, it was the punch all over me and the kitchen. We laughed for at least fifteen minutes before even realizing that both our moms were standing in the kitchen. They were just staring at us wondering what in the world had happened. You would think that getting punch spitted at your face, on your birthday, would make you mad. That is why laughter makes ordinary days special. In my case, laughter was the shortest distance between my cousin and I. It would have to be short for her to get that much punch on me. Laughter made that birthday extra special, because I will never forget my twelfth birthday.

@CAPS10 @CAPS10 @CAPS10, @CAPS1 @CAPS1 @CAPS1, and now even @CAPS2 (@CAPS3 @CAPS4 @CAPS5). Laughter! Some say it is the best medicine. It can brighten a cloudy day, cure the blues, and soothe a breaking heart. However, a simple snicker or giggle can also break a heart. I remember being in 1st grade and becoming the target of my classmates' jokes due to my weight. Their laughter crushed my self-esteem, leading to tears. One particularly hurtful moment was on the bus when girls I considered friends laughed at me, calling me a "beached whale." Their words stung, and I vowed never to ride the bus again. That experience motivated me to lose weight and regain confidence. Years later, I am 60 pounds lighter, a varsity cheerleader, and proud of my journey. Despite my own growth, I caught myself laughing at an overweight girl with my friend at the mall. Seeing her pain mirrored my past hurt, prompting me to stop. I realized the impact of hurtful laughter and vowed never to mock others' feelings. While I enjoy humor and making others laugh, I draw the line at the expense of someone's emotions. My story serves as a reminder of the harm laughter can cause and the importance of empathy. So laugh, but not at the cost of another's feelings.

Laughter is a big part of my life and I believe it is essential for a healthy relationship. My mother and I share a bond filled with laughter, often finding humor in the silliest of things. One memorable moment was when my mother, aunt, and I tried a homemade facial mask and ended up looking like a group of crazy ladies, struggling to contain our laughter. Despite the mask cracking and our efforts going down the drain, that day remains one of the funniest in my life. I have various forms of laughter, from laughing so hard that I forget to breathe to emitting a snort on occasion. Laughter has brought so much joy and lightness into my life, and I cannot imagine living without it. It truly is the best medicine.

The laughter in me is a powerful force that helps me get through tough days. A good laugh, especially with my best friend, can bring hope and joy even in the most difficult moments. It keeps me motivated, helps me connect with others, and adds a spark of joy to my life. Without laughter, I would struggle to navigate the challenges of each day and find it difficult to make meaningful connections. Thank you, laughter, for being my constant companion and source of strength.

The @CAPS1 @CAPS2 @CAPS3  The beautiful flames danced so peacefully in the @CAPS1 air. The faint shimmer of the blaze was the only light we had. The weight of the sixty pounds of wood started to get heavy as I walked from one side of the house to the other. After about two hours of packing clothes, food, water, sleeping bags, pillows, and tents we headed out for @ORGANIZATION1. It would be about two hours of driving, that felt like twenty minutes. @PERSON3, @PERSON1, @PERSON2, @PERSON4, and I were the worst group of people to put into one car. The first few days were spent basking in the one hundred degree heat, swimming, and flirting with the random girls we found around the camp site. We slept as little as possible, so that we could enjoy the friendship and just pure fun we were having. During day two, we decided to go mountain biking. We were on those bikes for hours before we noticed the sun was going down. In the moment we all turned and saw the most extravagant view the earth has ever created. There were burst of orange and red. The colors ricochet from cloud to cloud. After hours of riding our bikes in the heat, we chose to go for a swim. As we swam I felt something touching my foot. Then all of a sudden there was a hand on my foot. When I looked down to see who was grabbing me, it was only a stick. As I looked closer, it turned out to be a root system of a fallen tree. It looked fake, as if someone or something had put it there. This though sparked a conversation about @CAPS2 for the day to come.  The sparks danced together as if they were @CAPS4 and the @LOCATION1. The only light we had was the brilliant glow of the fire. @PERSON3 was playing a gorgeous melody on his guitar. As I listened and enjoyed the flawlessness of nature, I felt someone watching me from behind. I nudged @PERSON3 and when we turned around, our hearts stopped. There was a spinning green light, almost twenty feet in the air. I spoke the word everyone was dreading, @CAPS2. I had slowly stood up and the light started spinning faster. I quickly grabbed the machete, that was next to me, and approached the light. As I grew closer, I could make out small figured in the @CAPS1 shadows. Then, an eruption of children laughing came booming from the direction of the light. A little boy emerged, unable to control is laughter, and ran away. After returning to my seat next to the camp fire, I thought about life. What if @CAPS2 were real and they are watching us. No, there not real. I laughed it off, and continued my week long vacation.  The days at the campsite were filled with adventure, laughter, and moments of pure joy. The mysteries of the night, like the spinning green light, only added to the magic of our time in nature. As I reflected on the possibility of supernatural beings watching over us, I couldn't help but feel grateful for the unforgettable experiences and the bonds formed with my friends. The flames continued to dance peacefully, illuminating the beauty of the moment, and I knew that these memories would stay with me forever.

Laughter has been a nonchalant but steady and strong force for me in many relationships. Laughter is truly one of the best parts of life. It spreads happiness and joy, making everything better. It is contagious and can brighten someone's day in an instant. Laughter is the essence of life. Without laughter, my life would be meaningless, and without that sense of happiness or compassion, life wouldn't be worth living. My sister is the only person I trust with my secrets. She is the only one who makes me happy when I feel down. My sister and I laugh with each other at our own jokes. My sister is my other half, and we share everything. She makes me laugh and is always there when I need her. I'll always be there for her also. Laughter is an important part of life. My sister and I laugh and play together. One day, I came off the bus from school, all I could do was cry. As I waited for my sister's bus to arrive, the tears fell down like a river flowing. The bus appeared, and a sense of joy appeared with it. But it wasn't the bus that brought my joy, it was my sister. Right away, she could feel my pain and noticed my tears. I could see in her face the love and care. She asked me what's wrong, and I could hear the worry in her voice. My river of tears stopped, and I began to speak. Afterwards, she told me something I'll never forget. She said, "No matter what happens, I'll always love you." And we laughed. It was the sweetest laugh, a chorus of laughter filling the air. Nothing that people say about me is true, so I learned to laugh at it. My sister is my rock, my confidante, and my source of joy. With her by my side, I know that no matter what life throws at us, we will always have each other to lean on and laugh with.

It's always hard to know what to do when a friend or family member comes to you when they are sad or mad. Most of the time you don't know what to do. I have learned that making people laugh with something as simple as a joke can always make them feel better. As I was sitting at home one sunny afternoon, I got a call from my friend @PERSON1. When I put the phone to my ear all I could hear was a loud crying. @PERSON1 wasn't saying anything to me, not one word. Even though, I repeatedly asked her what was wrong with her, @PERSON1 wouldn't even say a word. Not knowing what to do or say to her anymore, I asked her to calm down and take deep breaths. Desperately, I wanted her to be able to talk to me and tell me what was going on because I had started to get really worried.  A couple of minutes later, @PERSON1 started explaining to me what had happened. @PERSON1 started off by telling me she was irresponsible that she didn't pay attention to what was happening around her. I asked her why she was saying that about herself because I knew she was a responsible person. Finally, @PERSON1 screamed that while she was home watching the @CAPS1 basketball team play basketball, her dog @CAPS2 got run over. The dog had actually died. I found it very ridiculous and pathetic that @PERSON1 would be crying over her dog. I didn't want to be rude about it and tell her what was going through my mind at that time.  Even though that was the way I felt about the whole situation. I thought of the words I needed to say to @PERSON1 but I was confused. Actually, it wasn't so much that I was confused, I was afraid of hurting her feelings with my words. Finally, I decided to tell her not to worry about her dog, that my friend had a couple of dogs for sale. Also, I told @PERSON1 that if it made her feel any better I would buy her a new puppy. After saying that to her there was an awkward silence. My hands started to get shaky because I thought @PERSON1 was mad.  All of a sudden, I just heard her start laughing really loud and once again she couldn't talk. I felt so relieved that I had made her laugh and not cry or get mad at me. @PERSON1 wouldn't shut her mouth, she just laughed and laughed and laughed hysterically. Finally, she shut her mouth up and started talking to me again. @PERSON1 thanked me for making her laugh and making a joke out of the situation, rather than saying depressing words that would make her feel bad and make her cry even more.  I was happy I made her laugh because she felt better about herself and not worse. As I was laughing, I told her that anytime she needed to laugh I was the person she needed to call. Anytime, any day, and anywhere I would be happy to bring a smile to her face and a loud laugh to her mouth. @PERSON1 laughed with me and thanked me one more time for making her laugh. From that day on, I always like to make people laugh because I know I'm going to make them feel better. I sure love it when others make me laugh too. It's just an amazing feeling, a great feeling that everyone loves and can't really describe. After making my friend @PERSON1 laugh, I found out laughter was a key element of life.

Laughter is an important element to have in life. Because without it, there would be no happiness or joy in the world. Friends are a great source for laughter, they are the people you go to to be yourself. Some people use laughter to release pain. For example, whenever my dad gets hurt he starts laughing. My dad was in the navy a few years ago, and during training he got hit in the stomach. Nothing really was wrong, but it did hurt him. So he sat down and started to laugh. I guess this trait is hereditary because I find myself doing the exact same thing from time to time.  When I learned about how laughter heals, it wasn't too long ago. It was last summer, early August and the end of summer was coming close. Traditionally, my family would drive to a nearby store and buy a huge pack of fireworks. Once the sunset came, it was time. We all knew it was time to light up the sky with colorful sparks. After the end of summer had passed, my cousin came over. My mom had been feeling a little sick, but it wasn't contagious. Despite her health issues, we found ways to keep ourselves entertained and distracted.  As days went by, my mom showed signs of improvement. I was eager to go out and enjoy a movie with her and my cousin. The next day, my mom woke me up feeling much better. We decided to go see a movie and have a good time. Everything seemed to be going well until a few days later, my mom passed away in her sleep. It was a sudden and devastating loss that left me feeling like my heart had exploded like a firework.  In the midst of the grief and pain, my cousin and her family tried to bring some laughter into our lives. They knew that laughter could help alleviate some of the pain we were feeling. Finding moments of joy and laughter in such a dark time was truly remarkable. It reminded me of the importance of laughter in our lives, even during the most difficult moments. Laughter truly has the power to heal and bring light into the darkest of times.

Someone once said, "Laughter is the shortest distance between two people." To me, that means that laughter is the quickest and easiest way to connect with another person. I believe this because my older brother and I used to have a strained relationship. However, as we spent more time together, we found that laughter played a crucial role in bringing us closer. One day, while sitting on the back porch, my brother unexpectedly fell into a bush, leading to a moment of shared laughter that broke the tension between us. Since then, laughter has become an integral part of our family gatherings, where stories are shared and bonds are strengthened. In my experience, laughter brings happiness, which in turn fosters love, making it a vital component of relationships. Therefore, I agree that "laughter is the shortest distance between all people."

This true story might sound somewhat cheesy, but it's true and, in my opinion, it's a love story. On a typical day, after finishing her school tasks, Sarah decided to log on to BookFace to chat with some new friends she had made online. Sarah had forgotten that she had sent a friend request to Mike. Mike had accepted Sarah's request, and that's when Sarah remembered about the request. Mike and Sarah started to know more about each other, minute after minute, before they had no clue who the other one was. Mike gave Sarah his number after a long chat so she could call or text him to keep in contact while being off of BookFace. Mike was starting to like Sarah, and so was she. Sarah now knew that Mike is a high school student, a sophomore to be exact, that he is tall, and also has friends in common with her. Sarah really liked talking to Mike a lot, and so did Mike to her. Sarah noticed that Mike loved to laugh a lot, which always made her day brighter. Mike knew Sarah had recently broken up with her boyfriend, but he didn't mind; he liked her. He had a strong hope that he could have a chance at making Sarah happy. Eventually, Mike asked Sarah if she would be his girlfriend, to which Sarah joyfully accepted. Days passed, and they were doing perfectly until Sarah started receiving texts from her ex-boyfriend, which affected their relationship. Despite still being in love with her ex, Mike didn't give up and fought to win Sarah's heart. One night, while talking on the phone, Mike asked Sarah if she was willing to try to forget her ex. Although scared, Sarah agreed to try. Their communication was excellent, especially when laughter was involved. Sarah even asked Mike to laugh for her, which he happily did. Laughter played a significant role in their relationship, making it much better. It may not be perfect, but it certainly helped them overcome obstacles and unnecessary fights. Laughter seemed to be a universal language that helped them communicate and understand each other better. In conclusion, laughter indeed plays a crucial part in all relationships.

My relationship with laughter has been a crucial aspect of my life ever since I met my boyfriend. Despite facing challenges and misunderstandings, we have managed to overcome them and keep our laughter alive in our relationship. I cherish the moments of joy and laughter that we share, as they remind me of the love and support that we have for each other. As long as we continue to make each other smile and laugh, I believe that our relationship will remain strong and unbreakable. Laughter will always be a fundamental part of our connection, bringing us closer together and helping us navigate through life's ups and downs.

"Laughter" I once heard a man say " laughing is the key to happiness, and if you do not laugh you aren't healthy" @CAPS1 do people love to laugh? Because it laughing creates great memories, it gets rid of sadness, it gives you energy, and it even gives you a good abdominal work depending on how hard you laugh and for how long. There is nothing better than a good funny movie that makes you laugh so hard you cry, your jaw hurts, and your stomach is even sore the next day. Some of my favorite movies are funny.  I bet laughing or making someone else laugh could get you hired at a job. Say you go in for an interview for a job that involves you working with people everyday. Are you going to go in there boring and moditone? No, your going to go in there make the person who is interviewing you laugh and act like you have known him or her since @CAPS2 @CAPS3.  Laughter can also be abused. It can be used in bad ways, such as making fun of people because it @MONTH1 be funny. Calling kids in your gym class names because they cant throw a baseball as far as you. Laughing @MONTH1 make people feel as bright as the stars at night, or it @MONTH1 make people feel as bad as a basketball player missing the buzzer beater to win the championship game. After thinking back on those moments we began to laugh, and not just a small unnoticeable giggle, i mean we were laughing out loud. It then got rid of that aching sadness that had been in the room all night. I will never forget how laughter that very night would become such an emotional memories later in life. Laughter truly has a powerful impact on our emotions and memories.

Laughter is a crucial aspect of my life, bringing joy and brightness to my days. It plays a significant role in my interactions with friends, family, and my boyfriend. One particular instance that stands out is when my boyfriend used humor to alleviate my stomach ache during a journey home. As we traveled, he lightened the mood by sharing amusing anecdotes and eventually made me burst into laughter by revealing his unintentionally voluminous hair after using a shampoo labeled "from flat to volume." This incident turned my focus from discomfort to uncontrollable laughter, showcasing the power of humor in easing distress. The memory of his comically inflated hair continues to bring smiles, highlighting the enduring impact of laughter in my life. Laughter truly remains my go-to remedy for any ailment, ensuring that joy and mirth are never far away.

Have you ever wondered how you and your best friends even became friends? Maybe not, but maybe you have and couldn't remember. Well this story I'm about to tell you today is about how my friend @PERSON3 and I became friends. I'm also going to tell you how we have stayed friends for as long as we have and all the little things that have kept us friends. Admittedly we did not start off as friends who laughed all the time, instead we started off as a crier and a helper. @PERSON3 and I first met in the eighth grade. I had just gotten called out of my first period class and greeted by my math teacher @PERSON1. @PERSON1 told me that we had just gotten a new student that moved here from @LOCATION1 and wasn't exactly happy about it. She also asked me if I wouldn't mind showing her around the school with another classmate, @PERSON4, I agreed and walked into the room @PERSON3 was in. When I saw her the first thing I noticed was her eyes, as the tears went down her face. Then I realized she was a very pretty girl who, like @PERSON1 said wasn't happy. I will admit i was a little scared to try and show her around seeing as she wasn't happy at all to be here. But once we got started she had calmed down immensely, but she still wouldn't even crack a smile at our feeble tempts to make jokes. I still felt like she should be happy and broke out the big guns. So I walked differently and talked in a funny voice, I even started saying random funny things in long pauses. Eventually she smiled, so I kept going. Toward the end I got her and @PERSON4 to laugh so hard we all almost wet ourselves. But as funny as it was for us, it definitely wasn't the last funny thing we did. You know the type of funny things that happen and no matter what, you always remember it when you see that person it happened with, right? Well to say the least @PERSON3 and I have a lot of those moments. Granted a lot of them happen with other people, but that's what makes it fun. Like this one time in our drawing and painting class we, @PERSON3, @LOCATION2, and @CAPS1 and I, were all in @PERSON2's little office getting a picture to draw. I had been hyper pretty much all day and so had @CAPS3 else. I randomly look around the room and see a really cute looking poster I hadn't noticed ever before and without realizing it I had said aloud, "@CAPS2, that's really cute." @CAPS3 started laughing and holding on to the desk to keep from falling to the ground. I still hadn't realized I said it aloud and was really confused but still laughing because watching them laugh was really entertaining. They finally calmed down long enough to say what I'd just said and I blushed but started laughing along. Now every time they see me and remember that moment they crack up laughing and they point to something and say it the way I said it. That's why I think that having the big memories of the really funny thing has kept us together. It helps us remember the fun times during the bad times. It also helps to keep our link strong throughout the group of our friends. But the little things matter too. Every little thing we do together as friends helps us later. If we didn't do all the little funny things and only did either big funny things, or boring things, I don't think our friendship would last long. Like when we're talking and we accidentally burp or we fart while we walk. Or maybe when I laugh and I hide my face with my hands and my arms jiggle. Possibly even when we say something weird or walk funny because we really have to go to the bathroom. It's not just being friends that keeps us together it's how we are and who we become with that other person, I feel like I become a better person and I believe I help her become one too. Besides the little things are just as funny as the big things we do. So as I've stated before laughter is a big part of a friendship. @PERSON3 and my friendship hadn't started in of laughter, it started in tears and grew to be laughter. Laughter had brought us together in an act of weirdness and it has stayed very strong ever since, not only because we had a lot in common, to be frank we don't really even have that much in common, it is because of the big hilarious moments we've shared not only together, but with other people and the little things we do on a daily basis that we find really funny. I do have to say laughter is probably the best thing to keep any relationship good and healthy.

We all kinda smiled and at each other and went to dinner, cracking jokes and laughing then laughing at my laugh. Thank goodness for laughing, once we started laughing I felt comfortable and welcomed. Laughing is a crucial aspect of life that can bring joy, create lasting memories, and strengthen relationships. From childhood beliefs about laughter prolonging life to the fun shared moments with friends and family, the power of laughter is evident in everyday experiences. Whether it's sharing jokes with siblings, enjoying the company of close friends, or simply finding humor in everyday situations, laughter has a way of lifting spirits and brightening moments.   Memories of shared laughter, such as stealing a truck for a joyride or pretending to be in a spaceship under a table, hold a special place in the heart. These moments not only bring a smile to the face but also serve as a reminder of the joy and connection shared with others. Even in difficult times, a good laugh can provide a sense of relief and perspective, making challenges seem more manageable.  The ability to laugh and find humor in life's ups and downs is a valuable trait that can lead to a more positive outlook and stronger relationships. Whether it's reminiscing about past adventures or creating new memories filled with laughter, embracing the joy that laughter brings can truly enrich life in countless ways. So, next time you find yourself in a tough spot, remember to laugh, for it may just be the remedy needed to navigate through life's obstacles with a lighter heart and a brighter spirit.

Laughter is a crucial part of my life, serving as a source of strength and comfort in challenging times. Whether faced with difficult situations like my brother's return to jail, a painful breakup, or my own health struggles, laughter has the power to uplift and heal. Even when dealing with heartache or illness, I choose to find humor and joy in life, knowing that laughter is the best medicine. Through the laughter shared with loved ones, I am able to navigate through adversity and find solace in the simple pleasures of life. Embracing laughter as a vital ingredient in my daily existence, I am reminded to cherish the small moments of happiness that bring us closer together and make life worth living. So, in times of darkness, I choose to laugh and find light amidst the shadows, knowing that laughter is the key to living a fulfilling and joyful life.

Laughter. We all need it. We need it as a reminder that there is hope for those who have perseverance, for those who strive not to better others, but for those who strive to better themselves. We need it as a reminder to live our dreams, instead of dreaming of living. And, in my opinion, most importantly, we need it as a reminder that even though we make mistakes, there is still a chance for those who simply have the courage to seize it. In the past, my foster parents decided to go out for dinner, leaving me with a friend to spend the evening together. We decided to set up the Christmas tree first, and after admiring our work, we went down to the den. It was during this time that I made the decision to break up with my girlfriend, feeling a mix of happiness and loneliness. My friend, sensing my emotional state, gave me a hug, which unexpectedly made me burst into laughter. This simple act of kindness and understanding brought me comfort and reassurance. It was in that moment that I realized the true value of friendship and the power of laughter in healing the soul. And for that, I will always be grateful.

As people have bonded over the years, those bonds have been strengthened by laughter, joy, and trust. All of these are important, but they all work together to build these bonds. For normal people to enjoy one another, they must have fun, and fun begins with laughter. Laughter comes from the brain, and if two people find the same thing funny, it brings them together with their similar interests. By telling a funny joke or being a person who always has a smile on their face, people are drawn to them more easily. Being a seemingly happy person has given me the friends I have. When I am with my friends, we are always laughing or joking about something. We could be laughing at ourselves, at a random person on the street, or even at something stupid. Most of the time, we won't get upset about it, but sometimes we may take it too far. Stupidity and pain are probably the top two reasons why we laugh. Stupidity occurs when someone says something that doesn't make sense or comes in at the wrong time. While I have never understood why we laugh at pain, it may be because we are relieved it is not happening to us or because we know the person will recover. Laughter will always bring people together in relationships, showing common interests and what people can tolerate from others. Without happiness and laughter, the world would be incredibly dull.

Laughter is a mystery. Happens whenever it pleases. It puts smiles on faces. Laughter just happens in many ways it can. Although, mine just happened to end up in a crazy situation with a huge mess to follow it. Things got extreme, unforgettable. Things you could never forget. Around two months ago, in the cold winter. It was my 21st birthday. I threw a little party for myself at my house. Though, I was in for a little treat. As everyone arrived they all had a smirk on their faces. Nobody would tell me what was going on. I started to become distraught about it all. Until my buddy and my boyfriend walked into the kitchen with a 5 pound bucket full of spaghetti, with a ten pound gallon can of tomato sauce. Next thing I knew my mouth was agape. I couldn't believe my eyes, not understanding why so much of it. Also, why did they have it. My mother walked out and exclaimed "Load up the cars, and let's go!" As we approached the park, I had a funny feeling in the pit of my gut. I looked around and noticed my sister-in-law was holding a video camera. Right then and there I knew something was going to happen. Something big, extraordinary, out of the extreme and I was right. Spaghetti was flying everywhere, getting in people's hair, faces. Clothes were getting stained and messy. Not to mention it was cold, wet, and rainy outside. The fog made it hard to see who you were hitting and who was throwing it at you. By the end of the noodle war, I looked the worst. Even now the shoes I was wearing are stained. As we got back to my house we had to wash down with the hose. I swore I was going to get sick from the cold water running down my face. I could feel noodles falling out of my hair and clothing, the sauce streaming down my face. Laughing here and laughing there. Everyone was laughing at others for how badly they were covered with noodles and sauce. Eventually, we all got hungry. We decided on nachos. So, my mom poured two family size nacho chips on the table followed by two ten-gallon cans of nacho cheese with jalapenos, olives. You might think the noodle and sauce was messy, well that's where I went wrong. My friend dropped nachos on my couch. She threw cheese at the tree. So, my friend finally said "No more nachos!" And on it was cake time. Ginger thought that there wasn't going to be another mess. Well once again she was wrong. They all started singing the happy birthday song, cameras were flashing, my mother in the background crying. Soon after that we played video games. I got irritated with someone on the game and ended up throwing the controller at my television and broke it. Mother wasn't too pleased with me after that. Oh well, we still got to watch movies in the other room. Eventually people started leaving. Saying our goodbyes, I'll see you later, peace out dude. We said it all. I looked back in the living room and saw nothing but a huge mess of chips, nacho cheese, and cake. Not to mention my broken TV. I got stuck cleaning the mess for over three hours. Though, we were laughing the entire time it happened. Having the greatest time ever with each other. If I could I would go back and do it all over again just for the fun and laughs. Laughter is everywhere. You may not see it right away. Though you will once you start laughing your brains out. Laughing puts everyone in good moods and smiles on their faces. It may also make a mess and put things in a crazy situation. You can't deny after those crazy situations that you would go back and do it again. Laughter is the greatest thing in this world we call home.

Laughter plays a significant role in our lives, influencing our relationships and how we interact with others. While some may see laughter as a means of creating distance between individuals, I believe it is a vital component of any relationship. Through laughter, we reveal our true selves and showcase our sense of humor. It allows others to understand us better and see the fun side of our personalities. In relationships, laughter can strengthen bonds and create a sense of camaraderie. It is a tool for building connections and breaking down barriers, rather than causing distance between people. Ultimately, laughter is a powerful force that brings joy, happiness, and unity to our lives.

There are times when I get along with others and times when I don't. I also have moments where I can make people laugh until they cry. One particular incident that comes to mind is when my friends and I were walking to the store and I started pointing out random things along the way. When I pointed out the @CAPS1 store, one of my friends burst into laughter so hard that he ended up peeing his pants. We had to go back to his house so he could change into clean clothes, which took him a good @NUM1 to @NUM2 minutes to do so. When I asked him what took him so long, he simply replied, "I'm taking a pee." This statement made me laugh even harder, and it dawned on me why he found the @CAPS1 store so amusing. It turned out that the last time we were there, a man was bragging about his son's football team, which my friend and I were supposedly part of, being in the top ten, even though we weren't. The man was so embarrassed by what my friend said that he got up, hugged us, and then jokingly asked why he didn't get a hug. This whole situation was so hilarious that I couldn't stop laughing, thankful that I didn't have to rush to the restroom.

Laughter fills the air around us with happiness and joy, bringing warm memories of loved ones and adding a splash of hope to those in need. It is the key to solving life's problems and can come from various sources such as jokes, shows, or joyful reunions. Laughter not only creates bonds between people but also helps form lasting friendships. Surprises and shocks can also trigger laughter, turning unexpected moments into humorous memories. The connection shared through laughter is special, allowing people to understand each other without words. From family gatherings to childhood memories, laughter plays a significant role in our lives, reminding us of the joy found in simple moments.

Laughter plays a crucial role in my everyday life, allowing me to express a range of emotions such as happiness, sadness, and even pain. Whether I am feeling joyful, hurt, or trying to mask my true feelings, laughter serves as a powerful tool in conveying my innermost emotions. It brings me solace during times of sadness, helps me cope with anger, and creates moments of pure joy when I am surrounded by loved ones. Laughter is not just a simple expression of amusement; it is a vital component that brightens my days and enriches my relationships. In essence, laughter is an essential part of my existence, bringing light and positivity into my world.

Laughter is indeed a powerful force that can transform even the most mundane of experiences into memorable ones. Initially disappointed by Mr. @CAPS3's seemingly ordinary demeanor, the students were pleasantly surprised when he revealed his true colors on the second day of class. The classroom was transformed into a vibrant and lively space, filled with laughter and fun activities that brought the students together. The impact of Mr. @CAPS3's teaching style and personality is evident in the lasting memories and lessons that the narrator carries with them to this day. Laughing is an essential aspect of my relationships with others, serving as a way to connect, bond, and uplift spirits. It acts as a universal language that transcends barriers and brings people together in moments of joy and levity. Whether it's sharing inside jokes with close friends like @LOCATION1 and @CAPS4 or simply enjoying a good laugh in the company of others, the power of laughter cannot be understated. Through laughter, friendships are strengthened, memories are created, and life's challenges become a bit more bearable. As I navigate the ups and downs of life, I am grateful for the presence of friends who can make me laugh, reminding me that even in the darkest of times, there is always a reason to smile.

Laughter is like cooking; it brings people of every kind together, but the wrong food or the wrong time can bring discomfort to you and others around you, such as beans. Laughter is a medicine. Laughter is a universal language; you can speak "language" with a foreign friend, even when you know not an ounce of their native tongue. Laughter differs, ranging in loudness, pattern, softness, and attitude. You laughed weeks into the world and you'll be laughing your way out of it as well. Sometimes in life, it is important to laugh! Laughter is forgiving and a nod to acceptance. It was my freshman year and I had arrived early that morning to keep my friend company who's mom had dropped her off at such an early time, due to transportation conflicts. I wasn't sure why we were even fighting or why we were on particular subject; I only knew we had gone off on a "bunny trail" and was picking me apart for something I had done weeks ago. Our voices were escalating and despite the fact our disagreement wasn't taking a turn toward the physical, our words were just as devastating, taking jabs below the belt and giving "black eyes" of sorts to both teams. was right and I knew it, but did really have to carry such an air of self-righteousness? I thought, " hadn't done what did, I wouldn't have any secrets to spill." was also wrong of me, but my attention wasn't focusing on that, but rather on deflecting her fiery words, sure to not let my guard down and start crying or something ridiculous like that. "That only happened one time!" declared as tried to defended herself. " way, you didn't have to tell the whole world!" "I didn't tell the world," I objected. "I only told one person...who told one person, who told another person...and so on." raised her eyebrow in a manner as to say, "? You know what I'm talking about." The air in the room was as stiff as our direction we were taking in our argument, going nowhere and getting to no point. The feeling was mutual; was done with me, I was done with her. leaned back casually against the wall, attempting to appear apathetic, when her ankle succumbed to gravity and the present moisture, grazing the surface and causing her to lose her footing. All the cool once had was thrown out the window. Her shoe caught the slick surface of the tile, wet from where hundreds of trodden footsteps were left from that morning's downpour. Crashing down, met the unforgiving, stone floor with a which left her face dazed and pride altered. I wish that was how the conversation had gone--with her standing not three feet tall and me towering above her. Concealing the slight satisfaction that was lurking behind my dimples, I slowly slid down the wall that stood behind me, coming to eye level with her. I took one look into her eyes, as they were waving a white flag and then the smug victory left me. I craned my neck backward, smiled at the ceiling and let out a giggle. I'm not sure what thought about that at first yet slowly but surely, managed a chuckle. My giggle triggered into a full-out laughter seizure, her catching on and soon leaving us both laying on the floor. There was nothing particularly special about that bleak, speckled tile, but it was that desolate stone we ended up sprawled on, heads huddled on and hands on our bellies, trying to steady our breaths back into normalcy that one early morning. Sure, I apologized and accepted, but I think her forgiveness went without saying; laughter is not dependent on words. "," managed with a smile. The laughter my friend and I had shared in that pre-school classroom carried throughout the day. "Laughter is the shortest distance between two people." That very distance brought assurance into the relationship I shared with my friend. No, it didn't solve our problems, but it reminded us of how silly and meaningless our petty arguments amounted to be, definitely something worth laughing at. Sure, her fall from grace triggered the expression of innocent surrender from my part, laughter, but it was the letting go of bitterness and the welcoming of a laugh from both sides that ended it all. So, no, while we were not on the same brave wave, our laughter was above picking sides--we were still speaking the same "language."

In this essay, I will be discussing the importance of laughter, conflict, and trust in a relationship based on my strong bond with my cousin, who I have known for many years. We often find humor in each other's mistakes, using laughter as a way to bond and support one another through difficult times. Through the ups and downs, we have learned that these elements are essential for a healthy and fulfilling relationship, and I am grateful to have such a strong and meaningful connection with my cousin.

On a +Â¨tude cette class-l+. Tu peux aller au bibliotheque si tu veux...." @CAPS3 all blinked at me, @PERSON1, @NUM1le, and @ORGANIZATION1, chocolate-haired and mocha-skinned, impatiently awaiting my answer. I glazed my eyes over, attempting to look lost in thought, as if I didn't care I wasn't included. Sniffling, she and @NUM1le went to the bathroom, leaving me all alone with @PERSON1. Only @PERSON2 could have felt my same emotion as he stared up at @CAPS6. Silently, I continued shooting peas. @PERSON1 just stared at them as @CAPS3 darted around the room. Suddenly, with a horrible miscalculation, a pea hit a boy in the face. And then, he turned around and swore. And then, @PERSON1 and I looked at each other from across the table. And then, we laughed. We laughed so hard I cried. So hard that huge, alien tears flooded from my eyes. People around us were laughing too, even though @CAPS3 had no idea what was so funny. I didn't even know what was so funny. But it didn't matter, because we were dripping tears and snot, reaching for each other, reenacting the pea hitting the boy's face. It was as if we had been friends for years, and laughing happened all the time. It was saturated with all the angst and lonliness and despair I had felt the past four weeks. The connection we felt was instantaneous, like lightening, the kind of connection I felt with my best friends back home. My soul was open. It was the best laugh of my life. Sniffle sniffle. GASP. Laughter. GASP. Swipe of tears. Sniffle sniffle. Laughter. GASP. This is why. I thought. This is why you came. Bell rings.

I didn't believe my grandfather when he told me laughing could cure anything. I was nine years old, the days were dark and cold, and I felt like my life was a shattered piece of a stained glass window. Not only had my ageless pit bull just died, but also my little sister would tease me if I dared to shed a tear for the loss of my best pet. I sat on the couch, staring at the fire as it crackled and popped, when my grandfather sat down beside me and told me a story. It was about him when he was young and how he lost his best friend too, only his friend wasn't a pet.  "His name was Jack," he began, "and we were eleven years old. Oh, how we had so much fun. All we did was play! We thought we were gonna grow old together and be each other's best men and cause trouble until the end. Jack was my best friend until the end. I loved him, very much like how you love your dog. I never thought anything would happen to him. I thought that we'd both live forever. But then something did happen. Jack had gone fishing alone because I was at church and his dad had to work, and it was such a wonderful day to go down to the river and then he never came back from the river..."  As he sniffled at the old story, he said, "You see, there's a cure for sadness. Do you want to know what it is?" I nodded, half-thinking there was a magical medication or spell. "It's laughter," he said. "Laughter?!" I was utterly shocked. "Yes, it's simply," he said gently, knowing my easy temper, "through the stages of grieving. Feel lost for a little bit, and then find your way back home. Love is in your heart and always will be. Find a wave of joy and go with the flow. Love life, because, as you have just seen, it can be so short."  I nodded and didn't look at his sober face. He kissed the top of my head, looked into my eyes, and then left me alone to think. I needed to move on? How? Life wasn't that easy. I knew that. I opened up my notebook to do some homework to get my mind off my dog and Jack. That's when I discovered a small piece of paper the size of a deck of cards. I flipped it over, showing that it was a picture. A tear leaked out of the corner of my eye. It was of me and my dog. We were both in a mud pit, my blond hair looking like dirt. My pit bull was rubbing his greasy head on my shoulder, smearing more mud onto myself. I smiled, missing him even more, and feeling a lot better than a minute before. I loved him. I loved him so much. I still do to this day, and I had to get over the fact that my friend was gone. After I saw the picture, I laughed to myself, automatically feeling better about being such a horrid granddaughter and an inconsiderate best friend. Seeing the good times we had and smiling made me honestly feel better about myself. Maybe laughter is the cure for anything.

The bus flew around tightly wound corners. Beyond the windows, farmland, rocky bluffs, and peaceful rivers streamed past. Exhausted from the fourteen-hour flight, I barely knew what time it was. The only things keeping me awake were the jolting of the bus and one other person I barely knew gossiping quietly. We were going to visit and live with a group high school students, affectionately referred to as "our family." I had met my partner, Lisa, only once. Everything I knew about her, her life, her family I learned from maybe ten, maybe twelve short messages. Communication was going to be problematic. My mother started teaching me German when I turned two, but I was nowhere near fluent; I was self-conscious and uncomfortable around native speakers. Lisa's English was decent, but her family spoke only German. Finally, the bus drove down the narrow cobbled streets of the quaint town. It pulled up to a plaza packed with people. The doors hissed open, and we filed out into the crowd, standing on tiptoes to search for our new families. All around me, people chattered in a mix of German and English. Lisa and her parents waited somewhere in the middle, and I slowly wove my way towards them. Brigitte, my host mother, grabbed me in a hug. "Wie geht's? Wie war dein Flug? How are you? How was your flight?" Trying to recall my German, I faltered, "Der Flug war sehr lang, also ich bin ein bisschen mude. The flight was very long, so I'm a little tired." Lisa took my arm and led me uphill towards the school, where our welcome dinner was being held. She explained, "Everyone is very excited to meet you. Our town is so small; we never get tourists. We only get exchange students every other year." My stomach was filled with that jittery-sick feeling of nervous anticipation. Normally, making friends was easy for me, but this time was different. I only minimally understood the language and culture of the people surrounding me. The long flight was evident in the sleepless bags under my eyes and my greasy, knotted hair. My jet-lagged brain wondered how I would get along with these people. Would I fit in, be able to slip into German life without many hitches or snags? We passed from the antiquated street to a dusky tunnel-like entryway. After a few turns, we emerged into an open courtyard. An array of food covered several tables, and the scent of grilling bratwurst wafted through the air. "Are you hungry? You should have something to eat. We have so much food here," Lisa told me. I grabbed a plate and placed a roll, strawberries, and a sausage on it; I was too anxious to really be hungry. Lisa steered me towards a worn table with wooden benches, where her friends were already enjoying dinner and a few beers. She introduced me, and I perched stiffly on the edge of the seat. Her friends talked excitedly, questioning me about my life. As they loosened up, they began to joke, sometimes in German, sometimes in English. Some of them teased me about my accent. It wasn't a mean teasing; they weren't trying to be malicious, just light and funny. So I laughed. In that moment, I seemed to fit better with these people I only sometimes understood. I was less a foreigner and more a new friend. Relaxing, I allowed myself to laugh at my mistakes and really enjoy being someplace entirely new.

Laughter is something that is there when you are happy. Laughter is there when we are having fun and when we are in a good mood, it makes us smile. The guys were supposed to spell "Isabella", but they ended up spelling "Isabell"! One of the other guys saw the mistake right away, so he moved to the left and since my uncle didn't move to the left either, they ended up spelling "Isabel"! I'm not going to lie...I saw my uncle when he was in the wrong spot because the letters were facing my way, but I could have stopped that from happening but I didn't because I couldn't! But at the end it was funny. Everybody there started laughing and I got so embarrassed! But when I was walking off the dance floor I started laughing! Now that we think about it, that is the funniest thing that has ever happened in our family. I guess laughter really is there when something embarrassing happens. Laughter is something that is there when you are happy. Laughter is there when we are having fun and when we are in a good mood, it makes us smile. We end up remembering the fun we had together, that we start laughing really hard! Laughter is there when we are happy, but it is also there when it is the best day of your life. One day me and my friend Taylor got the idea on a snow day to get his quad and tie a rope to the back. He was drifting around a post, not seeing the hill ahead, and I was on the back on a sled. After our wild ride, we decided to head back to Taylor's creek, which was frozen about 12 inches thick. I was driving the quad along the bank, with Taylor on the ice behind me. Suddenly, the ice started to crack, so I sped up to prevent him from falling in. However, after about two minutes, the ice gave way, and Taylor went under. I managed to pull him out and raced back to his house.   Once we were safe, Taylor changed into dry clothes and sat there, laughing for hours about our crazy escapades. It was a day full of thrills and laughter that we would never forget.

Laughter is a symbol of joy and happiness. It is to become amused or derisive. Many people today make jokes or funny remarks just to hear somebody laugh. It is never something we should take for granted. Through many relationships no matter what kind, I believe laughter takes up at least 1% of your relationship. It's to show the best out of someone and to let them know you are listening. There are plenty of other reasons in this world needed for laughter. "I'm sure you can even think of one". In my views of this world and our society today, I believe laughter is what makes up our "human" spirit. It's to show ourselves and other people the spark we have inside us. Have you ever sat and pondered why we make each other laugh? I have asked myself this same question over and over. For me making people laugh is letting them know I care and to also think I'm funny as well. We even do it just the fact of wanting people to like us better and to be known as funny, hilarious, or just a good person to talk to. Sometimes we can go to the extremes of being too funny, and feeling guilty for picking on someone in a laughable way. I remember in the eighth grade, I was thirteen years old. I was really shy and didn't have many friends. One day in class, some of the popular kids actually came over and started talking to me. I was excited and nervous that other kids wanted to talk to me. Of course they were laughing and making jokes, not caring what anyone else was saying. Then this one girl started talking about other people like she knew everything. When she started talking about my best friend it made me angry but happy at the same time because some of the things she was saying were true. That's where I messed up, I started talking about all the other dumb things she did, just to make everybody else laugh. As I was sitting there all I felt was guilt and disappointment in myself. I couldn't believe I was sitting there talking about my best friend, just to try and make myself popular. Later that day she came up to me really upset and couldn't understand why I would do that to her. I told her I was sorry and that I only did it to make myself popular and seem funny to other kids. We didn't talk for almost two weeks. I tried to do everything in my own possible way to get my best friend back. It did take me a while, but she finally came around and forgave me. It was a good life lesson for me, knowing laughter may not always be a good thing. Now me and my friend are juniors in high school and when we think back on that day. We both together can share a laugh. In conclusion, you can see how laughter can bring somebody up and tear them down. I have experienced these things as well in my lifetime. Laughter has made me stronger and to be a better person, even if it means turning down popular kids you don't hurt those closest to you. Go out and make somebody laugh today.

Laughter is a vital aspect of life, bringing joy and connection to those who share in it. However, it is important to remember that laughter can have consequences, especially when it comes at the expense of others. In the end, laughter should always be a source of positivity and togetherness, rather than a tool for belittlement or harm.

Laughter is a key to any happy and successful relationship in my opinion. It can break the ice in an akward situation or help you become closer to someone. Some people have said that laughter is the shortest distance between two people, and that laughter is the best medicine. I believe that both of those statements are true. Personally laughter has dramatically changed many different social situations throught my @NUM1 years of life.  One time in particular that I remember laughter really bringing me closer together with other people is when I was camping with a few of my friends. It was three years ago in the middle of @DATE1 and we were all sleeping outside under the stars. We had all been talking about pretty serious stuff, family and friend problems and just sharing our hardships in general with eachother. I didn't really have much to complain about, I had a pretty average family that I loved along with good friends. However that evening I was learning some interesting but disturbing information about my friends home life. She started to talk about how her parents don't care and how they are both alcoholics, I could tell by her tone of voice how painful admitting this information was for her. The mood had suddenly changed from discussing light issues to a serious, emotional conversation. She continued to tell me how alone she felt sometimes and how she just always wished she could be with her friends because we always have a good time.   After she told me all of this we laid in silence for a while. Neither of us were asleep but I had no idea what to say. I mean how could anything I say make that situation better or help her to feel better. While we had been having this conversation our other friend had run back to the car to grab sodas and go to the bathroom. We heard her saying our names and searching for us in the dark. All of a sudden she knew where we were, she had tripped over the edge of our sleeping bag fell on us and spilled a bunch of fizzy grape soda all over our faces. Normally we would have been angry but we all thought this was hysterical. While in the midst of laughing like crazy people I looked at my friend who had just recently told me her painful story, now she was crying from laughing so hard and I knew that a little laughter had brought us closer.  That is a memory that I will never forget, it was an experience where I feel laughter has played a major role in making a relationship more comfortable and close. Similar experiences have occured throughout my whole life. Laughter is a common ground, where all people can relate to one another. Maybe it brings people closer together because when you are legitimatley laughing you are so caught up in it that you forget about everything else. All of your problems disappear. Laughter truly has the power to bring people together and create stronger connections.
