"@CAPS1!" @CAPS2 society today loves laughter. From comical shows to hilarious friends, people have fun convulsing with glee. Not to mention that when you're doubled over with laughter you are getting an amazing workout. Everyone that texts @MONTH1 use "@CAPS3" or "haha" to show they think something is funny; but it is nothing compared to actually being with friends and having, "a smile that burst."  I couldn't wait. I was on the coast at a camp with my friends, and we were about to head-up to walk up to the three crosses. Some of the other girls were asleep and we had to leave quietly. One of the girls tripped as we were walking out the door and it took all we had to not burst out in laughter. Because when she tripped, she barely caught herself, as she was about to fall on sleeping @CAPS4. Jasmine scurried out the door with the rest of us. After the door was closed, we all doubled over laughing. Jasmine's face, when she tripped was priceless.  We headed into the crisp air without looking back. From a gravel path to the cement road going up the hill, we happily skipped along. As the hill got steeper, we started walking. Jasmine, after being tired from skipping, almost fell again. Everyone started laughing again. The walk up the hill was taking longer than expected. Finally, we could see the three crosses at the top.  When we arrived at the crosses, we waited for the miraculous sunrise. We kept staring at the ocean; waiting with anticipation. Eventually, @CAPS5 pointed out that the sun rises on the east and would we coming over the mountains. Again, all the girls laughed because we were so tired we forgot which side the sun rose on. At last, the astonishing sunrise happened. It was full of pink, purples, yellows and oranges. After watching the sunrise we realized we still had the treacherous walk back down the hill. I peered over the edge and saw a little path. With a bunch of convincing, I got all the girls to walk down the steep hill because it looked shorter than the cement road we came up.  The first part of the path was simple. As we started heading farther down the hill it got skinnier with more brush. A couple of the girls thought we should head back up, but I convinced them otherwise. So on we went. "@CAPS6 no!" @CAPS7 yelled. We turned to see she had managed to let her shoe fall of into a blackberry bush. She had just gotten her shoes the day before and now they are muddy and lost. Everyone was trying to reach it, but it was just a little too far away. Suddenly, @PERSON1 tried to grab the shoe; immediately she fell into the blackberry bush! @PERSON2 forgot about her shoe for a little and started doubled over with laughter again. While flailing and screaming we yelled for her to stop because if I didn't mention this earlier; this is a very steep hill. While she was in the bush, she grabbed @PERSON2's shoe. The hard part was getting @PERSON1 out.  The first time we tried to pull her up; we got her up a couple of inches then she fell back down, into the bush. Finally, after what felt like a million tries, we pulled her big butt out of the bush. Everyone was laughing so hard during the extravaganza. @PERSON1 was super embarrassed. After all of that, we headed down the hill. We still had giggles while trotting down the trail. As we went, we saw animal tracks. We then realized the trail was most likely made by animal. A couple girls joked around about being terrified of the animal tracks. Eventually, we got back to the cabin, still laughing about what had taken place. The rest of the day everyone was happy and giggly for waking up with an amazing morning.  Laughter helped the girls have a wonderful rest of the day. Laughter helped us work through the mud, the shoe losing, and the cold. With out it, we could have been very grumpy. Also, having amazing friends to laugh with was phenomenal. Laughing helps people be happy; being happy is better than being sad; therefore, laughter is important. When writing this paper to the @ORGANIZATION1's in @LOCATION1, I told my friends about the adventure we went on and the predicament we got ourselves into. They laughed hysterically, since they knew the girls. Laugh often to be happy.  Laughter is indeed a powerful tool that can turn any situation into a joyful experience. It helps us navigate through challenges and brings us closer together with friends. So, let's embrace laughter in our lives and continue to spread happiness wherever we go

It was some day in December, I was on my way to school. My friend Alex was walking with me because we both lived on the same street. He lived a few houses away from me but we always walked to and from school together. Well on this particular day i decided to wear a pair of sneakers that had absolutely no traction on the bottom of the shoe and there was snow out. I slipped a few times but never fell. We were laughing because I would be right in the middle of saying something and id almost fall over. We got to school and he started telling everyone about it, I joined in. It was pretty funny because even at school I would almost fall over because the floors were wet from the dried snow. I thought about just walking home and changing my shoes but I would have to wait until lunch because I couldn't leave school until then or i would get in trouble. After first period I found a puddle of water and started sliding across it for fun. My friends tried doing it too but their shoes had too much traction on it. The bell rang for second period to start and I headed to my class. It was fun trying to get to class because I slid around everywhere. Once I got into class the teacher told me we where going on a field trip to the ponds. I was about to skip out on it but the teacher was walking right behind me. We boarded the bus and started heading out to the ponds. My teacher called our names out to make sure we were all there. He must have done it about every ten minutes. It was pretty annoying. The bus driver was playing country music too, I don't really mind country music but that day I didn't really want to listen to it. I went to get my ipod from my pocket and found out it wasn't there. I had left it at my house when I was rushing to get to school. We finally arrived at the ponds and we unloaded the bus to begin our field trip. Our teacher told us not to go to close to the ponds because if we fell in we would be soaked and the bus driver wouldn't let us back on the bus. I thought he was just talking smack and I asked the bus driver if he was serious. The bus driver told me if we got wet he would have to wait for us to dry off so we didn't get the seats wet. Again I thought it was a bunch of bull. We met up with our tour guide dude and started listening to him tell us about the history of the ponds and what they are used for. While walking around the ponds I started to slide on the ground. I grabbed onto my friend so I wouldn't fall over but he had pretty bad balance and we both fell over. Everyone started laughing as well as myself. My friend didn't think it was too funny at first. But once he got up he started laughing and joked about how I couldn't stand up right. On our way back to the school we talked about what we learned and if we would want to go back and learn more or even volunteer to work at the ponds. I thought it would be pretty fun if I didn't slip around the whole time. We unloaded the bus again and headed into the school. I found out the little puddle i had found earlier hadn't dried up, I got a running start and slid across it. I didn't fall over this time. The bus had brought us back just in time for the last class of the day, which unfortunately for me was P.E. I got to the gym and asked my teacher what we were going to be playing. He told me we were going upstairs on the wrestling mats to play a dodge ball game. Upstairs on the wrestling mats was a small area and we only went up there if we had a small class. I lucked out big time because we have to take our shoes off when we play on the mats.  I got done with P.E. and the bell rang to tell us school was over. I got dressed into my normal clothes and headed home. My friend Alex was waiting outside for me. We started heading home and I slide around with every step I took. The sun had melted the top layer of snow and turned it into ice. I looked over at the pond and laughed. He laughed too. The whole way home I was skating on ice. It was a really fun day. Except right when I got home I fell on the deck because the step was icy.

It was one of those days where I just sat around all day doing nothing, but play video games, text, and laugh at myself. It was one of those days where no one bothered me; no one even really talked to me; no one told me to do chores. By dinner time someone decided to call me up stairs to eat, but let me tell you, it wasn't anything like pizza. Although I'd rather eat it than get a lecture on not being thankful. My brother came home for the first time in ever, ate with us, then decided to leave again. But this time I asked to come with; I'm so tired of beating my high score on the game. He said no, of course. I made my daddy change his mind for him, of course. I don't see why he wouldn't let me come in the first place. He was going to hang out with the guys I grew up with, my friends, not his. Anyways. I got ready then we hit the road. There him and I were, laughing about dinner and what kind of music my mom listens to, on our way to pick up my friends. These guys are great! All we do is crack jokes about each other and crack up. But let's get down to business. I didn't tell you this, but it's summer time, around The Fourth of July. Fireworks are for sale and we're creating "bombs" out of them. Or they are. Since I'm a girl, I guess I'm not allowed, or something lame like that. But there is this girl my brother likes and I guess he wants to impress, excuse me "impress" her by showing up at her house so she can see these "master pieces" they've made. That just makes me feel bad for him, but honestly just made me laugh. Maybe she'll be impressed. Key word: maybe. Although, no, it won't. Because to this day they are still only friends. So about these bombs. Complete duds. We tried, well I just watched, over and over again to make 'em work, but they wouldn't do a thing. Eventually my friend Josh put a whole bunch of sparklers into my favorite stuffed animal. It just made a bunch of sparkly colors and loud noises, but it was pretty fun to watch. We got in on video too, it was a total good laugh for everyone. After my brother said goodbye to his "girl," we decided to head home. The thing is, we had so many fireworks left! We know this kid Tim who lives somewhere on the way home. So we decided to go by his house, have Josh get out of the truck, light the firework on his porch, have him jump in the tail of the trunk, then drive off as fast as we could. The first time we did it we couldn't stop laughing. They didn't come out of their house, so we did it again. They still didn't come out. We did it about one more time, by then all the neighbors were out. They were all so confused. That just made us laugh even more. It was so great we wanted to keep doing it, but to someone else this time. We know this girl Sarah who lives near all of us. We thought, why not? It's not gonna hurt to stop there real quick and have some fun with her too. Apparently she thought different. Way different, actually she thought it was the rudest thing ever. We were just joking around, gettin' a laugh out of all our fun. We weren't being rude, she's our friend. Long story short, her mom got mad too and chased us down in her car. She never caught us, but she got our license plate number. The next day, on The Fourth of July, she called the police. They didn't think it was a big deal, but they still showed up at my house and talked to my parents about what went down. I was at my boyfriend's so lucky me I only had to talk to my mom on the phone about it. She realized we were just having fun and actually laughed about it too. That Fourth of July night was great. It was one of those nights where you laughed the whole time and wouldn't change a thing even if you got in trouble with the law for it. Something I will definitely never do again, but I'm so glad I have this hilarious memory to reminisce on for the rest of my life.

He wasted about six marshmellow before he even got one that he could eat. And everytime he dropped one into the fire it got more and more funny. We laughed and laughed until our stomach hurt. The best part was theat my grandpa didn't think it was funny so he just looked at me and my cousin like we were stupid or something. My cousin and I have gone camping with my grandpa every year now for about four years and each year we have an adventure filled with laughter as we go closer to each other. He and I believe that it is important to laugh together because it keeps you smiling and helps you grow closer to whoever you are with. Keep laughing and have a fun in all you do.

"Laughter" I believe laughter is the shortest distance between two people. When things between you and a loved one get fuzzy making them laugh will always help break the ice. When I get angry with my boyfriend he knows that in order for me to be happy he must make me smile/laugh. That is exactly what he does. The very first time he made me angry he didn't know what to do. It was @DATE1 @CAPS1 and I had just started dating. I remember he asked me if I was hungry and I said "no I'm not hungry," so he continued to ask. Since we had only been dating for a short period of time he really didn't know much about me, so he didn't know that I am a type of girl that gets annoyed easily and I have a really low temper. He continued to ask me if I was hungry, thirsty, bored, or tired but he didn't realize that at this point I was really annoyed; an hour and a half passed by and he was still asking! I was going crazy I didn't want to tell him how I felt because I knew I was going to make him feel bad, but I thought to myself and said "no he has to know because its going to be worst if later on in the relationship he has to find out what I like and don't like on his own rather that me telling him. I went on and told him every single little detail about me good and bad, at first he just listened but towards the end he exploded and told me that why wasn't I just straight up with him from the beginning. That made me really upset, I was trying to be honest with him before anything worse happened but i guess not. I stayed quiet for the longest time and he kept asking me "what's wrong," "tell me what I did wrong" so I told him that it really made me upset how he flipped out on me for no reason really all I was trying to do was save us from a larger argument, he looked at me and told me that I did do something wrong! He said that we had already been together for two months and it took me that long to show him my true colors I kind of understood where he was coming from but at the same time I didn't agree because by that point he should have already known. I mean it doesn't take that long to know a person especially if its your girlfriend. In the end we just agreed that we had to be ourselves around each other. He busted out saying "ouch charlie you bit me" in a @CAPS2 accent that just made me loose it I laughed for days after that and completely forgot about thee over whelming discussion we had. The point being here is that laughter is the tool to breaking the ice when things get tough and it doesn't necessarily have to be a loved one it can even be a complete stranger, if the person is shy making them laugh will help construct a great friendship with them. You can make anybody's day go great with just a little grin that you put on their face a simple "hello" or "hey" can even make them smile. I believe that a person that smiles often lives longer. This @MONTH1 not be true but in my little world it is. I am all about smiling, all about making people laugh. Honestly I hate seeing people walk around with angry faces like if they have no friends when all they really want is someone to make them smile-and that would be me! In conclusion, if it wasn't for laughter what relationship would still be standing at this point? None, because if your always arguing and always wining and never laughing then how do you expect your relationship to last? Like I said "Laughter is the shortest distance between two people."   Laughter plays a crucial role in building and strengthening relationships, whether with loved ones or even strangers. It has the power to break down barriers, ease tension, and create connections that can last a lifetime. So, don't underestimate the value of a good laugh - it may just be the key to a happy and lasting relationship.

For me, laughter makes the world go round. It is much needed to keep the world light and filled with a sense of happiness. You will hardly come across me without a big old smile plastered across my face. There are so many stories to choose from but one that will be the most fun to tell, I think. It still makes me giggle just thinking about that moment. I was going on a trip with my last boyfriend, down to for the Fourth of July. They have a big Fourth of July walk and I was lucky to get to tag along with him and his mom. We were staying with good friends of his mom, and. Their house was stunningly amazing, with beautiful wood floors, a big open living room that combined with the kitchen and dining room, vaulted ceilings, and a big stunning window that framed crisp scenery. Even with the house being so great, my favorite part was the railroad tracks. Not more than a quarter of a mile through a little trail surrounded by woods were two sets of tracks stretching out in both directions as far as the eye could see. My favorite part of the whole trip were those tracks. It was the second night of our stay in around midnight. My boyfriend and I went for a walk in the refreshing night air. We could hardly see and were holding on tight to each other to try and keep balance. Smiling and giggling, we finally stumbled out of the very well-hidden trail entrance onto the tracks. Hand in hand, we started to walk down the tracks just enjoying each other's presence. In the dark, the stars were the most stunning I have ever seen. I'm not sure why, but the sky just seemed to open up and look two times bigger than it really is. Midnight was perfect for stargazing without a cloud in sight. So we decided to lay down between the tracks and look at the stars. There we cuddled together for a good few minutes. Then my boyfriend looked up, giving me a puzzled expression. I followed his gaze to see what had caught his attention. Far in the distance was a light slowly advancing towards us - a train at midnight. Looking back at each other, we both laughed at the pure surprise of a train at that hour. As the train advanced, we jumped off the tracks to wait for it to pass so we could resume our spot. The train was going way slower than I was expecting, no more than four to five miles per hour. My boyfriend's eyes lit up with an idea, and without thinking, he said, "We should jump it!" As soon as the words left his mouth, he regretted saying them. I thought it was a great idea, but he tried desperately to convince me not to do it. I headed towards the track, telling him to live a little and let's have some fun. I had never jumped a train before, but from the looks of it, this train was perfect to try it out on. I grabbed onto one and jumped on right before my boyfriend could stop me. He finally gave in and jumped on the next one. We were both smiling and having a great time when we jumped off and met in a hug. Then the train stopped, and we froze. A light started coming our way, and freaking out, thinking we would get in trouble, I sprinted for the trailhead with my boyfriend close on my heels. I couldn't find the trail, and the light was getting closer, so we both jumped full speed straight into a big bunch of bushes. There we stayed perfectly still until the light passed us and the train began to resume its pace. I met my boyfriend's big fat smile, and we both just rolled over laughing, unable to help ourselves. What were the chances of going out for a simple walk and all this happening? Still smiling hugely, my boyfriend leaned over to me and gave me a perfect kiss. That was one of my best nights ever. This moment is just an example of how smiling and laughter were a big part of my boyfriend's and my relationship. Love, friends, and laughter are the reasons life is worth living.

Being able to laugh is one of the greatest feelings in the world, especially when shared with family. These moments are priceless and create lasting memories that bring joy even in difficult times. During a family trip to an unfamiliar destination, getting lost turned out to be a hilarious adventure. Despite the confusion and worry, laughter filled the car as they navigated through the town. Jokes about the mother's navigation skills lightened the mood and made the trip unforgettable. Laughter truly connects family and friends, turning negative situations into cherished memories. Life is meant to be enjoyed, and laughter with loved ones is a vital part of that enjoyment. Embrace the moments of laughter and fun, for they are what make life truly worth living.

Laughter brings people together in a unique and powerful way, creating bonds that can last a lifetime. I experienced this firsthand when I joined a lacrosse team and connected with two girls through laughter. Our shared moments of joy and amusement helped us build a strong friendship that extended to the entire team. As we traveled to a tournament, laughter continued to unite us, despite our diverse backgrounds and origins. This experience taught me that laughter is a universal language that can bridge differences and bring people closer. It truly is the shortest distance between two individuals, making the world a better and brighter place when shared among friends.

Humor is a huge part of who I am, and I love making people laugh, but this story is about an event that made my whole family fall down laughing on the floor. It all started one day when my cousin received a trampoline for his birthday. It was a great day not only for him but for the rest of us kids too because we all could go and play on it whenever we wanted.  We were always over at my cousin's house after that. We would have competitions to see who could jump the highest or who could do the coolest trick. Sometimes we would fall off or one of us would get hurt, and then my aunt and uncle wouldn't let us play on it for a while. But they would always cave and let us back on it.  It wasn't until a few months later that we all witnessed the funniest accident that any of us had ever seen in our lifetime. It all started out at my aunt's birthday party. Usually, she had it at some fancy restaurant, but not this year. This year she decided just to have it at home to save some money.  So we all showed up for my aunt's party - my mom, my brothers, and me. First off, we did all the regular birthday things - meeting family members, eating some food, and singing happy birthday. Basically, in my eyes, it was all the boring stuff. I mean, come on, there was a trampoline out in the backyard just waiting to be jumped on, but the adults wouldn't let us get anywhere near it until we had eaten.  Finally, everyone was done eating, and they were going to let us kids go have our fun. It started off as normal as any other day we went to play on the trampoline, but little did we know that all of our stomachs would be hurting from laughing in a few hours from an event that was about to transpire.

@CAPS1 is my personal belief that hilarity and giddiness are the best emotional states to be in. Therefore, it makes sense that people who find laughter in the same things would be of good relations. It is because of their likeness of minds that they are connected and find happiness in each other's company. My story is an example of laughter's connection between people and the strength of the bond it forms. Picture the scene: it was a hot day on the north side of a mountain. Standing there was a weak eleven-year-old boy who thought he could not continue further. Patiently standing beside him was his father, a climbing veteran who had scaled mountains in different locations. The boy was tired, he could not put one foot in front of the other. His muscles screamed in protest as the blisters on his heels throbbed in harmony. The sun beat down on him while the snow gave way and brought him to the ground. It was as if the mountain wanted him to fail and was urging him to give in and cry in defeat. Fatigue then consumed the boy adding fifty pounds to each of his limbs. His brain had dimmed as well leaving him capable of only simple thoughts like putting one foot in front of the other. He began finding any excuse to stop and made them often. The boy's father had tried everything he could think of to give his son the incentive to keep going with no avail. He tried another tack, he began to tell the boy stories, perhaps in hope that it would take the boy's mind off the excruciating pain. And to the relief of all concerned, it proved effective. What was most interesting about the whole event is it wasn't the content of the stories that helped, it was the humorous and sarcastic tone that made the real difference. An infusion that I would describe as a solution of laughing gas and an energy drink washed over me. In the presence of my father's humor, I found the strength to keep going. It was like I had been completely recharged and refreshed. My arms and legs, which had previously felt like solid pipes of lead, lightened considerably. The stabbing agony in my muscles and joints frayed away and left. The dull pulsing of the blisters on my heels was silenced. This was all due to someone's thoughts and ideas tickling my funny bone. I believe laughter to be the anesthetic of nature, the emotional element that keeps the world sane. It was at that point in time when I realized what I respected most about my father. I had no shortage of traits to choose from. He had an indomitable work ethic, was a great teacher, and possessed an extraordinary amount of energy. But what I respected most about him was that we were similar in our humor. We laughed at the same things and found hilarity in each other's comments. It forged a strong bond between us, one constructed of euphoria and glee that continues to this day. Whenever I am morose, he always manages to find a way to bring a smile to my face and I found that I too had the same ability. To my belief, a relationship formed on laughter is the strongest one of all. Laughter is a force that paves the way to friendship, respect, and love. You cannot have hope for a better future if you do not have laughter. It is the drug that descends from the heavens, a drug that runs through the bloodstream of society, freeing the minds from the stress and worries of what tomorrow will bring. Laughter can unite a population and instill a feeling of friendship in a society. Have you ever laughed at something and then turned to find that at the exact same moment someone across the room had also begun to laugh? Then your eyes lock and a slow smile spreads throughout both of your faces, as you realize that you are not alone in how you think and what you laugh at. That connective force is a result of the power of laughter.

Laughing, smirking, giggling, chuckling; these all have to do with one subject, that is, laughing. Laughter is everywhere, you hear it in libraries, parks, at home, behind your back, it can be a great thing or a horrible thing even with family and friends. Everyone has a past with laughing that has welcomed them, helped them out, cheered them up, or even, just so they can make a very special friend that will stay with them forever.  It was the start of a brand new school year. I had just moved from another town. I was a seventh grader about to start at a new school in a new town, and I wasn't a real big fan of hanging out with people, so I stayed to myself most of the weeks, eating lunch in the guidance center, trying to figure out where books were without talking to anybody. My schedule was good, I had choir, art, drama, you know all the stuff I like. Art and drama were a blast, but when it came to choir and singing, my social level went down. I love to sing, but never did it in front of people.  Then one day, I was walking to choir and I tripped and fell, my papers falling with me. My school work was all over the hall, math at one end, science at the other. But, out of all the kids in the hallway, only one laughed. She walked by, said I did a great job but something triggered her to come back. She helped me pick up all my math homework and picked up my schedule and saw that she too had choir this period. Her name was Sarah, she told me, and I told her my name, and we walked together. We sat next to each other and I sang with her, our voices in harmony.  We talked in between periods, at lunch, on the bus ride home. We became great friends and the principal thought so too and he went ahead and gave us classes together. We were friends and we still are friends till this day. But the sad thing is that she moved at the near end of eighth grade year. But she was the only friend I had for a little while and I always give her a call every now and then. Sometimes we can talk for hours, laughing and talking about how we are doing and when we are going to see each other again. She has been my best friend for at least two years now and it all happened by a slip of a foot, that falling of papers, and one little laugh from an amazing person.  Laughing has got me so far in life and at school. Every now and then, when I see someone all alone, wanting a friend, I go and talk to them, and even laugh with them. One little laugh can trigger a huge friendship waiting to happen. Some say, "Laughter is the shortest distance between two people." and I believe whoever said that because it happened to me. Laughter truly is a powerful connector, bringing people together in unexpected and beautiful ways.

When it comes down to laughter, it can change a person's thinking or even the mood that they are in. Laughter can be the ending result, to a bad start to a day or to greater the relationship between two people. I love to laugh because it shows how I am feeling and it keeps me happy, I not only laugh when I'm sad, but also when I'm in a great mood as well. Growing up in a world full of tragedies and war, I feel like you should always keep your head held high and the smiles flowing. Although, when life gives you lemons, you must make lemonade and keep your face with the sour look because it's funny! I think that laughter is one of the best medicines around and can fix most problems whenever you are feeling down. My older sister brought into this world the most amazing little nieces an aunt could ever have. When they were little babies I used to make silly faces, dance to music, and watch movies with them, but this isn't what brought us closer. It was the fact that I wanted to laugh, in which made them happy too. One time, I was feeling really down and out, but I didn't want that to affect me, so I proceeded with my day and began to watch music videos, when "Crazy in Love", by Beyonce came on. They went crazy! They started jumping on the bed and twirling their hair back and forth as if they were Beyonce!, they really stole the show. I couldn't believe what was happening before my eyes, and I burst out with so much joy. I felt so much of their joy, that I had to get up and dance with them, we jumped, we twirled, and whipped our hair several times before the song ended with us dizzy and out of breath. After we had our fun of the music video, they just kept dancing and in my head I'm, like "don't they ever get tired", but I was pretty sure that their laughter brought them continuous amazement. A smile is worth a thousand words and laughter is priceless, my nieces really and are truly what brought me up that day. It was bitter in the start but then ended up sweet, let's just call it bittersweet. I feel like my nieces knew that I would be sad so they would say "Shorty, what's wrong", Shorty being my nickname because I am very short. They would always find a way to make me feel the need to smile and have a good time. Me and my nieces' relationship has grown to the highest extent and I know that whenever I'm with them, I will laugh. If someone once said that "laughter is the shortest distance between two people", then they are correct because I may be in a different country, state or any other area but whether we talk on the phone or actually see each other, I will laugh about all their crazy antics and the closer we become as one.

Having laughter in your life is essential in showing your true self. It transcends relationships, whether it be with a romantic partner or a friend. Laughter brings people closer together, creating memorable moments and strengthening bonds. It is a powerful tool that can turn any situation into a joyful one. So, embrace laughter in your life and cherish the moments of pure happiness it brings.

Just walking through a party store in a banana costume with one of your best friends, trying to find the perfect costumes for an upcoming event, can lead to endless laughter and unforgettable memories. The bond we formed through laughter extended beyond just the two of us - it drew others to us, creating a sense of camaraderie and shared happiness. Whether we were playing games with neighbors or simply hanging out in the sun, our laughter always brought people together and strengthened our friendships. As the saying goes, "Laughter is the shortest distance between two people," and it couldn't be more true in our case. Our shared laughter has not only connected us on a deeper level but has also helped us navigate through tough times with a lighter heart. In the end, it's clear that laughter truly is the glue that holds our friendship together, making every moment spent together a cherished memory that we'll always hold dear.

Many other people believe that laughter is an important part of any relationship. I also agree with those thoughts. When I first arrived in a new place about a year ago, I struggled to communicate as I did not speak the language fluently. However, I quickly learned that laughter can bridge any language barrier. Instead of feeling embarrassed, I found her laughter infectious, and it helped us bond instantly. Through our shared laughter, we became fast friends, and I realized that laughter truly is a universal language that can bring people together in any situation.

Laughter is the best way to show someone that they are funny. It is the best way to relax. Everyone says that hearing a baby laugh is great. Watching comedians doing their acts can cheer people up and have them start laughing. Laughter is the best way to relax and here is three reason for that. First, is that no one can stay angry at the person making them laugh. Second, is that when someone laughs everyone around that person start laughing. Third and last reason, is that no one can stay sadden when something funny is happening. What do you think when you hear a baby's laughter? I think that the baby is truly loved by its family. @CAPS6 only happened a few weeks ago on a day when all the students were supposed to be out having fun or sleeping because there was plenty of snow outside. A guy was crying in the band room, holding a french horn in his lap, his gaze fixed on the ground. He expressed his frustration about never getting the first chair position despite his hard work. Another student, who held the coveted first chair position, tried to explain the situation, emphasizing the need for specific players in specific spots. The argument escalated, threatening to tear apart the horn section. Realizing the potential consequences, a third student intervened with a humorous approach, diffusing the tension and prompting a resolution. The senior student was promised the first chair position once the competition ceased, bringing an end to the conflict. Despite being the target of jokes, the humorous intervention ultimately helped improve the relationship between the two students. As they look forward to the senior student's upcoming opportunity to shine, the band section is now characterized by mutual understanding and respect.

Everyone loves to laugh, but not everyone fully understands the power of laughter in building relationships. A simple laugh can bring two strangers together and turn them into close friends. This was the case for me and my best friend, @PERSON1. We started laughing when we first met in the @NUM3 grade, and that laughter broke the ice, making everything less awkward between us. As we continued to laugh and talk, our friendship grew stronger. By @NUM6 grade, we were inseparable, spending weekends together and sharing secrets. Our laughter not only brought us closer but also created a strong bond of trust and support between us. When @PERSON1 needed a place to stay, she moved in with me, and our friendship only deepened. Living together has only strengthened our friendship, and we are like sisters now. It's incredible to think that a simple laugh was all it took for us to become the closest of friends. Laughing truly has the power to transform strangers into lifelong companions.

One summer evening back in high school, a couple of friends and I were feeling incredibly bored. Nothing seemed appealing - not a trip to the movies, not grabbing some food, not even playing video games. It was then that one friend suggested we go outside and do something different. Before we left, he grabbed two hefty rolls of plastic wrap from his pantry. As we walked, he kept urging us to follow him without revealing our destination. Eventually, we ended up at a local building, where he unveiled his plan.  The idea was simple yet mischievous. Three of us would be stationed on the roof as lookouts, while the rest would be on the ground to execute the prank. When the coast was clear, we would quickly run across the street and wrap the plastic around it, causing cars to come to a halt. Despite some initial doubts about the plan, we all agreed to give it a try.  As we waited for the signal, tension mounted. Finally, we received the go-ahead and swiftly carried out the prank. The sight of cars stopping in confusion was both exhilarating and hilarious. However, when a police car approached, we had to make a quick escape, leaving behind one roll of plastic wrap.  After narrowly avoiding getting caught, we regrouped at a friend's house, laughing and reminiscing about the successful prank. Moments like these strengthened our bond and created lasting memories. The thrill of laughter and the shared experience brought us closer together as friends, solidifying our friendship even more.

I agree when people say laughter is what mostly brings people together. In my opinion, most of the time when you're talking to someone, laughter is needed. It is what brings the dullness out of a person and makes the conversation interesting. Only when you are talking about something serious, you don't need to include laughter, but I'll explain later.  I can easily tell a true story about laughter from my life. Right now, I have a perfect group of friends. Sure, there are times when they mess up and act like kids, but I feel like I need to forgive and remember that they are there when I need them. Anyways, I can remember the first time I met each one of them, and the one thing that started our friendship was a joke. I can't exactly remember which joke we shared, but I do remember that we all had the same taste in comedy. And once we saw that neither of us were serious and dull people, it made us want to spend more time with each other.  As time passed, my friends and I were really drawn to each other. From time to time, we were happy to express our friendship through jokes. Sometimes the jokes are really stupid and have caused us to bring revenge on each other, but that is just how we stay close to each other. Day by day, when we see something funny on television, the internet, or real life, we always show it to each other and know that the other person will find it very funny. It makes us feel closer and know we all have the same taste in at least one field.  I can give one clear example of this: I was watching a comedy once, and the comedian was talking about his childhood and a prank he once played on a stranger's house. Right when I saw this video, I knew right away my friends had to see this because I knew from past experiences that they enjoy these types of laughs. And I was right, as soon as they saw the show, they were amazed at how funny it was, and we got closer than ever.  I want to share one more example from my life about laughter bringing two people closer. So, after telling you that laughter gets me closer with friends, I also want to point out that laughter brings out a sense of outline when you talk to girls - or boys, if you're a female. I met this one girl, and every time I talked to her, I had to throw in a joke or a story that would make sense to our subject. After a while, she started joking around and making stories too. She told me that she saw me as a different guy compared to other people. She said that she meant I wasn't a boring type of person, and that it kept her wanting to keep talking to me. Now, me and this girl are closer than ever, and the root that started this relationship was laughter.  So, as you see, laughter makes any relationship happy and open. Of course, I'm talking about the relationships that are playful. I meant there are people out there that take everything seriously and can't take a joke. But I would really encourage you to take laughter in your life if you already haven't. Look in my life, I used laughter and gained a lot of friends of all sorts just by joking around about something stupid. You don't have to say stupid things, but I say it would really make your life more interesting if you use laughter.

These are some examples that I remember when I had fun and laughter in my life. It all started in the early years when I was a child, and my cousins were living with us because they had just moved down to our town from another place. It was fun having them around. My cousins and I would always ride bikes. Sometimes, one of my cousins would take my bike without asking, and I would get mad at him. We would race down the street with our bikes, and I always seemed to win on my dirt bike made for racing.  We would go behind some apartments where we had built a ramp out of dirt. One rainy day, we all went outside to play, even though it was pouring. We got all muddy and had a great time, despite the mess. After cleaning up, we would play video games or head to the park for free lunch. It was always a blast being at the park with friends and family, playing and enjoying the outdoors.  In later years, my friends and I would often stay at one friend's house for the weekend. We would play games, including one memorable birthday sleepover where we played Grand Theft Auto. Laughter was always a big part of our friendship, and those who could make us laugh were the best company to keep.  Laughter is essential in friendships because it creates a bond and shows that someone is a good person to be around. Friends who can make you laugh are truly valuable. In my experience, laughter has been a crucial aspect of my relationships with friends and family, making our time together all the more enjoyable.

Someone once said laughter was the best medicine. To me it was like someone was saying "Hey! Life isn't gonna get any better so just enjoy it while you can!" And that's what I did for a while, but laughing at everything got old very quickly. Sad to say I still laugh at most things, even sad things. I laugh because I think that if I do then everything will just get better. That's not even close to what really happens. In fact, it only causes more pain and suffering in most cases.  Like the time where I met this guy named Person1. He was amazing. Most people who met him thought he was a god and when he heard people talking about him like that he would always get very upset. He was a human. Nothing more and nothing less. That's how I saw it and that's how he saw it too. When we first started talking to each other it was between notes I would give my friend and she would give them to him. He was a very shy guy so he never wrote back on a piece of paper. Instead he had her tell me what he said. Then he finally got the idea to write messages in her phone and then I would read them and answer back. It was fun for a while but I wanted to actually meet the guy.  A few months went by and we were back to our old way of talking to each other. He was very kind and never did he have a bromidic moment. He told me about his family, his life, his future, what he felt, and how he wished he could see me so he could give me a big hug. I thought we could actually make things work between us, that is until he moved away. I was a little upset but it really didn't bother me except the fact that talking to each other became almost as rare as seeing a different picture of him.  While at school one morning my friend came over to me and had a careful gaze. I knew something was wrong and that it had to do with Person1 but I just acted oblivious to it hoping it would lessen the blow I knew was about to come. She said he had told her it wasn't going to work out between him and I. I sat there and like the idiot I was I said I knew it wasn't going to anyways, he was him and I was me. She said he was sorry and all these other excuses but I wouldn't listen. Instead I ignored it and went on with my life like I think everyone should.  So who ever said laughter was the best medicine obviously hadn't experienced the after effects of it all. It may bring temporary relief, but in the end, it can lead to more pain and disappointment. Laughing may help us cope with difficult situations, but it doesn't make the problems disappear. It's important to face reality and deal with our emotions in a healthy way, rather than masking them with laughter.

Trust is a crucial component of any friendship. It is built on honesty, transparency, and mutual respect. When friends trust each other, they can rely on one another to keep their word and be truthful in all situations. This trust forms the foundation of a strong and lasting friendship, where individuals feel comfortable sharing their thoughts and feelings without fear of judgment or betrayal.  In my own circle of friends, we have established a deep level of trust by agreeing to be open and honest with each other. We make a conscious effort to communicate openly, discuss our opinions, and work together to find solutions that benefit everyone. This level of trust allows us to depend on each other like a team, knowing that we have each other's backs and will always support one another.  However, trust can easily be broken if one party is dishonest or deceitful. When trust is lost, it can be challenging to regain, and the relationship may never be the same again. This is why it is essential to value and nurture the trust between friends, as it forms the basis of a strong and meaningful friendship.  In conclusion, trust is a fundamental aspect of any friendship. By being honest, transparent, and dependable, friends can build a strong foundation of trust that will help them navigate challenges and strengthen their bond. It is important to value and protect this trust, as it is the key to maintaining a healthy and fulfilling friendship.

One day when I was having trouble coping with some big changes in my life, I sought the help of a friend. Normally, when I'm having a bad day, I tend to keep to myself. But this time, I needed someone else there to help me. I met with my friend, and she tried everything to cheer me up, but nothing was working. Then she said, "Want to hear a story?" Wanting anything to take me out of my slump, I agreed. She began, "The other day, my family and I went grocery shopping..." She continued to tell me a funny story about their dog treats being mistaken for cookies, and how it led to a hilarious moment with their dad. As she told me the story, I couldn't help but laugh, and soon enough, I found myself feeling much better. I realized that sometimes all you need is a little laughter to brighten your day and help you through tough times.

Have you ever had a fear of falling off of a cliff when up in the mountain? I have, I actually had that experience. It was a few winters ago, we had just gotten off of the bus. I had grabbed all of my gear from the storage from under the bus and headed for the slopes. we strapped in our boots and went to the lift to catch a chair up. I was with my friends, all three of us joined the snowboard team at school that year. The three of us caught a chair up to the top of the run. The air was so crisp, and the snow was a fresh blanket of powder. We were all so excited to go ride in that perfect of a day. As we went down the run, it was the same old usual every time. so I talked to my friends and suggested that it was time we went through some new trails. They agreed, so we went down through a new area. It was a good trail with many jumps and a lot of powder. It seemed like a perfect area to board in. We all enjoyed it very much. But we realized that it was coming to the end when the trail was getting a little narrow, then suddenly, there was a drop right in front of us. I shifted my board sideways so I can stop, but it didn't help. It was a patch of ice that I hit, and it was no use. I couldn't stop. I fell off, and braced for impact. I was thinking that I was about to be seriously injured because of the rocks below. But luckily, my board was the first to hit the rock, showering the cool day with sparks lighting it up. I slid down the snow a couple more feet, trying to stop myself. As I came to a stop, I looked back wondering how I survived that. I was worried that my friends would do the same, but they had stopped just in time. We all couldn't believe on what just happened. I learned a lesson from that day of to always scope out the area first before you go through it. I luckily was not hurt, I could have been seriously injured. It was a scary moment, but it taught me a valuable lesson about safety on the slopes.

A lot of people always say that a sense of humor is very important when looking for a significant other, or even a friend. Some people don't realize how much laughter can bring people together! I know now that all it takes is for two people to laugh together to become great friends. My best friends, Rachel and Sarah, became my friends by doing just that. All my life I've gone to small schools with my aunt, Susan. We are only two years apart so we usually can stay within the same school, so I never feel alone. Rachel ended up going to a different school than me. I would have to face school on my own. My freshman year of high school, I was pretty nervous. It was my first time at a huge school, I had just moved and I didn't know anyone, so I was pretty shy. I made my first friend pretty easily during one of my classes; Mrs. Johnson, the teacher, wanted us to have partners, so that we could do a certain exercise together. Rachel and I both chose each other for some reason, I don't know how, but we were drawn to each other. Mrs. Johnson told us we would be doing the "mirror exercise". We picked somebody to be the mover, and somebody to be the mirror. Rachel ended up being the mover. I had to follow her movements exactly so that Mrs. Johnson wouldn't be able to tell who the mirror was, but when Rachel started acting like a monkey, we both laughed and Mrs. Johnson even laughed too. During lunch, Rachel introduced me to her friend, Sarah. She claimed to have known her for several years. Sarah and I smiled at each other, we didn't really talk at all. By the time my last class of the day came around, I was ready to go home, because it was a math class, I never really liked math. I came to find that I shared that class with Rachel, we met already, and shared Sarah as a friend, we sat by each other. We still didn't have much to say though. A few days went by and we still didn't really talk, we just awkwardly sat next to one another. Meanwhile, Rachel and I became closer friends, acting out silly skits together in Mrs. Johnson's class laughter was bringing us together, but I didn't really notice, because it wasn't any different then how I've made most of my friends. One day, we had testing in our math class, we had to go to the computer lab. Sarah and I chose computers next to each other, we started our tests silently, same as always. Then, suddenly Rachel turned to me and asked me if I had ever heard the "Knock Knock" joke. When I, very startled, replied no, she sang it for me, right there in the middle of the computer lab. When she finished we both started laughing so hard that it hurt. Our teacher warned us to be quiet, and we got back to testing with smiles on our faces. After that moment, everything changed! Like magic, Sarah and I started talking and joking all the time! Rachel noticed the change, she was glad we were getting along so well, but wondered what caused the sudden difference. To this day, Sarah and I share laughs whenever we have the time for it. Even though I am busy with babysitting, school, and my job. While Rachel goes to college, nothing can stop the connection we made that day, through the power of laughter! I have learned that laughter is a top basis for any relationship, but it is not the only one. You also need to have trust. If you can't trust someone, even if they are humorous, that doesn't make them a good friend. You also need a sense of safety. If your friends are encouraging you to do something that makes you feel uncomfortable, they aren't very good friends. I know that Sarah and Rachel are the best friends I will ever have. Laughter brought us together and I know it will keep us together for generations to come!

Laughter is like feeling alive, where nothing else matters, and the pain in your life is released, giving you the feeling that everything is alright. It can lighten the mood, make tense environments more relaxed, and create unforgettable memories. I have shared many adventures with my friend since third grade, filled with laughter and stories to tell. One particular memory that still makes me laugh until I cry is when we tried to spy on our neighbors as kids. Climbing on a trash can next to a wooden fence turned into a disaster, leaving me with scraped hands and a hilarious story to remember. Through laughter, my friend and I have built a strong friendship, as it has become the main source of connection between us. Laughter helps us navigate through challenges, reflect on our mistakes, and simply be ourselves without any pretense. Without laughter, our adventures and experiences wouldn't be the same, and our friendship wouldn't be as strong. It truly is the shortest distance between two people, bringing joy, bonding, and authenticity to any relationship.

The comfort of a laugh. Many different kinds of comfort can come from a laugh. My story is the comfort of love. I was a young and foolish teen. A few days ago my friend had me laughing so hard, and all because he slipped up while meeting my mother. He was nervous to meet my mother. For some reason, I started to laugh and he suddenly began to act as if everything was fine, and that there was nothing to be nervous about. Later we went for our walk, and I asked him about it. I simply said, "Did your mood change when I began to laugh?" He smiled and replied, "When you laugh, I feel calm and know that I am going to be alright." Myself being a typical teen girl, I blushed and quickly changed the topic while trying not to make eye contact. Suddenly, I could not help myself. The feeling of his eyes on my cheek was overpowering my will to not look. Turning my head slowly, sure enough, he was staring straight back into my eyes, his eyes were wonderful, they reminded me of sunflowers with a blue sky behind them. As he stared back, I got a feeling as if he were trying to unlock all that I am, and all that I know with his eyes, as if he could see straight to my soul. Quickly, I turned away. With a soft and almost beautiful voice, he let a little laugh out. This laugh was as sweet to my ears as nectar is to a hummingbird. The next few days were hard. All I could think about was that walk. People must have thought I was crazy, every time I would remember the walk, each time I would remember his laugh, I let a laugh of my own out. I realized that laughter plays a big role in everyone's life. For me, I laugh when I'm with the people I love. For some, it's watching TV that they find amusing, or maybe their kids did something rather silly. So silly, you had to tell your book club. The point is that laughter is everywhere. Laughter is never a bad thing; in fact, it has been proven that laughter has a lot of health benefits. Some people don't get it. Laughter is not something to be ashamed of either, if someone laughs at you, just laugh with them. It's not laughter that starts wars, it's not laughter that kills people, it's people who choose not to fill their lives with the joy of laughter. So here is the goal. Laughter can also be very contagious. So try and pass a laugh on. Do something that makes people remember it, they will start their own laughs. Laughter - pass it on!

The benefits of laughter are well-known, but let's delve into how laughter can strengthen different types of relationships. Lastly, in friendships, the power of laughter can cultivate deep and lasting connections, as people are naturally drawn to those who can bring joy and laughter into their lives. Overall, laughter plays a vital role in fostering strong relationships and creating meaningful connections with others.

In my story, I shared three funny pranks that my brother and I pulled on our aunt. Despite the mess we created, our aunt simply told us to clean up, and we spent hours restoring the bathroom back to normal. These pranks may have caused chaos, but they also created hilarious memories that we can now look back on and laugh about.

Emotions are a fundamental aspect of human life, bringing both tears and laughter, which are essential components of our existence. Recently, I had the opportunity to turn a girl's tears into laughter and brighten her day. It all began on the popular teenage platform, "@CAPS1", where I noticed the girl I liked was also online. We engaged in typical teenage chatter, and she eventually asked if we could hang out. Eager to spend time with her, I agreed to meet at the library.  Upon seeing her, I noticed she appeared upset, though she was still stunning in my eyes. When I inquired about her mood, she was reluctant to share. Wanting to lift her spirits, I launched into a series of humorous and outlandish topics in the hopes of bringing a smile to her face. To my relief, my efforts paid off, and I succeeded in making her laugh and enjoy herself.  Since that day, we have been in a happy relationship, and I make it a point to say something quirky or random every day to bring a smile to her face. The Element of Joy and Laughter  Laughter is a crucial element in a person's life, especially during moments of joy and happiness. It serves as a powerful expression of appreciation and can uplift the spirits of not only the person laughing but also those around them. Different people react to laughter in various ways, influenced by their emotions and personalities. While some may find humor in jokes, others may laugh at mishaps or accidents. Emotions play a significant role in how individuals perceive and respond to laughter, with happiness often serving as a catalyst for joviality.  Jokes, in particular, have the ability to evoke laughter and create memorable moments. From simple puns to elaborate pranks, humor can bring people together and lighten the mood. However, the interpretation of jokes can vary widely among individuals, depending on their sense of humor and personal experiences. What one person finds hilarious, another may not, highlighting the subjective nature of humor.  Accidents, too, can sometimes elicit laughter, albeit in a more complex manner. While some may find amusement in unexpected mishaps, others may view them as unfortunate events. The perception of humor in such situations can vary greatly, underscoring the diverse ways in which people respond to laughter-inducing circumstances.  In essence, laughter is a valuable component of human interaction, fostering connections and spreading joy. By sharing moments of levity with others, individuals can cultivate a positive atmosphere and uplift spirits. So, embrace laughter, cherish the moments of joy, and remember to share a good laugh with friends and loved ones. Laughter truly is the best medicine for the soul.

Laughter can make a situation less uncomfortable, bring two people together, or just show you're having a good time. In my experiences, laughter comes at the best of times. On a typical day at school, I was sitting with my friends at lunchtime, just hanging out and talking about what's going on in our lives, when I noticed a girl sitting all alone. I don't recognize her; she must be a new student. Curious to meet someone new, I walk over to her and make conversation. After a little while, we relax and start to talk about our interests. I remember her saying something funny, and I started to laugh. She begins to laugh at my laugh, as it sounds almost hysterical, and everyone thinks it sounds ridiculous. At that moment, as we're sitting there laughing together, I realize it's bringing us closer despite the fact we had just met. Laughter makes life more enjoyable and happy, knowing that you can share that with someone you have just met or someone you have known your whole life. It's a universal language that everyone should speak. Laughing is healthy and good for the heart.

There was this time during our vacation when there was a lot of snow on the ground. My cousin, brother, and I were all getting together to go out to my grandparents' place for some snowmobiling and a few nights' stay. Despite the delay in getting out due to the late hour, we made the most of it by watching movies until morning. The next day, after a hearty breakfast, we finally ventured out to enjoy the snow. With my grandpa driving the snowmobile, us kids were in for an exhilarating ride, with me ending up looking like a snowman from all the snow flying around. It was a hilarious sight that my grandma couldn't resist capturing on camera. After a full day of snowmobiling, we headed back inside, where I thawed out in front of the heater while sipping on some delicious hot chocolate made by my grandma. It was a fun and memorable day, filled with laughter and unforgettable moments in the winter wonderland.

We were heading to our first ski race. On either side of me, my friends @CAPS1 and @PERSON1 sat, crammed together in our team van. Our packed bags and ski gear filled the vehicle to the top, along with six other kids, occupying all of the other empty spaces. Our uncomfortable seating arrangements didn't seem to ruin our fun, within five minutes of our road trip, the van exploded with laughter, as @PERSON1, most likely a future comedian started off cracking jokes, just being himself as usual. Within those first five minutes of our drive, I could already tell that this was going to be a ski trip I would always remember.   The van rolled up to the hotel parking lot. My ski team would be lodging here for the long weekend. The sky had turned black with the @TIME1, and me along with everyone else trudged along with weary eyes, exhausted from the long drive. We quickly unloaded our bags, all eager to hop into our beds, needing to be well rested for our first ski race of the season. Shortly after, everyone was soon in bed, knowing that five a.m. would be coming quickly. The sun began rising over the mountains, signaling time to wake up. This was not the case for me. I had been up for nearly an hour, and sat in our van while we sped around each corner up to the mountain. It was race day, and me, along with all of my teammates were all excited for the day coming.  The morning flew by, collecting our bibs at registration, getting our lift tickets, and inspection of the course. I now stood at the top of the hill peering down at the course ahead of me. I had to focus. While I have had a lot of fun, it was time to concentrate, to preform my absolute best. The pressure was on. I now stood in the start gate, my coach stood by my side, and my friends were watching as well, cheering me on. I was hoping not to disappoint. "@CAPS2 ready," the official began in a tense voice, "@CAPS3!" I threw my self our of the start gate. I flew by each gate, staying in control and most important, going fast. The wind slid past my aerodynamic body, my ankles and knees rolled with each turn. Everything was going well until I broke over the knoll. My body compressed bringing my knees to my chest, as I skied over the roller, throwing me off balance. I fought to get back up, to regain myself, but I couldn't do it. My skis spun out from under me, causing me to be spit out from the course, landing on my back, sliding down the mountain, hopeless and done for. It was over. I sat in the snow frustrated with my performance. I wanted a second chance that I wasn't going to get. @PERSON1, one of my teammates, came up to me and sat in the snow by my side. My first thought was he was going to say something of a cliche "nice job," or a "you'll do better next time". To my surprise he tells me one of his ridiculous jokes. My mouth turns up, trying to contain a laugh, unsuccessful, I burst into laughter. @PERSON1 sits there and smiles at me. Almost immediately I found myself in a better mood. I give him a quick "thanks," with a smile before we both @CAPS3 to watch and cheer on our teammates. Although I didn't do my best, I didn't let my results ruin my weekend. The next day, I skied two solid runs with top finishes, if I had stayed upset with myself, I would have never been able to achieve those results. I came to realize that some days, just a small laugh can be all you need to turn any day around. Laughter, I have found is essential in any situation. It's a connection that can bring anyone closer. For me, laughter changed my personality that day on the mountain. Laughter can mean many different things for many different people, laughter could be a special bond between to people. Laughter can remove the seriousness or competitively in a situation, but also it unites us. Languages are different among people, but everyone understands a what a laugh can do, a laugh is universal.

Living, laughter, love. To this day, I don't remember exactly why I was laughing. All I can remember, vividly, in my mind is the look on my grandfather's face. He had on the same smile he always wore during times of joy. It was a wide warm grin he would shine your way every so often. As I laughed uncontrollably that day, so many years ago, he shined his happiness and love down on me for so long that I will never forget a single wrinkle in his grin. My grandfather, who we all called "Pops," had a way of keeping the peace and happiness in everything. No matter how bad things were within our family, he would always make things right. No one could get angry at Pops, and no one could stay sad when he smiled. That's just the kind of guy he was. Pops was a big part of our family gatherings, just like the one we had on my birthday. That day was our family's last birthday celebration with Pops, soon after, he passed away. When I look back and realize how important that day was, I can see that it was a perfect day for everyone. It was a happy day and my earliest memories of my grandfather were of his great big happy grin shining down on me while I giggled away during a card game.  When that day kicked off, in the early morning, the weather was already proving to be spectacular. Every one in my family was in high spirits and was ready to enjoy the day as a family. My favorite activity during each and every family event is to play my favorite games with everyone. Our family has a few specific games that are a tradition during family gatherings. One of our favorites is called "Spades." Now "Spades" was one of the many games that my grandfather was very good at playing. He rarely ever lost a game, and would not finish playing until he had won at least once. So when everyone was assembled at our house, I convinced Pops and my cousin to play "Spades" with me. We went into the spare room and starting dealing out the cards. About a half an hour later we were still playing, and to no one's surprise, Pops was winning. It was just before the food was ready and we were about halfway through the game when either my cousin, or Pops said something to me that I thought was the funniest thing my tiny 5-year-old ears had ever heard, and I began to laugh.  My family was so thoroughly entertained by my laughter that they could not keep their smiles and laughter tucked away without bursting into giggles as bad as mine. It seemed that my senseless laughing created instant joy to my family, including my grandfather. Pops' smile was one of the greatest things my little eyes looked up at during my childhood. It was something so imaginary, yet so colorful and vivid in front of me, that I would worship his smile like I was seeing my first solar eclipse. I never quite understood, at such a young age what was so fascinating about his smile, but now I do understand. Pops' smile showed true, wholesome, unbreakable joy. His smile didn't come out all too often so when it did, you knew something good was happening.  No one knew that was our last birthday with Pops. I most certainly could not imagine it to be the day I would spend with my grandfather. Everything was so perfect and so increasingly happy, it seemed to be a crime to end his life during such a time of joy. Although if I were him, and if I had to choose my last day, that day would be perfect. My single memory of that day was laughing, and being happy. I can't think of any better way to spend my last bit of time with Pops than a day where we were both completely satisfied in our card game, laughter, and smiles.  Laughter is a funny thing. It is unique in every person, and can range from any kind of humor to pure happiness. Laughter brings hope in times of doubt and never fails to make someone smile. Someone, somewhere started a quote that says, "Live. Laugh. Love." I believe those three words can combine together, and act separately to sum up a perfect life for anyone willing to live out the true, meaningful definition of each of those words. Laughter brings smiles of happiness, humor, and love. Love brings us all together, and when we strive to be happy and to love, that is when we can truly live. My grandfather loved each and every one of his family and friends and made a priority of keeping them happy. He lived his life the best way that I believe anyone could ever live it. He died after a life full of love, happiness, and, most importantly, the very special gift of laughter.

Some people say that laughter is good for the soul, and that could be true, but the soul is definitely not the only thing. Laughing is great for your heart and mind too. It can improve relationships, make friendships grow stronger, and even start making two people who don't know anything about each other, extremely close. You can meet someone new or be with someone you barely know, and just because they make you laugh you feel like you want to get to know them better. I love that feeling. Honestly, you can laugh with any age or gender. You don't both have to be male and female, you could be with a little boy, an elderly lady, or anywhere in between and still have a lot of fun. Last year I never had anything to do, so I decided I should start volunteering places. The two places I could volunteer at were: a daycare next to my house, or an old folks home about 2 miles away. I thought really hard about it, trying to make the best decision for me. I couldn't make up my mind, and even though I didn't admit it, I felt like they would be just as boring as sitting at home. I finally decided I should do both of them, so I could meet some new people, and have new experiences. I started with the daycare. I woke up at 3 am, and walked to the daycare. I wasn't sure what it was going to be like at all. I didn't even know if I was good with kids. I walked in feeling awkward. The manager came up to me and asked me if I could help out with the 4-year-old's coloring room. I nodded my head nervously. Was I supposed to color for them? There's no way they could color a picture by themselves. They're only three! I thought. Oh well, if I follow directions then this day will go by faster. When I went in, all the kids ran up to me with a smile on their face. "Sit by me!" one said. "Color here!" said another. "There's a spot right here!" "Look at my picture!" "I drew a rainbow!" "I drew a car!" "I drew you!" With that, I looked down. There I was, on the piece of paper. A bunch of blue and green scribbles. That day was a lot of fun. I was laughing and having a great time with the kids. I learned that I absolutely adore kids, and I'm actually pretty good with them. The next week I went to the nursing home. I was even more nervous there. I felt so out of place. I hadn't found out what I was going to be helping with yet, so I sat in the lobby. When the receptionist asked who I was here to see, I said nobody. She then asked me why I was here, and I replied, oh, I was going to volunteer. She led me down the hall and told me that it was almost time for lunch so I needed to get ready to serve lunch. I did, and then I heard, what I assumed was, the lunch bell. I gave everyone their lunch with a big smile and it was honestly great. If one of them looked a little down, or upset I could flash them a smile and they would grin back, obviously in higher spirits than before. After lunch, I played a few games of chess. Most people who were there took naps after lunch, so there were only three people out there. I played first with a lady who used to be a nurse. I got to know her pretty well in the half-hour we played the game; which I won. Next was a guy who was a veteran. He fought in the Vietnam war. He seemed really nice, but serious. I won that game too. The last man used to be a comedian. He was so funny. He told jokes the whole game! Maybe he said a few too many, because he beat me at chess. Well, that was my excuse. When I got done, I was in a great mood and I couldn't wait to come back again. I learned a lot that day. I found out everyone is alike in some ways, even though each person is unique. I realized you don't have to be the same as the person you're with, to laugh and have a good time. It doesn't matter what age, race, gender, size, mentality, maturity, etc. The only thing that matters is that you are in the same place at the same time, trying to make the best of your day. I am so glad I decided to volunteer, otherwise I would have never known so much about people, love, life, and laughter. Laughing truly does bring people together, regardless of their differences.

As I reflect on my childhood, the memories of laughter and joy shared with my @CAPS1 continue to hold a special place in my heart. A few years ago, when I was younger, I decided to conduct an experiment on laughter and the colors of clothing people wear. I noticed that I was generally a happy person, laughed a lot, excelled in school, and had a positive attitude, mainly due to my bright and cheerful wardrobe. I hypothesized that individuals who laughed less and wore darker clothes would have a lower mood and attitude.   For a week, I attempted to limit my laughter and gradually transitioned from bright colors to darker shades in my clothing choices. It was challenging to find dark clothes that I liked, as I was accustomed to vibrant colors. As the experiment progressed, I received curious looks from classmates and concerned inquiries from teachers about my unusual behavior. Despite feeling a bit off, I continued with the experiment.  Towards the end of the week, my demeanor noticeably changed, and even my family noticed a difference in my energy levels. I struggled to find joy in everyday interactions and even lashed out at friends, which was uncharacteristic of me. However, when I reintroduced bright colors into my outfit on the final day, I didn't feel any significant shift in my mood.  In my conclusion to the class, I shared that my hypothesis was partially correct. Laughter did have a significant impact on my mood and attitude, but the color of clothing did not seem to influence it. As my teacher cracked a joke, I couldn't help but burst into laughter, signaling a return to my usual cheerful self. It felt liberating to laugh freely once again, reinforcing the power of positivity and joy in our lives.

Laughing is truly a powerful tool that can bring people together and strengthen relationships. So, let's remember to laugh more, to spread happiness, and to nurture our relationships through the power of laughter.
