A few years back, my dad and I were watching TV at home when my little sister's friend accidentally ran into a sliding glass door, leaving a slobber mark on it. We couldn't stop laughing at the situation. Later, my brother scared our cat, causing it to jump in the air, leading to more laughter. In the garage, we found an electrical starter and ended up shocking ourselves for amusement. Despite the broken starter and giving away the cat, these funny memories will always bring a smile to our faces.

A laughter is a wondrous gift. It allows your mind and your body to conjoin with others. It is the root of happiness, and brings a sense of sanity to those who have lost hope. When you feel alone in the world with no one at your side, laughter will be there to accompany you. At one point in my life I felt confused and by myself. I was empty. Solitude was the only thing I could have, and the only feeling my mind would register. Just when I had thought that I might be the only person in the whole world, something had come to save me.  I was six years old when they got divorced. I couldn't stand to hear my parents fight. One day we were the perfect family. We would play board games and go to the movies together. Something had changed very quickly. My father grabbed his jacket, told me he loved me and then he was gone. Was I ever going to see him again? Why isn't he living with us? These are questions I kept asking myself. I think i was too young to truly know what was going on. The days were long and I found myself becoming sluggish and glum.  About two weeks after my father had left, some neighbors moved into the house adjacent to me and my mom. One of the neighbors looked young, about my age. I didn't think much of the new people in town. I told myself that people come and go. Nothing lasts forever, and I should expect the worst. One day I was riding my bike and thought that I should stop pedaling and crash into my fence. I hit the metal fence and simply fell over. I heard a laugh and turned around. It was the new neighbor kid. There he was rolling on the ground, grabbing at his sides. He must have thought of my crash as entertainment. I picked up my bike, began to move, then crashed once more. Another series of laughs sprang from this boy. That was the first time I had smiled in a long time. I grew fond of whatever feeling or humor I was giving off to this new kid. I asked the boy his name and he didn't respond; though he did start to laugh again. It was my voice that he was laughing at. Everything I did caused him to become hysterical. I found out later that he was from Mexico and didn't speak a word of English. Over the course of a month or so, I felt the hole in my heart begin to fill. My new companion and his laugh was the start to my new beginning. My mom and I eventually moved out of our house and lost contact with the neighbors. I am always reminded of him when I hear a laugh. Though he's not near me in a physical sense, I am guided by his laughter every day.

Laughter is indeed a powerful medicine that can help lift spirits and bring joy in difficult times. In a recent experience with my mother after her surgery, a simple word-search activity turned into a hilarious moment filled with laughter. As we navigated through the puzzles, making silly comments and jokes along the way, we found ourselves laughing uncontrollably. Even simple misunderstandings or mispronunciations brought tears of laughter to our eyes. These moments of shared laughter not only helped us forget about the pain and discomfort but also created a stronger bond between us. In the end, I am reminded once again that laughter truly is the best medicine, capable of healing not just the body but also the soul.

One day after school, my friends @CAPS1, @CAPS2, and @CAPS3 came over to my house and convinced me to put on clothes that I could get dirty in. After getting rinsed off, we all headed inside, still laughing about our muddy adventure.

Human beings are indeed strange creatures. We constantly seek validation and acceptance from others, yet struggle to truly accept ourselves. Building relationships is a risky endeavor, as we give others the power to either uplift us or tear us down. However, there are key qualities that can help us identify true "builders" in our lives - trust and kindness. While kindness may not always lead to immediate friendships, laughter is a universal language that can instantly connect us with others. In a classroom setting, laughter played a crucial role in fostering unity and breaking down barriers between classmates. Through shared moments of joy and amusement, individuals who were once perceived as annoyances became cherished members of a newfound "family." It is remarkable how something as simple as laughter can transform our perceptions of others and ourselves, highlighting the power of humor in building strong relationships and fostering a sense of community.

Despite initial anger, laughter eventually brought everyone closer. However, a prank at a party involving pulling down someone's bikini went too far, causing temporary tension. Ultimately, the experience helped solidify the bond between friends, showing the importance of laughter in strengthening relationships. Laughter truly plays a significant role in creating positive connections between people, making it an essential aspect of life.

Laughter is a key ingredient in a fulfilling and successful life, as it helps us navigate through challenges and find light in the darkest of times. Being in a relationship can be both fun and challenging. It is important to have trust in each other to build a strong bond. Trust allows you to confide in the other person and feel secure in the relationship. Having good friends who support you and have your back is also crucial. They can help you navigate through difficult situations and enjoy fun times together. Ultimately, being with people who bring joy to your life and make you feel happy is essential for a fulfilling and enjoyable relationship. So, cherish the relationships you have and make the most out of them by creating lasting memories and sharing experiences together.

Everyone laughs differently, some people laugh so hard that they cry, and some don't. But one thing that they have in common is laughter. People use laughter as a way to express their feelings of joy, happiness, or if something is just really funny to them. Laughing is a great way to feel happier about something. Having a good sense of humor can help you get through tough situations, embarrassing things, or just a bad day.  Laughing at yourself and embarrassing moments can help you get over them and not be so embarrassed. Whenever I laugh, I always feel better. Laughing reminds me of all the good things in life, like spending time with friends and family, and all the inside jokes we share.  Some of my best memories involve laughter with my friends, like the time we went to @ORGANIZATION1 before high school started. The car ride was filled with laughter and singing. We even did a fire drill around the car when we got stuck in construction. We made boring moments fun and memorable.  Exploring @ORGANIZATION1 on bikes, we laughed, told jokes, and talked about our excitement for high school. Floating down the river on rafts, we splashed each other and laughed the whole way. Even strangers passing by could see how much fun we were having.  Back at home, we enjoyed a meal together, unable to keep straight faces. Our friendship was evident in how we could just look at each other and laugh, sharing inside jokes and special moments. Laughter truly brings people together and creates lasting memories.

Laughter can indeed play a significant role in building and strengthening relationships. It has the power to uplift spirits, create a sense of connection, and bring joy to those involved. Making someone laugh can break down barriers and help people feel more comfortable with each other. It can also be a powerful tool in diffusing tense situations and turning negative emotions into positive ones. Laughter truly has the ability to bring people closer together and foster a sense of camaraderie. So, next time you find yourself in the company of others, remember the power of laughter in bridging the gap between two people.

Each person filed in, one after the other, making a human train. The metallic red bell chimed once as each person pushed the door slightly more open. Walking in, I was enveloped by the smell of Chinese food and conversations that hummed in my ears. I took a few steps forward and stopped, not knowing where to go. To the right was a wall covered in Chinese symbols and meanings, while to the left were hundreds of tables already filled. Not knowing where to take my place, I turned to my mom. I so badly wanted to plop myself down at one of the adult tables, even if it meant I had to sit there silently. With moms knowing what's best, she shoved me towards the back of the restaurant, telling me to go sit with my cousins. I did as she told me, like always, but made my reluctance clear. Walking over to the table with the speed of a slug and my feet dragging on the floor, I awkwardly stood in front of the circular table. Yanking out one of the chairs, I turned to my mom with a pleading look as desperation filled every fiber of my body, for I knew there was no way she would give in. Staring at these six relatives, I didn't know how I could manage to sit here the rest of the evening. We had all gathered at a Chinese restaurant for my grandpa's 80th birthday. Each of his children had flown from the mainland to Hawaii in order to spend this special moment with him. I hadn't seen these cousins for over two years, and some much longer. I had already visited with them since we'd been in Hawaii, but I hadn't talked to them much, none the less when we were all together and forced to mingle. With my napkin on my lap, I sat and looked at my cousins, each one staring back at me like I was an animal at the zoo. After a moment or two, they seemed to forget I was there because they averted their gaze and began talking amongst themselves. The only person at the table who I didn't feel like a complete stranger towards was my cousin, Sarah. She had wavy brown hair with blindingly blond highlights, sun-kissed from those bright tropical days, along with that brown tanned skin that made me jealous. We began talking, and soon I found myself enjoying the moment. It wasn't until the food came that we actually began interacting as a group. Being teenagers with bland palates, everyone stared as the waiter brought the first dish. After asking the friendly waitress what it was we were about to eat, from her broken English we deciphered that they were buns with duck inside. Frantically trying to get all of the tables served in fairly constant intervals, she left our table and all of us looked at our food blankly. No one wanted to take the first bite. One of my cousins, Michael, stepped up to take the masculine role as the dare devil. We all waited tentatively as he chomped down on the moist bun and swallowed. Once done chewing, he smiled and it seemed this dish had won his approval. Digging into my buns, I began to wonder if maybe these people were easy to relate to and I had made a small thing into a big ordea. From then on, I would just be myself and stop worrying about not having seen anybody for years; All I needed was to be myself. The way the courses were set up left plenty of time to chat between each plate they brought. Since I was no longer worrying about what to say or how to say it, I easily fit into the conversations and began to relax. Shortly after the duck tray was removed from the table, it was discovered that my cousin Michael, who is from Boston, pronounces certain words with an accent. Soon everybody began comparing the way we pronounce things to the way that he does. After each difference we found, we would chuckle. Things carried on like that for the rest of the evening, everyone laughing at things that were only moderately funny, but we found hilarious. It was that evening when I realized, even though you may be uncomfortable around a group of people who you don't know very well, finding a common ground helps you to ease that discomfort. Finding something that you all enjoy talking about may be hard to do, but finding something that makes you laugh is a lot easier. Laughter is something that everyone enjoys and can take part in even if they're not contributing to the conversation. By feeling as though you're a part of what's going on, you feel accepted, and that's all anyone ever wants.

People say laughter is the shortest distance between two people. A concept I saw to be true was when I met a girl named Sarah. Three years ago I was at a city park swinging, wondering if it would hurt if I jumped. I took a few chances and let go of the swing chains, flying through the air, feeling the unbalanced sensation of falling in my chest. As I hit the ground and struggled to get up, I felt hands on my shoulder and arm. Looking up, I saw a girl - not just any girl, but a gorgeous one. She had green dazzling eyes, flowing hair, and soft, gentle skin.  "Hi," I managed to say. "Are you okay?"  "I'm fine, just forgot to stick the landing. Thanks for helping me. Um, what's your name?" I asked.  "Sarah, and you're welcome. What's your name?" she replied with a giggle. We decided to walk around together, stopping at a monkey dome where we asked each other random questions. I learned that Sarah was 12 years old, loved baby blue, and aspired to be a doctor. During our stroll, we shared past memories and personal stories. At one point, she suddenly asked why she felt so happy with me.  "Well, it could be my charm or just making you laugh," I joked.  "It's definitely the laughter," she said between laughs. As a car horn interrupted us, we exchanged goodbyes, knowing we might not see each other again as my family was moving to a new town. Walking back home for the last night in the city, my thoughts lingered on Sarah and how laughter had paved the way to our friendship.

When a day is qualified as perfect there are a lot of things that go into making it so. Most perfect days in people's teenage years are in the summer beyond the stress of school. My perfect day wasn't in the summer, nor was it on a crazy spring break in Cancun. My perfect day was on a fall day in the middle of October in my freshman year of college. It was on this perfect day that my friendship with my roommate was founded. A friendship that is now the best one of all. A friendship that is based on fun times, memories, story-telling, and laughter. By the end of October, I had spent multiple weekends with my roommate. However, none were as memorable as that weekend in late October. We decided we needed a break from studying and with that said, we set off for a nearby hiking trail. Arriving at the trail was peculiar because I was so far out of my comfort zone. It was also peculiar because I hadn't met a single soul my roommate was about to introduce me to. When I first laid my eyes on her friends, I couldn't fathom how my roommate had met them. She is artistic, creative, outgoing, and adventurous. The friends that shook my hand were into things like painting, photography, and poetry. I didn't think upon first meeting them that opposites could attract or become fond of one another. As the day progressed I found my comfort zone again. As the hours flew by and jokes and laughs were exchanged, I realized just how similar we all really were. I didn't think that all of the silly things we did that October day would matter to me months down the road, but they do. When we were taking pictures in the colorful leaves with silly poses and laughing so hard we cried, I realized just how perfect the situation was. If that day wouldn't have brought smiles to my lips and my mind to its comfort zone, it would have been a day long forgotten. If you go back on every happy memory you have, there is always one common ground. A joke, or even a funny face makes you laugh extremely hard. Every time I walk by that hiking trail I think about the day when the sun was shining and we sat on the rocks exchanging laughs. I think about my roommate and I running through the forest laughing and tripping over our own feet. I think about her friends laughing and pointing as we attempted to climb a tree. After all of the fun activities we were quite wound up. They suggested we take a walk; so we accepted and off we went into the woods. Within five minutes of our departure, we stopped walking. Our walk had put us on a hill covered in fallen leaves. I'm not sure what events lead up to my roommate pushing her friend down the hill. However, I remember her friend pulling another friend down with her. I also recall the others sliding down to join the fun. Watching them play and roll down the hill of leaves was something like watching a scene from a movie. Nobody was on their phones or distracted by technology. Around us was laughter and peace which enveloped us like music. The day had no stress and it had the perfect amount of sunshine. It was like something out of a dream. Once you are in a moment like that, where your own little world is pulling you closer, you never want to leave it. When you're on a laughter high, you disconnect yourself and for a few brief seconds, your life is in its simplest form. You are just you, no racing thoughts, no overwhelming emotions. You are just one person. I never thought that something as simple as laughs could create or strengthen a friendship. On that October day I realized that the laughs shared between my roommate and I would be the first memory of many to come. Every event and every laugh that we had that day will be something I think about when I'm feeling doubtful about the world. It will always be a memory that makes me grateful for being alive. Someone once said, "Laughter is the shortest distance between two people." On that October day, I wouldn't have believed it, but laughing made me closer with people I would have otherwise overlooked. Laughter and smiles connected my world to my roommate and to the world of her friends. And as of today, that has made all the difference.

Moving to a new place can be a daunting experience, especially when leaving behind familiar faces and surroundings. The thought of never seeing friends and family again can be overwhelming, and the prospect of starting over in a completely different location can be unsettling. The journey to @ORGANIZATION1 was long and tiring, and the initial impression of the new surroundings was less than welcoming. The apartment complex seemed old and overcrowded, and the constant rain only added to the dreariness of the situation. However, amidst the initial discomfort and sense of isolation, a ray of hope emerged in the form of unexpected friendship. Despite feeling out of place and alone, a simple joke sparked laughter and camaraderie with a group of boys in school. In that moment, the sense of alienation began to dissipate, and a new sense of belonging started to take root. It was a reminder that connections can be found in the most unexpected places, and that even in the face of uncertainty, friendship and laughter can pave the way for a brighter future.

Laughter at its finest. Laughter is one ability that everyone in the world has. Not only does it help you make more friends, but it can also turn your day all the way around. The capability to laugh is of huge importance in this world. Without laughter, days would be dull, sad, and somewhat depressing. When I see someone laugh, it brightens my day, makes me smile, and causes me to laugh along with them. By laughing we become happier, learn more about others, and make our bad days better. I have experienced, first hand, the joys laughing can bring after I have had a bad moment, and that is why I believe that laughter is extremely important to have and to keep in your life. Not everyone can have a great day all the time. Bad days occur, and when they do, seeing one funny incident and laughing about it is what can turn the whole day around and make it great. Many people hear the statement, "Laughter is the shortest distance between two people," or a statement similar to that one and will never agree with it. Often times we will scoff and disagree completely. It turns out that I used to be one of those people myself. Most days were not the best they could be, plus having to go to school all day long ruined it a little more. People kept telling me that if I laughed once in a while then I might feel better more often, and I never actually have fun when I participated throughout the day. I never believed them, and why should I? How could one action as simple as laughing change the way I feel about everyday life? The possibilities were just too unlikely. I didn't think I'd change my views on it either, until a few years ago. It started off like any usual day would, not so great. My hair was a mess, my sister and I could not stop fighting, and my brand new phone broke right as we started our shopping trip to the mall. I had decided that the day was going to be horrible because so far, nothing had worked out well. As the day went on, nothing worse happened, but nothing better did either. My sister and I kept traveling around, going to stores, and shopping. Finally, at our last stop we saw a situation occur. As we were sitting at a stop light, waiting for traffic to move, I spotted a strange man sitting across the road all by himself. The man looked as though he had an injury on his foot, and our suspicions were confirmed when he began walking like a hurt penguin would, barely shuffling his feet and bobbing up and down as he moved forward. The sight of this man made me smile, and when I pointed him out to my sister she started laughing uncontrollably. Then I too, began cracking up. The man with his crazy way of walking had made me laugh had proceeded to turn my entire day around. What I thought was impossible turned out to be the exact opposite, possible. Laughing could bring you closer to others and make your day more amazing. As a result of my trip with my sister that day, my views and beliefs about laughing were changed greatly. Laughter actually was the shortest distance between two people. Even though my little sister and I were arguing before the funny man came, after we were done laughing about him we realized that in the span of a few minutes we had become closer than ever before. It is crazy to think that one incident can change your mind about some of your strong beliefs, but it happened, and that day is now a memory that I am going to keep with me forever. I'm happy it happened because as a result of it I have begun to think differently about laughter and the effect it can have on certain situations in my life. I now think of laughter as one of the greatest pastimes to have and do it quite often.

Outdoor education is a valuable experience for students to learn and explore the natural world. In sixth grade, I had the opportunity to attend an outdoor education trip. I remember waking up early and heading to the meeting point where the bus would take us to the outdoor education center. After boarding the bus, we were assigned to cabins, and I was placed in a cabin with seven other students.  I had brought my electronic device with me, but the teachers informed us that we were not allowed to use any devices during the trip. The following day, we engaged in various activities, starting with a delicious lunch of pizza, pizza pockets, and hot dogs. One of the activities involved catching fish and examining them before releasing them back into the water. We also went on a hike through the mountains, where we were fortunate enough to spot some deer grazing peacefully.  After a tiring but fulfilling day, we prepared to head back home. Despite the exhaustion, I felt a sense of accomplishment and enjoyment from participating in the outdoor activities. Outdoor education not only provides students with a break from their daily routines but also offers valuable lessons about nature and teamwork. I am grateful for the opportunity to have been a part of this memorable field trip.

The laughter of my family is a precious aspect of our lives. Whether we are sharing breakfast, lunch, or dinner, we always find joy in each other's company. During breakfast on the morning of @DATE2, my sister recounted a hilarious incident from her workplace involving a banana and her manager slipping. The image of her boss falling was so comical that we couldn't help but burst into laughter. Later, during lunch at school, my mom shared a funny story about our dog running around frantically after a shower, which had me laughing uncontrollably. Even my brother had a humorous tale to tell during dinner, about walking out of the bathroom with toilet paper stuck to his pants. We both thought the way our other friend, the diva that she is, was reluctant to get wet was preposterous. So, naturally, we pushed her in numerous times. These are the things that make our relationship so special. We can be serious for each other when needed, and no one will disrespect my friends and get away with it, but when we are together, I can let my guard down and can be myself. My goofy, irrational, apparently hilarious self, and still have fun. Our laughter can even change how a situation is going to progress. For example, after we were done on the river, we all went to a local park for an afternoon of music and food. We all got enormous ice cream cones, the best money can buy. My friends had already finished theirs, and were playing with "Wilson" a few yards away. I was just about to take another heavenly lick of my waffle cone when the beach ball flies over and knocks all the ice cream right out of my cone! I was left with a completely intact cone, but all of the good stuff was on the ground. Needless to say, I was devastated. Who knows what would have happened if we hadn't started laughing. Maybe I would have teared up, or sulked for an hour or two. However, my face was just so comical, staring in disbelief at the empty cone, that they just couldn't help but laugh. They fell on the grass, in hysterics. Even through my disappointment I started cracking up as well, and then everything seemed okay. Laughter is the shortest distance between two people, or three in my case. My two best friends make me laugh like no other people I have ever met, and I suspect I will never meet anyone else that makes me feel as they do. This laughter we have makes us feel better. It helps us relax and let our guard down, so the times after we laugh together is often when we confide in each other the most. If one of us is feeling down, or is under the weather, laughter is the sure fire way to get them back on their feet and smiling. Even simply being with them makes me feel more exuberant, lets me abandon my troubles. This is why laughter is so important to the the three of us. Whenever we laugh, our relationship builds. It is the good times we have had that help us through the bad times, and I know that our good times wouldn't have been so good were it not for the way we can laugh together.

The @CAPS1 of Laughter  Many people think it is love that brings people together. But love is something that develops over time and brings people closer in the long run. Before you've ever loved someone though, you've laughed with them. Laughter creates conversation, mends relationships, and brings joy to people. Its an important part of any relationship and has certainly helped me make friends.  In the kindergarten, everything was new to me. I got to leave my house, go to school, eat lunch, and go to recess. There were many children just like me, bouncing with excitement as our daily routine started. Although we played together at school, at home there was no one around to play with.  One day after school, I noticed a boy walking around next to my yard. I walked over and remembered him from that school day in my classroom. "@CAPS2", was all I said. He turned around, and with all his might, burped as loud as he could. We fell into a fit of laughter and I knew I'd made a new friend that day. From then on, him and I were best friends. Any adventure that happened after school always ended with us laughing about something. There was no need for our parents to set up any "playdates" or scheduled time to meet other children because it was easier to laugh at something and make a friend naturally, not awkwardly while the parents chatted. From then on, making friends was a piece of cake.  Through grade school and well into my teenage years, I had a best friend and a lot more friends, solely, because of a moment of laughter. Laughing is something that can always "break the ice". Whenever you meet someone new, it's always kind of hard to just talk to them. You don't know whether to be serious, outgoing, funny, or quiet. But if something happens that makes both of you laugh, then it becomes easier to communicate because that laughter eases some of the tension in between. It's like riding a bike, after the initial awkwardness, things just get easier and easier.  For many, laughter helps heal pain. Tragic things happen in every person's life and it can be hard to deal with at times. Whether it's a breakup, a depressive mood, or maybe even a death of a loved one, something funny and a laugh can help them get their mind off of whatever is bothering them. Most of them time that's all a person wants, something to help them forget whatever troubles them, if only for a few minutes. It's how people build better relationships, they do whatever they can for each other to make each other feel better.  Besides its healing and conversation starting qualities, laughing is simply fun to do. It can start out as a small giggle, turn into a chuckle, and end up as a fifteen minute session of raging, side cramping laughter. And most of the time, you're with friends so they're enjoying the moment of fun and happiness right along with you.  If you've never laughed once in your life, there's something wrong. It will eliminate awkward moments, relieve painful thoughts or feelings, and create instant fun. Just try it, it's not that hard. I guarantee that it will bring you closer to someone, make life less stressful, and make you happy.

When I was younger, my sister and I would constantly fight, whether it be verbally or physically. Our arguments would drag on for hours, causing tension within our family. With only a few months between us, the rivalry seemed to intensify. My mom tried various tactics to make us stop, from grounding us to giving us extra chores. However, the most effective method was making us sit face to face, holding hands in a criss-cross applesauce position. Despite initially hating this, the forced closeness would often lead to laughter, helping us forget our disagreements. This laughter brought us closer together, allowing us to move past our fights with a hug and a renewed bond.

Life is so uncertain, unfair, and unforgiving, but one simple thing can change that view on the cruelty of the world; laughter. In your deepest concern in your darkest thoughts laughter can bring the sun. Laughter is a cure for the sick, a pill for the wounded, and comfort for the old. We give not even the slightest thought to laughing, when in return it gives us joy and happiness. Laughter is the light at the end of the tunnel, a flashlight for the lost, and a lifeline for the hopeless. Laughter truly is the cure for all of humanity. Explaining laughter is like explaining why we breath, we just do, it's a part of living. It's natural for people to laugh, maybe not always appropriate, but it's something we revert back to in necessary times. Laughing makes dreams, hopes, and puts to rest the thoughts of uncertainty. Laughing is a friend, a helper, and an icebreaker to many leaving joy and hope to everyone that it meets. It's part of life we must cherish every moment we can.  Many times laughter has helped me, but one time sticks out more then the rest. A moment, a simple moment were laughter changed me, my views, and life itself; putting my life into motion. With shoulders slumped I listened to my six period teacher as she droned on about nothing important. I turned around hoping to find something to distract me. When I turned I met eyes with a man I had never had spoken to, he watched me with curiosity waiting for my explanation. I wanted, no, needed to talk to him so I took a chance. "@CAPS1 you watched wrestling?" he smiled and chuckled.without that the conversation would @CAPS1 been totally different. He could @CAPS1 ignored me, but he laughed and that altered the course of my life. Soon after that, that man became my boyfriend, because we talked after I asked him that. That laugh made everything so simple, it made the puzzle fall into place. Moments @CAPS1 arise when laughing has dug me a pit of ruins. Even though laughing is such a wonderful thing you still need to be careful and know when the right time to laugh is and when its not. Again a moment that sticks to me was a time when I was young. I played by myself for the most part picking up a barbie I brushed her hair,"@CAPS2 come here." I heard my father call.I went to the living room where my brother already reside and waited with my barbie. My father kneel to talk,"@CAPS3 going to be leaving soon because she needs sometime. I want you to go with her and make sure everything is okay. I want you to stay with her and I'll see you when I can. I love you @CAPS2 always remember that." I bubbled with laughter, I didn't realize or even comprehend what was really going on. I laughed as we got into the car, by the time we were gone i realized how serious this issue was. Maybe I didn't hurt anyone by laughing, but it hurt me for not taking it so serious.  Life is never know, we never know where life will take us, lead us, kick us, or drop us. Laughter is an emotion and can cure the wounds, but its also a power we must not mistreat or misuse. Giving us joy and fun, it helps pick us up when we fall and it rejoices us. Laughter is a way of life and the savior of humanity. Laughter truly is a gift that keeps on giving, a light in the darkest of times, and a beacon of hope for all. Cherish the moments of laughter, for they hold the power to transform lives and bring about positive change in the world.

Laughter is a contagious disease that should be included in everyone's life as they grow up. It plays a key role in creating memorable moments and strengthening relationships. For me, my family has five days dedicated to laughter throughout the year: birthdays, Easter, Independence Day, Halloween, and Christmas. These days are filled with fun activities, games, and shared laughter that create lasting memories. From playing laser tag on Independence Day to trick-or-treating on Halloween, each celebration is marked by joy and laughter. These moments of laughter not only bring us closer together but also help us relax and enjoy life. As my grandparents used to say, "A laugh a day will keep the doctor away." Laughter truly is the best medicine for the soul.

Many summers ago, @CAPS1 best friend @PERSON1 and I had a sleepover at @CAPS1 house. We were both excited because @CAPS1 dad would be the only one there. @CAPS1 mom and brother were out late. After eating popcorn and getting stuffed up on candy, we decided to try something new and fun. @CAPS1 house has a counter bar where four to five people can sit at and so @CAPS1 daddy decided to turn on some hip hop music. As though @PERSON1 and I could read each others minds we jumped on the counter and started doing the runway model walk. We worked it like no other. It was funny to see @CAPS1 dad pretending to be the fake photographer and say that's "gorgeous" as though he was a real photographer. @PERSON1 and I strutted up and down and did stops and poses and turns, until we got too dizzy. We all knew we could never do this with @CAPS1 mom @ORGANIZATION1 which made everything so funny! We all bursted out laughing until we couldn't breathe! Later on after that fun model runway, we decided to pillow surf down the stairs. I was a little afraid at first but after I saw the look on @PERSON1's face, I knew I had to do it. I grabbed a big body pillow and surfed down those stairs like a champ! It was such a blast! @PERSON1 and I kept pillow fighting for what seemed like forever! @CAPS1 dad put on @ORGANIZATION1 and we laughed the rest of the night away. That night was one of the best and funniest memories of @CAPS1 childhood.

In my opinion, I think that laughter is a very important part of life. What would the world be like without laughter and jokes? It would be a very boring and dull place. I can't even imagine what it would be like. The world needs to have laughter in it. People need to make jokes and they need to have laughter and comedy in their life. I myself have a lot of laughter in my life. One day in fifth grade my best friend and I were jogging around the track for gym class. We were running together and talking and telling jokes to each other to help pass the time because it was really boring. I told this one really awesome joke, I can't remember what it was, and he started laughing so hard. We were both laughing together to the point we were crying. He fell down on the track, and rolled off into the grass. I said "@CAPS1 on we need to keep going or the gym teacher will get mad". He said, "I can't, I just peed my pants!." That made me laugh even more. He got up and walked over to the gym teacher. The gym teacher told my friend to go to the nurse's office. After gym class was over I met him back up with him in the classroom and he told me he called his mom and she brought him a new pair of underwear and pants. I wonder what his mom must have thought. It was a funny day.  We have always talked about that day together from then on. I would always jokingly make fun of him for peeing his pants, but I told him a funny joke. Our whole relationship was based on making each other laugh and telling jokes. Just all around the two of us being stupid together was what we did. Jokes and laughter made our friendship so much better and gave me amazing memories that I might possibly have for the rest of my life. At the same time, if you have no jokes and laughter in your friendship, it can make your relationship very boring and lame. If you do not have any, or little laughter in your friendship, then you do not have fun with that person and it makes you not want to hang around them because it just feels boring.  I have this other friend named @CAPS2, I occasionally go over to his house and we hang out and play video games together. The weird thing is, we hardly even communicate with each other. We just do stuff and don't have any fun with it. There is no jokes or laughter or anything awesome like that. We just play his video games silently not saying a word to the other person. Its the most pathetic thing I have ever seen. It is the most boring friendship two people could have. It is really boring over there because we just do the same thing over and over. I don't really like going over there that much. I would rather be at a different friends house having fun, but I still go over there anyway and I am not sure why. Without jokes and laughter in a friendship, it just makes things boring and not fun. It is something you definitely need to have. Laughter is not just an important element in a friendship, it is also an important element to have in a dating relationship. If you are dating somebody, then you absolutely need to have laughter in your relationship. If you look around you always see couples making jokes together and laughing with each other all the time, having fun. It makes their relationship interesting and enjoyable. Think about it, who wants to date a boring person that doesn't like to laugh and make jokes? Nobody wants to. So in a dating relationship you especially need laughter and comedy more than in a friendship. You want to keep things going good so the other person likes you and thinks your funny. That is one of the key things that makes a couple close. So as you can see by my three examples, laughter really makes a big difference in relationships and just in life in general. If you have laughter in a friendship it can really impact the relationship in a very good way. It makes it an interesting and fun relationship. Laughter makes people happy and get along with each other. If you are feeling down, laughter can always bring you up and make you feel better. It is almost like a medicine. If you do not have laughter, it can really make things suck, and make the relationship boring. Nobody wants that. People do not want a boring, lifeless relationship with somebody. Laughter is something that bring people together in a good way. It brings all of my friends together and makes us better friends. We have a good time and really enjoy ourselves. Laughter is a great thing that everybody needs to have in their life.

From Laughter to Friendship, the first day of school last year, I walked through the doors of the school hoping I would make a friend or two. I was not sure of how this would happen but I hoped for the best. I entered my first class and sat at a table with all unknown faces. I wanted to say something but was afraid of their reactions. The teacher made us play a couple games where we had to introduce ourselves. Those didn't really help. Everybody was tense and it was all awkward. I wanted to be myself already and make friends. For the rest of the day, all my classes were like that. Everybody was tense and awkward, like something was keeping us quiet. Not knowing anybody didn't help the situation a bit. That was the first day for me. The second day I walk through the school doors determined to make some friends. I thought about what jokes I could say, what interesting thing about myself I could share, but to me all those sounded like stupid ideas. I walk into humanities and sat at a table with a friendly looking girl. The teacher told us to introduce ourselves to the other students at the table we were sitting at. For a minute or so it was very silent, but I wanted to introduce myself so bad. I couldn't stand this silence any longer. I looked in my backpack to grab a pencil and I see a note from my mom saying "Be yourself and make some friends honey, have a great day at school. :)" I started laughing because I thought it was funny that my mom actually wrote me a note and stuck it in my backpack. It was so unexpected and I felt like a child. I started laughing and when I looked up, I saw that the girl next to me was laughing too. I knew I had to say something, so I did. I said, "Hi my name is [Person1], but you can call me [CAPS4] for short. What's your name?" The girl looked at me, smiled, and said, "Hi, my name is [CAPS8]." Then I asked her what middle school she came from and other questions. We started talking, we exchanged numbers, and we became good friends. From laughter to friendship, who would have known? A year has gone by and we are still friends. We always laugh about how we started talking. A few days ago I told her how I felt that second day of school. I told her I was scared to introduce myself. She said she felt the same way and she didn't know what to do either. Since then I thank my mom for writing that note because without it I wouldn't have laughed and made [CAPS8] laugh and I wouldn't have made such a great friend.

It's the first day of high school and your gut is full of butterflies that make you want to run to the bathrooms and hide from the world. I had no friends yet and I was too shy to go and join any of the groups so I walked to all of my classes alone. Students would get in my face wanting to know what school I came from and wanted to know all about me. I remember wanting to be left alone, hidden in my own bubble space. Girls would ask if I was upset since I wasn't smiling or having fun getting to know my new classes. Lunch was much more crowded than my old school. Students would sit in hallways eating their lunch or crowd around one big table chattering loudly to one another. I chewed on my lip looking for a spot that wasn't occupied by students. I found a table near the front of the lunch room that was empty and placed my brown lunch sack in front of me eating my peanut butter and jelly sandwich. Two boys and two girls rushed over and settled down next to me laughing at one another for not getting a seat next to me. "Hi, I'm Grace, what's your name?" was a skinny boy in a black cap's response to me. "Sarah" was all I replied to all of them who stared at me the entire time. "That's a pretty name, I'm Emily, this is Jake, you just met Grace, and Ben is the funny kid next to you with his orange backpack," I smiled and nodded to them. They all ate lunch at the school and got pizza or sub sandwiches. They showed pictures of funny events on their phones to everyone even including me. "Sarah, that kid isn't careful he might get razor rash," I said laughing a little looking at the picture of a little boy sliding down a slide that looked like a cheese grater. Grace took off all his pepperoni and was flinging it randomly in the air. Emily was going to take a picture of everyone for picture id on her phone. Ben was next for his picture to be taken when the pepperoni in Jake's hands slipped and landed smack on Ms. Thompson's face. I busted up laughing and everyone at the table joined in. Ben and I were clenching our stomachs and wiping away tears. Jake went to the bathroom to wash away the smell from his face and when he returned Emily said, "Oh my word you should see your face I took your picture right after the pepperoni hit your face and your picture is just hilarious, your mouth is hanging open like you're going to eat something and like you're angry." Emily handed her phone to one person at a time and we all started to laugh again asking for Emily to send the picture to each of them. "I was wondering if I could be your guys' friend?" I asked looking them all in the eye. Grace was the only one to respond, "Of course you can be our friend, Sarah, duh, we didn't want to be your friend then we wouldn't be hanging out with you." Grace teased. My twisted gut loosened with relief. "Yeah, we probably would have made some excuse to leave," Jake smiled. I laughed at myself for worrying that I wouldn't fit in or have friends who could make me laugh as hard as I did when the pepperoni stuck to Ms. Thompson's face.

Laughter is a powerful tool that can bring people together and help them feel more at ease with each other. It can turn strangers into friends and create strong bonds between individuals. Sharing a laugh can lighten the mood and make even difficult situations seem more manageable. Through laughter, people can find common ground and build connections that last a lifetime. So, next time you have the opportunity to share a laugh with someone, take it - you never know where it might lead.

Laughter is one of the most important things in life. People shouldn't go a day without it. It's healthy and good in any relationship. It can also help with healing. The best kind of laughter is when you're out of breath and crying. It makes people so happy and wanting more. Don't take life too seriously, just laugh and smile all the time.   Someone dying is a dreadful thing. When two high school boys die, it's even worse. On a tragic day, a group of high school students were walking on the rocks by the ocean when a sneaker wave snatched two of them. The community was in shock, unable to comprehend the loss of two beautiful lives.   Hundreds of students gathered at church to mourn the boys and honor their memory. Friends spoke of the good times they shared and how much they were missed. Laughter and cheering at a school basketball game helped bring some healing to the community.   As time passes, the pain of their loss will still be felt, but remembering the good times and sharing laughter can help in the healing process. Life is precious, and it's important to cherish every moment and tell the people you care about that you love them. Laughter is a powerful tool that can help us navigate through even the darkest of times.

People can share many things. DNA, clothes, feelings, beliefs, religion, and laughter. For my sister @PERSON3 and I, laughter is what made our relationship stronger than it ever would. When I was younger it was the typical older sister @LOCATION1 younger sister vibe, frankly we did not like each other at all. Through maturing, entering high school, and being part of the same cheer leading organization we have spent almost too much time together and now it's almost as if we are the best of friends. In the @DATE3 we were together constantly. We would watchJerry @PERSON1, laugh and/or make fun of the people who volunteered to be on the show. We would watch clips of the showSaturday @TIME1 @CAPS1, that's where I introduced her to the character "@CAPS2". @PERSON3 and I would talk to each other in the voice that we adapted from "@CAPS2" and laugh constantly about @NUM1 @TIME1 @CAPS1 is also where we adapted the "demonic voice". We would talk to each other, and our friends in these voices. Both of us still talk like that @DATE1. As we entered high school we had to start driving together everyday to and from school. We would listen to music, make up random dance moves and sometimes I would have to steer if her favorite song came on(she was a very energetic dancer). It was all in good fun though. When we would enter into the school everything would change though and I understood that after about a week. I was the annoying younger sister who couldn't say hi to her in the hall or wave at her when she was around her friends. She wanted to be left alone so she wouldn't look weird. She was a junior then, they always think their the coolest around. Once she was a senior she would say hi to me, she would smile when she saw me, I even talked to her and her friends sometime. We also grew closer once I entered the student leadership class that she was also apart of, we had the same class every other day it was hard not to talk to each other. The single thing that I believe has made our relationship closer because of laughter was the three weeks she stayed in my room. She decided to "move in" when she would wake up in the morning with bug bites on her arms and legs and she would have no idea what they were from. We suspected that she just didn't remember getting them when she was out the @TIME1 before, but then when she wouldn't go out she still got them. We figured out what it was when her friend @PERSON2 came over; she had bed bugs. That @TIME1 I separated the two mattresses I sleep on and made her a bed thinking she would only be there for two three nights tops so my parents had time to disinfect her room. That turned into two three weeks. We spend almost every hour of every day together those three weeks, the only peace I got was in the shower. We would stay up late talking about our day, who we didn't like, who's outfit we really liked that day, what we wanted to do in cheer practice and who could have done better at cheering. If you knew @PERSON3 you would know how scared she gets over a movie so half the time when we were up late I was next to her trying to scare her. It's quite funny to see her reaction. Finally she "moved out" and I got my room back though I don't think, even now it feels the same as it did. They say many things about laughter; "Laughter is the best medicine" "Laughter is the shortest distance between people" "@CAPS5 two people in a room, they'll be laughing in @NUM2 minutes"; All of these talking about how relationships grow with laughter. I have the funniest, silliest, greatest sister in the world because we can laugh at the same things. We have the same mind people say, we do a lot of the same things, we think a lot alike, and we wear a lot of the same things as well. I am positive laughter has strengthened my sister and I's relationship. I bet if you really look at the relationship between you and someone you're close to, the first memory you think of is a happy moment of you laughing. Laughter truly has a way of bringing people together and creating lasting bonds that stand the test of time.

One day I was going to my friend @ORGANIZATION1 @PERSON1's house for her @NUM1 birthday party. I knew the birthday party was going to be a lot of fun even though it was only going to be @ORGANIZATION1, @CAPS1 and I. I didn't know it was going to be as fun as it turned out to be though.  The whole day I was waiting for it to be @NUM2 so I could go to her house. I packed all my bags and got everything ready because it was a sleepover. As I was on my way to her, she called me and said, "Before you get to my house, look to the right." The whole way my dad and I were driving to her house, I kept my eyes on the right side of the road, unsure of what I was looking for. As we got closer, I saw something in the bushes. It was @ORGANIZATION1 and @PERSON2. I told my dad to honk at them so they knew I was there, and as he did, they both pulled down their pants and mooned us! I was laughing so hard the whole night, thinking about the look on my dad's face!  Little did I know that wasn't going to be the funniest thing that happened that night. Later on, @ORGANIZATION1, @PERSON2, and I went for a walk down to the dock by @LOCATION1's house. While we were on the dock, a bat flew by, and @PERSON2 almost fell in the water because she was so scared. @ORGANIZATION1 and I were standing behind her, laughing so hard. By that time, it was getting kind of dark, and her neighbors were being really loud. So we ran from the dock to her neighbor's house and hid, yelling things at them to quiet down. It was hilarious because they had no idea where the yells were coming from, so they just kept looking around confused. We started laughing so hard we could hardly be quiet.  We had to wait a while for her neighbors to stop looking around trying to figure out who was telling them to be quiet. As we were walking back to @LOCATION1's house, we heard a car coming, so we made a plan. I stood in the middle of the street, @ORGANIZATION1 stood ahead of me, and @PERSON2 was hiding in the bushes. The plan was for @ORGANIZATION1 and me to pretend to be in a fight, and @PERSON2 was going to run out of the bushes and pretend to shoot me.  As the car started turning the corner, @ORGANIZATION1 and I started fake fighting. The car slowed down as it got closer, and here came @PERSON2 running out of the bushes and pretending to shoot me. I fell to the ground like I was really hurt, trying to hold back my laughs. We thought we got the people in the car good, but then we realized there was no gunshot sound. The people in the car were actually @CAPS2, some of @ORGANIZATION1's family friends coming over for the party, and they knew it was fake the whole time.  That night, we found a huge watermelon and took it out to a bridge by @LOCATION1's house. We brought her video camera and put it on night vision, then threw the watermelon off the bridge. When it hit the water, it made a loud sound and split into tiny pieces. It was so much fun, and we had a great time together. The next day, the fun continued with activities at the lake, swinging on rope swings into the water.  @ORGANIZATION1 got a bad rope burn, which was hilarious. @PERSON2, @ORGANIZATION1, and I always have the best time together and tons of laughs. A lot more happened that night, making it a great @NUM1 birthday for @ORGANIZATION1. I'm glad I got to be there with her for it.

We all have had times when some thing happened and you just thought of it as a nuisance. But looking back on the same occurrence you just have to laugh at how silly it was. I recall one of these experiences when I went on a motorcycle camping trip this past summer. It was a bright and sunny day when my dad dropped me off at the beginning of the main logging road of the area. I decided to keep my pace slow and steady and just enjoy the beautiful scenery. Later that day I found a picturesque place to camp for a few nights on the river. In the afternoon, I remembered some spurs off the main road from when I have driven with my brother in these woods and decided to go explore some of them near my camp. I decided to go check out one across the river that looked like a fun ride. As I was crossing it my front tire hit some lose rocks causing me to fall into the water! Thankfully I fell away from my motorcycle, if I hadn't it could very well have fallen on me which, out in the woods by myself, would have put me in quite the predicament. After getting my gear up and out of the water I headed back to camp to dry my clothes off, seeing as how I only brought one set with me. While reading a book and waiting for my clothes to dry I fell into a deep sleep. When I woke up I realized that the sun had been up for some time now so I decided that I had better get going on another ride before the day's out. This time I stayed on my side of the water and went up a steep road that lead up to the top of the ridge. As I climbed it became increasingly warm then I broke through the woods and witnessed a glorious sight. The sun was just cresting the ridge in front of me and I had to stop and bask in the sun shine. After a while of just sitting I got going again. The road I was on started to taper down into a valley. At the bottom of it, flood waters had washed large quantity's of silt over the road and it was still muddy. As I crossed it my wheels started spinning out and flinging mud at me as a result I ended up very dirty. Once again I headed back to camp to wash my clothes in the river. This time I didn't fall asleep for quite some time and when I did it was a fitful one. Upon waking I packed up my meager supplies and headed out to complete my journey. Most of a day got me only halfway to my destination so I was forced to stop and rest for the night. Just setting out my tent and getting out some food for dinner and breakfast in the evening didn't take me very long. Having little to occupy my time I just sat by my fire and pondered my trip and life in general. When I fell asleep I slept soundly until morning. Waking to the sound of birds chirping and the river rushing by me was delightful and invigorating. It only took me a few hours to reach where my dad was going to meet me and take me home. This trip helped me think and gather my thoughts. It also helped me enjoy the little things in life that we so often take for granted. Looking back at it always makes me laugh and realize that my errors could have been much worse but as it turned out they were just minor setbacks. All in all, it was a very good time to gather my thoughts and renew my soul.

My freshman year of high school started off less favorable than most. During the end of my eighth grade year, I found that my friends were not as loyal as I believed they were at the beginning of our friendship, and in turn started high school without any. It wasn't all bad because I was able to see things for myself for one of the first times in my life. Of course, I sulked, but looking back on it now, I am appreciative of this time that helped me get to know myself better. However, one can't go through life without any friends, so I quickly tried to conform to what was considered 'normal'. I had luck from the start, but I was still scorned from being deserted by all the people who I once considered friends and in turn took these recipients as little more than acquaintances. Like most acquaintances, we only spoke in class and kept the conversation casual about nothing more than trivial facts. I wanted to have 'real' friends, but I wasn't sure what a real friend was. I suppose that these so-called acquaintances considered me a friend, though I can never be sure whether or not this is true. So I continued through my days with a person to talk to in each class but no one to sit with at lunch. This circumstance, however, was made more desirable because my sister still attended the high school at this point. Her presence made my life slightly easier because I could confide in her and even eat lunch with her. People who have always had friends may not understand, but when you have nowhere to sit at lunch, it can be kind of lonely. Fortunately, my sister was always there for me, though she did skip a lot of school. And whenever she wasn't there, I could rely on her friends to keep me company. I found that even if I couldn't find my own friends, I could always share my sister's. This nomad existence continued until the second trimester of my freshman year. I had all new classes and felt as if it was a new beginning and anything could happen, and truly anything I could imagine did. It started out the same as the trimester before had. I went to my first couple classes and gained more acquaintances like usual and felt as if things might not change after all. However, after five minutes of sitting alone in my apparel construction class, two girls walked in and sat at my table. Their conversation caught my attention and held it. I knew that it was wrong to listen to others' conversations, but I figured that if they didn't want me to hear, they would have spoken quietly. Though I can't recall the actual subject of the conversation now, I remember it was a hilarious topic. Even though I took no part in the discussion, I couldn't help but be overcome with laughter as the two spoke. They then began to laugh so hard, which resulted in tears filling their eyes. In turn, my eyes also began to fill with tears from the extreme amounts of laughter. One of the two girls looked over at me and told her friend out loud to "look at her, she's laughing so hard at you she's crying!" I could hardly stop laughing long enough to introduce myself. Before I knew it, we became close friends, and it was all due to the amazing powers of laughter that can bring strangers together into best friends. This experience taught me the importance of being true to myself and showed me that sometimes, unexpected friendships can bring the most joy and fulfillment in life.

I was about ten when this story happened to me. I was with my grandma at the park when I put my head in the monkey bars and got stuck. While my grandma was in the bathroom, the other kids at the park found it amusing and laughed at me, causing me to feel embarrassed.  After managing to free myself from the monkey bars, I decided to play a trick on the other kids. I dared them to try putting their heads in the monkey bars as well. Unaware that I had practiced beforehand to avoid getting stuck, the kids attempted the same and ended up in the same predicament. I found it hilarious and had a good laugh at their expense.  When my grandma returned and we left the park, I asked to go home. The next day, I repeated the trick on a new set of kids, but this time they reported me to their parents. Consequently, I got into trouble with my grandma and was grounded for two weeks.  Despite the consequences, I couldn't resist trying the trick again the next time I went to the park. This experience taught me that kids will be kids, always curious and sometimes falling for the same pranks over and over again.

Friendship and laughter are essential components of a strong bond between friends. Through open communication and a willingness to forgive, we were able to mend the rift between us. The tension lifted, and we rediscovered the joy of laughing together. Now, as we continue to nurture our friendship, we make sure to cherish every moment of laughter we share. Our bond is stronger than ever, and I am grateful for the lessons learned from our experience. Friendship and laughter truly are invaluable treasures, and I am committed to preserving them in my relationship with my best friend.

Shafts of light escape through fogged windows casting a shadowed glare upon the surface of the table. A tremendous sign hovers on a wide oak shelf that borders the entire dining area. "@CAPS1's" reads in great letters buried under decades of dust. My eyes dance among the plethora of mismatched antiques and statues strung throughout the room, easily filling every crevice. These objects form a family of outliers, each individually unique, belonging to the restaurant. Huge posters of All-@CAPS2 athletes tower among large flat screens, while an acrid scent of molded wood and fermented beer lingers. Numerous bras fall from the ceiling of the bar that sits next to the entrance. The sound of crunching echoes in my ears as waitresses maneuver over fallen peanut shells. That's what sets this place apart from the others. The entire floor is littered with barrels of peanut shells and mashed peanuts as it is custom for the customers to throw them on the ground. Of course, there's my family; a vivacious group of five squeezing our round frames into a booth that comfortably seats four. We seem to mesh quite nicely with the crowd of miscellaneous objects, dressed in our "Today's Special" attire of skirts and dress suits. Distracted, I busy myself with the menu, browsing for something with a little zest and a lot of calories. A loud smashing noise breaks my attention, and I slide the newspaper-style menu below my eyes. Across the table sits my grandmother, a petite old lady standing proudly at 92, who devotes her free time to attempting stand-up comedy. I study the glass jar of ketchup she's holding and watch her pound the corner on a single peanut. The shell cracks open, and she picks out the nuts, sweeping its kernels onto the floor. I giggle to myself, surprised at the lengths this old lady is willing to go to. She proceeds to repeat this process with ten more peanuts until the entire family has stopped in curiosity. Looking up, she pauses with the jar suspended in her hand. "What? I'm just trying new ways of cracking open the nut," she exclaims, pausing for a comical response. With no reaction, we resume contemplating our meal choices. Minutes later, a hefty waitress reeking of drugstore perfume and last night's hangover sets down glasses of water and drags off sluggishly. Raising his glass, my father motions for us to follow. "Cheers!" he calls, clinking each of our glasses in turn. "Cheers! And cheers to cherry people!" my grandmother pitches in. "Oh, dear!" I shout automatically. Immediately, my parents chuckle because my grandmother has never been funny. It's a joke that nobody in the family laughs at her comments but herself, and that's how it remains. Years ago, my brother deemed her jokes the "Oh, dear!" because she poses as a comedian but truly isn't. From then on, each time she would crack a "joke," someone was quick to respond with yelling "Oh, dear!" To this day, she has neither improved nor given up daily opportunities to attempt to win over her audience. In quiet defeat, she chuckles to herself and focuses back on the menu. Seconds later, she's back in the ring for round two. "It's noon. So are we having breakfast or lunch? Or should we have... brunch?! I'm dying here, just laugh already," she pleads. For a moment, we all just stare at her. Innocent eyes gaze back; the predator calmly sits awaiting the move of its prey. Then, as if a switch had been flipped, we eye each other, and the ribbon is cut. Tea party giggles erupt into hoarse cries as rolls of thunderous laughter echo through the room. I hand my mother a napkin, which she uses to dab jubilant tears. The thick wooden table shutters under the pound of my father's fist slapping the surface in hysteria. I laugh so hard my gut aches, and yet I cannot understand why everything is so funny. All the while, my grandmother sits in pure delight, tickled by the success of finally earning a sincere response to her notorious off-the-cuff "jokes." It's a wonder we aren't thrown out of the restaurant. Customers in surrounding booths peer over the edge of their bench, eying us with distaste. However, this isn't the first and certainly won't be the last time my family causes a scene. Plain yet obnoxious jokes are a loosely run camaraderie in our family that always finds its spot in our books of lasting memoirs. The remainder of the meal was spent in bursts of giggles, and we were more than kindly shown out the door once our meal was finished. It's when you break into hysterics for no monumental reason and can't get through retelling it to someone

A long time ago, my family and I went to the lake to see my great aunt and uncle. They had a log cabin right on the lake, with an teepee in the back yard. They had a dock with a very big nice boat. I had went with my mom, my other aunt, and my two half sisters. I forgot why we went, but I think it was just because it was the weekend and my great aunt and uncle were getting older. I was very young, and I only remember bits and pieces of the trip. I remember watching cartoons with my sister on the couch, watching "SpongeBob" in our bedroom, having my sisters make me watch my first scary movie (I hate scary movies), going to a go-cart track and driving for the first time, taking one of the extra little boats and going on the lake with one of my older half sisters, also taking the big boat and riding around the lake with my great uncle, he would turn in circles and we would jump on the wave to make the ride more fun! We get around to the 4th of July, and they were selling illegal fireworks all around the state for the event of course. I remember sitting in the car with my two half sisters, and my mom had gotten out of the car to go and get fireworks from a stand on the side of the road. We were all tired from something, and we all stayed in the car. Outside the little stand where they sold the fireworks was this blow-up balloon guy; you know one of those blow-up looking things where it has a face on it and it doesn't stop moving and dancing? Anyways, my oldest half sister starts saying "look there he goes doing the macarena!" I had no idea what she was talking about until she pointed to the blow-up guy who was just wiggling and springing to life every second. Then my other half sister joins in and starts saying "and now he's doing the mashed potato!" and now I'm laughing because it's just so silly and funny, I actually thought he was dancing and doing all these dance moves! Now everyone in the car is laughing and giggling about something silly and funny, I mean we were throwing out silly dance moves, some not even dances moves, just random objects! "THE worm!" "THE robot!" "THE sprinkler!" we could not stop laughing! When my mom got in the car she was like "what happened?!". I tried to explain to her it was funny but she didn't get it. I guess you just had to be there to be a part of the ridiculous car stop at the side of the road where they sold fireworks to see why it was so funny!

Laughter can be a very important thing in everyone's life because it can help in many ways. It has helped me get through emotional problems with ex-boyfriends. My mom once told me that "laughter is the best medicine," and now I understand that dwelling on heartbreak is pointless. Making the people around me laugh and smile creates the best memories. Even a simple laugh or smile can make someone feel better and brighten their day. However, fake laughter can be hurtful, as it may come from insincere intentions. I try to make those I care about smile because it makes me happy to know I've made a positive impact on their day. My baby sister's constant laughter is infectious and reminds me of the power of a simple smile. While laughter can be a source of joy and relief, it's important to remember not to laugh at the expense of others' pain. Ultimately, laughter can have both positive and negative impacts, depending on the intentions behind it.

I personally believe that laughter is essential in any relationship. It has the power to bring joy, relieve stress, and strengthen connections between people. In my relationship with my toddler daughter, laughter plays a crucial role in turning difficult moments into lighthearted ones. Even in the midst of stress and frustration, her funny antics or cute expressions never fail to make me smile and laugh, easing the tension and bringing us closer together. Laughter is a universal language that can bridge gaps and create bonds, whether it's with a child, a partner, or a friend. It has the ability to uplift spirits, improve moods, and create lasting memories. In times of sadness or hardship, a good laugh can provide much-needed relief and perspective, reminding us to focus on the positive aspects of life. Overall, laughter is a powerful tool that can enhance relationships, foster happiness, and promote emotional well-being. So, let's embrace laughter in all our relationships and reap its many benefits for a more fulfilling and joyful life.

I believe laughter brings many different people together. In my friendships with friends we are always laughing about random, silly, things that happen to us each day. When we went to the councler she was very nice and talked to us in a way we all felt comfortable. She asked us what we missed most about our friendship and all three of us answered laughing. We said that we laughed every day and now we go home crying. She asked us if we liked to play games during the times we used to spend together, we answered yes. She let us play games, such as monopoly, which was really fun. At the end of the day the three of us went back to class smiling and laughing. When we entered the classroom everyone was surprised that we were actually getting along. After school I went home and my mom asked me how the councling session had gone. I smiled and said we all had a blast! The next day the three of us went back to the councler and played more games. This session also we would be writing a paper about how the fight had changed us. When we were done writing, all of us read the paper to one another. All having the same message: I wish this had never happened, I miss the laughing, and I will laugh about this fight in the future. In most ways laughing about this silly fight has brought all of us closer and kept us together. Now we have more and more things we can laugh about.  Every friendship has its ups and downs and along with those comes laughter or crying. In the end the only way that you and your friends can be closer is to laugh. Never miss a moment or second guess a change with your friends. They are always going to be with you along the journey of life and laughter is the key. Laughing with friends can strengthen bonds and create lasting memories, helping us navigate through tough times with a smile on our faces.

Benefits of laughter are numerous, ranging from improving mood and mediating conflicts to even providing health benefits.
