He was raging, spitting profanities. He dropped himself on the bench with the elegance of an enraged walrus. His mom came down from the stands to give him water, which only made him embarrassed him more. Sitting beside @PERSON2, I could feel the anger radiating off of him. He was ranting under his breath over number @NUM2, the opposing team's point guard. I noticed that while @NUM2's fast legs and swift hands made him a great ball-player, his voice -- a good octave above his teammates' -- was much more @CAPS8 suited for covering @ORGANIZATION1 songs than calling out plays. I turned towards @PERSON2, tapping him on the shoulder, and informed him of my insight. He looked at me for a moment, a mixture of anguish and "don't-talk-to-me-or-I-will-murder-@CAPS12" on his face before bursting out laughing. Clapping me on the back, he said with a smile: "@CAPS12 always know @CAPS4 to make us laugh, @PERSON1". Suddenly @CAPS13 dawned on me that my banter and dripping sarcasm was quite often the one thing keeping smiles on my teammates' faces. I was able to use @CAPS7 to diffuse tense situations, and allow emotions to flow freely in a more positive manner. We lost the game. In fact, we lost all but one game the entire season; and so I made @CAPS13 my personal duty to keep the entire team in good spirits even in the worst of times. As the weeks went by, I started to feel more and more an integral part of the team; making teammates laugh kept their minds clear of anger and frustration, and allowed them to play to the best of their abilities. And so @CAPS13 was. Some players had quick hands, others had a flawless shot. Me? I made people laugh. I gave my peers,

Laughter plays an important role in everyone's lives. Different laughs represent various things. For instance, have you ever heard someone chuckle and know right away that they are being sarcastic, or maybe even sympathetic? A laugh can say a lot. I'm going to tell you about the time my friend fell into an icy pond.   In early winter, my friend was visiting me at my house for a week. The third morning of her stay, we woke up to seven inches of snow. As my friend, who was from a place with no snow, anxiously laughed at the sight, I could tell she just wanted to go outside immediately. We bundled up and headed out, with my friend eyeing the frozen pond on my property. She jokingly asked if we could go swimming, but I quickly dismissed the idea. However, she was determined to walk across a log over the pond, despite my warnings.   As she danced on the icy log, I couldn't help but laugh at her antics. Predictably, she slipped and fell into the freezing water. After a moment of shock, I managed to pull her out, and we both ended up laughing despite the chilly situation. Back at the house, we changed into dry clothes and spent the day sipping on hot beverages, sharing laughter and creating memories. It was a day filled with unexpected adventures and laughter that we would both remember fondly.

Laughter forms a bond between two people; a good laugh can turn an uncomfortable situation into a pleasant one. A fantastic example of the power of laughter would be the first time I met my mother's boyfriend. My father died when I was thirteen and since then I had stubbornly resented each new man my mother attempted to bring into my life. This iron clad resolution ended when my two sisters and myself sat down to dinner with @ORGANIZATION1. One @DATE1 @TIME1, my mother announced that she had invited her new boyfriend over meet her children. My sisters and I were forced to scrub the house from top to bottom in order to prepare for our guest, while my mother cooked a giant pan of lasagna. When the house was clean and the dinner was cooked, I dressed for this most grievous occasion. My obsessive compulsive mother made me change clothes at least thirty times before she deemed me presentable enough to meet the man whose existence I was beginning to despise. At precisely six thirty in the @TIME2, @PERSON1's blue @ORGANIZATION2 pulled into our driveway. I shot my mother a steely eyed glare as I opened the door for the buffoon; thus, a most dreaded dinner began.  My determined hatred began to soften as soon as I saw @PERSON1, but it was by no means expired. @PERSON1 was tall and tan, a few years older than my mother judging by his wrinkle strewn skin and the silver streaked through his dark hair and matching mustache. He had the sort friendly, pleasant appearance that makes him immediately likable. My now giddy mother and her sullen children sat down to eat with the cheerful stranger. My younger sister warmed up to him first. She and @PERSON1 share a love of snakes, lizards and all things I deem "creepy crawly." A common interest brought them together before I knew it. My older sister adored @PERSON1 after a lively conversation about football ensued. @PERSON1 and my sister discovered they were both @CAPS1 fans, and consequently formed a bond over their team.  After winning my siblings over, @PERSON1 tried to charm me into liking him to. He attempted to talk of movies, music, sports, animals, even politics, but nut nothing he said could melt my icy disposition. I was determined to hate him from the start of the @TIME2, and no amount of charisma would break my persistent stubbornness. Eventually he gave up on me, and focused on entertaining the people who did like him. Over dessert he jumped into a stand-up comedy routine cleverly disguised as a story about his recent flight to @LOCATION1. He went on about the ridiculous security checks, the overly cheerful flight attendants who really hate their job, and the corny safety videos. I had tears of laughter in my eyes before I remembered that I had made a solemn vow to loath @PERSON1. I fought hard to resume my former demeanor, but my will did not stand a chance against @ORGANIZATION1's sense of humor. The triumphant smile and slick wink he shot me from across the table told me that he had won. Sure enough, we were the best of friends before the night ended.   Eventually @PERSON1 and I conversed about movies and music and found we had similar tastes in both, but our common interests had nothing to do with our friendship. They simply fueled the fire. The power of laughter brought us together like a magnet and a washer. Just as the shortest distance between to points is a straight line, laughter was the straight line between myself and @PERSON1. He and my mother are still together, and ever since he came into our lives, laughter has been our constant companion.

The warm day spent with friends at the mall, followed by lunch and fun at the park near the river, turned out to be even better than expected. Laughter and joy filled the day, reminding us of the importance of happiness in life. Laughter is a key aspect of life, bringing people together and creating memorable moments. The ability to laugh and find joy in simple things is essential for a fun and fulfilling life. This day served as a reminder to cherish these moments and appreciate the happiness that comes with them. Laughing often is a way to connect with others and bring lightness to everyday life.

The time I went @CAPS1-wheeling! One time when I went @CAPS1-wheeling with @PERSON3, @PERSON5, @PERSON1, @PERSON4, and I, we went up @ORGANIZATION1. This is the arrangement of who was in what trucks. It was @PERSON2 and I in my @CAPS2 @NUM1, @PERSON1 and @PERSON4 in his tracker @NUM1, and @PERSON3 and @PERSON5 in his @NUM3 wheel drive jeep @CAPS3. When we started to head back down the mountain, @PERSON3 let @PERSON5 drive down. @PERSON5 can't see very well at night because she wears glasses and her eye sight's not very good. Well, I was following them down the mountain and we finally got to the pavement, and @PERSON5 was going pretty fast for that road because it's a narrow, curving road, and that was the first time she had ever been on it before. She went to go around a really sharp corner and got up on two wheels and flipped over right in front of me, so I had to slam on the brakes so that I wouldn't run into them. So, I shut my truck off, ran over there as fast as I could, and helped @PERSON5 out of the truck. When I turned back around to go help @PERSON3 out, he was already on top of the truck. He looked at @PERSON5 and said, "@CAPS4, look at what you did to my truck, I have tried many times to roll it and never have been able to - god damn you!" So, we all started laughing, and then I got a chain out of the back of my truck and pulled him back over. Then it was really quiet, and @PERSON4 farted, and we all started to laugh again. Well, then @PERSON3 found out that he got a hole in his radiator. I had to pull him back to his house, and it seemed like the longest drive ever because his truck weighs way more than mine, so I had to pull him home in @CAPS1 wheel drive, and you can't go over thirty in @CAPS1 wheel drive because things can break. So, we finally got to his house, and his dad came outside and he saw the truck and was really upset because he gave that truck to him as a graduation present, and he messed it all up. Then he finally cooled off because he said no one was hurt, and he was glad for that. So, we went inside the house, ate dinner, and went to bed. The moral of the story is to be very careful because things can happen when they are unexpected.

We all know the benefits of laughter. Many people believe that laughter is an important part of any relationship. Is there anything more to laughter? Can one person be happy without laughing? I have never gone a day without laughing. I know the benefits of laughter. Do you? I know the benefits of laughter. Its truly amazing how something so simple can bring people together, make friends and fix relationships, or make someones day a little better if they are having a rough time. There was a time in ninth grade when my best friend and I got into an argument because I didn't ask him to be on our basketball team for a tournament that happened once a year. After talking it out, and my best friend cracking a few jokes, it had fixed everything. My point is that laughing can release tension, not make everything so serious. Laughing can help you make friends too. Around the world, simple laughter can bring two or more people together. What about enemies? Laughter could possibly show you something you like in that person your not too fond of. Laughter happens to be great for health too, and its a proven fact. What happens when you are really stressed about a test you had recently taken or something different? There are a lot of ways to handle stress, but a really good technique is simply laughter. Try going onto the internet to find something funny that will make you laugh, go hangout with a friend or group of friends, or go and find something else that might have you laugh a little. A famous @CAPS1 @CAPS2 @CAPS3 always gets nervous before one of his shows, and it just so happens that laughter is something he uses to shake off his butterflies. Its quite amazing how laughter can help you in many situations.  Do you ever find yourself feeling down or stressed? Have you had a good laugh recently? Laughing will probably help. If you are having trouble bonding with a friend or simply having a bad day laughter will be a great cure. Laughter is great for your health, and laughter has helped me in my life so far. and whether you realize it or not laughter helps you to. Your laughter can help others too! Next time you feel down or need something to lift your spirits have some fun with friends or do something you enjoy that might give you a good laugh. Laughing is truly a universal language that can bring people together, heal wounds, and improve overall well-being. Embrace the power of laughter in your life and see the positive impact it can have on yourself and those around you.

Laughter is indeed a powerful tool for connecting with others and expressing our emotions. For some, like the author, communicating through laughter can be a challenge, especially in a new environment where cultural differences play a significant role. However, through effort and observation, the author was able to adapt and find common ground with others, ultimately forming friendships and experiencing the joy of shared laughter. It is clear that laughter not only brings people together but also has the potential to improve our overall well-being. As the author discovered, even fake laughter can have positive effects on our mental and physical health. By embracing laughter in all its forms, we can create a more harmonious and joyful society, where understanding and connection flourish.

Many people love to laugh and find it important because it brings a sense of joy and happiness. Laughing with friends, like in the case of the writer and their best friend, can create lasting memories and make even the most mundane tasks enjoyable. Despite some teachers disapproving of their laughter in class, the writer and their friend continue to find ways to have fun and make the best of any situation. Laughter is a powerful tool that can lift spirits, improve mood, and strengthen bonds between people. In the end, embracing laughter and finding humor in everyday moments can greatly enhance one's overall well-being and outlook on life.

Laughter is an essential tool in forming connections and building relationships with others. It serves as a common ground where people can come together and share moments of joy and amusement. Through laughter, individuals can find others who have similar interests and create lasting bonds. Laughter not only brings people closer but also helps in creating memorable stories that can be shared and cherished over time. It plays a significant role in everyday interactions, allowing people to find comfort and build strong relationships with friends, family, and colleagues. Ultimately, laughter is a powerful force that brings people together and enriches their lives in numerous ways.

An argument is defined as "A discussion in which disagreement is expressed." In many cases, a proverbial "gap" is created between the two conflicting parties. Without a way to bridge this gap, the two groups, or individuals, will not come to a settlement, and continue arguing until one or the other backs down and accepts the others point of view. Laughter, can serve as this bridge. The door slammed shut and I went straight to my room. I had returned home from what had started out as a good time with one of my oldest friends. Looking back I do not remember what it was about, all I knew was that I was not going to speak to him ever again; but being as young as I was, these such thoughts rarely last. I would see him every day during the school week, but it would not matter whether he was there or not. He was absent to me as long as we fought. This seemed like a good plan, to completely ignore each other until we had calmed down, but as with any plan, things never go quite as well as you want them to, especially when you are in the same elementary school, and in the same class. In elementary school, or at least in my case, there were many group activities, and when you are paired with the person whom you are not on the best terms with, things become difficult. Whether it was to build something, write together, or solve a math problem as a group, communication and teamwork are both important, and us fighting did not effect the group well. We would each discuss the best way to go about performing the task at hand with another member of the group with whom we were not fighting with, and then they would discuss and consult each of us separately. In short, it was a mess, and much more difficult than it should have been. Outside the classroom, the fighting persisted. At recess we would not agree to be on the same team, or even be on the same side of the field as one another. After about a week of this, I realized this needed to stop. At recess, I tried to get him to talk out our problem instead of shouting at, or ignoring each other. The calm resolution to the problem started out well, but being children, ended in a shouting match, to which I lost. I began to wonder if we would ever resolve this. When I got home that day, my mother, being a mother and always knowing when something is wrong, asked me what was bothering me. I was resistant at first to explain things, but, being a mother, she talked me into telling her. She started to go on about how I needed to be the mature one and that we needed to calmly talk out our differences, which I had already tried. I began to tune her out and imagined my friends mother giving him the exact same speech. By the time she was done, all I had received from the lecture was that I needed to try again. The next day at recess, I searched for him with the intent of resolving things today, no matter the circumstances. When I found him and attempted to talk things out, it once again turned into a shouting match. Nearby friends started to crowd and we kept at it. Suddenly, in the midst of the yelling, my friend, with whom I had been fighting with for the last few weeks began laughing. I was taken aback and thought about what could possibly have happened for angry shouting to turn into laughter. Looking around I saw nothing out of the ordinary, only a few snickering bystanders. I ran what had just occurred back through my mind. Just as I reached the point where he started laughing I had realized I had inadvertently made a joke while we were yelling at each other. This realization caused me to laugh, and everyone else nearby to laugh. After we stopped laughing, we sat down and talked things out like we should have done from the start. We questioned why we were still fighting over something as unimportant and trivial as this. After about five minutes of talking, we agreed to still be friends and that we would try to talk things out in the future before shouting at each other. When a teacher blew a whistle and recess had ended, I walked back to class feeling happy, and relieved that we had finally worked things out and could continue being friends. If I had not made that joke in the middle of our fight, I am not sure if we would have made up, even in the event we realized how pointless it was. Laughing during an argument will not solve your problems for you. However, laughter can create a bridge across the gap, and provide a common ground in which problems can be solved.

When someone first meets me, there is always a small wall to climb before we can really get to know each other: my laugh. I have this weird awkward nervous laugh, almost like a giggle, that I don't even hear. Others do though. Especially when they first meet me. I think that most times it helps people get to know me faster. But other times, I think it is a hindrance to getting to know me. When someone first meets me they usually always comment on my laugh. They either seem slightly thrown off by it, or they easily open up and joke around with me. They always tell me about it: how odd it is, how much I do it, what it's like, etc. As if I've never been told about it before. But, this is fine. I don't hear it come out and I don't mind being told. I don't really think of it as a bad thing. When they seem thrown off by my laughing, I get more awkward and try to control it, but usually end up doing it even more. If it seems to make them laugh and they don't make fun of me for it, I just let it come out, and it becomes very easy to get to know that person. I never really realized just how bad it was, until one weekend at the beach. I was on a beach retreat with my youth group, and one of the activities was a video scavenger hunt. We went around town and took videos of different things, actions, situations, and people. One of these things we had to get a video of was one of us playing rock paper scissors with a stranger. So I promptly went up to two older women and asked to play a game with them. When we all watched the videos later I saw and heard just how weird my voice, laugh, and mannerisms are with strangers. People had told me about them from time to time, but I'd never seen it. It was weird! Another situation was working at a camp this summer. When we did icebreaker games to break tension and meet the people on our teams more easily. Everyone on my team seemed slightly weirded out by me. I couldn't figure out why, until one person would just step up and be straightforward: and inform me of my laugh. As the first week went by though, I was the person that knew everyone on the team the best. Laughter is the shortest distance between two people. It can be bridged quickly, or made greater: depending on how people react to it. If they join in it together, the distance is destroyed. When, however, one person doesn't join into the laughter, or doesn't enjoy the other person's laugh, this distance is greatly increased. It becomes hard to breach this distance, and the chance to do so is probably lost. And that is just too bad. We should all be able to laugh together and share in each other's joy.

Every time I walk down the hall and I see a couple, they are either laughing with each other or doing other things that could disqualify my test. I know for a fact that the people that get voted cutest couple at our school are the ones that are laughing as opposed to the later. Not only does laughing create couples, then families, and eventually the next generation, but it creates friendships within schools, families, activities, etc. That's why personally I believe that laughing is the single most powerful action a person can do. Every person I am friends with have laughed with me and vice-versa. Especially one friend who I've gotten even closer since we met. I was very adamant about going to church when I was young. I have always been shy and church allows me to be social with others without ridicule. However I saw one girl sitting in the back corner who I felt was scared just like I probably would have been if it was anywhere else. My parents always wanted me to be more social and they said that one way to do that was to go out of my way to meet new people. I did that for maybe the first time in my life to say "hi" to her. She replied by giving me her name. However I went back into my shy self and walked back terrified to talk to her or any one else again. However, I was only in third grade when all this happened so as time passed by things changed. About 4 years after that a new church opened with a new class being open to children of all age groups. I had cemented myself into that classroom as one of two who regularly showed up. However this one day I was the only one who was there for my age group. Well actually I was the only one from my age group that was there on time. I saw a girl walking in with her dad who you could tell had forced her to go to the class. It took me a while to picture who it was but eventually I realized who it was. It was the girl who was scared to be in church and now she was the girl who was scared to be in class. She could clearly recognize me. I made a hand gesture telling her to come in. then you saw her smile. She shortly proceeded to laughing a little bit. This was when I realized I met someone special. Now every time I see her she smiles. That's how I know she will be a friend for a long time. Laughing can't be put into quotes, but it can be put into someone's memories for the rest of your life. I know this for a fact cause a lot of days have passed since and I still have these memories. Laughing is the easiest way to tell if a person is a true friend, something more, or should and will be forgotten. Laughter truly is a universal language that can bring people together and create lasting bonds that stand the test of time.

I was hanging out with my friends at the park, just enjoying each other's company. We played games, ran around, and laughed so hard that we almost had to rush home to use the bathroom. After getting tired, we laid in the grass and watched the clouds, pointing out funny shapes and figures in them. We even made funny voices to go along with the clouds as they drifted by. It was a simple moment of joy and laughter that made us forget about any worries or stress.  After heading home to refresh ourselves, we continued our laughter-filled evening by playing games on the Wii. Laughter truly is like medicine, lifting our spirits and making everything seem a little bit brighter. It's important to find moments of joy and happiness in life, as they can truly make a difference in our overall well-being. Making others laugh and smile is equally rewarding, spreading positivity and warmth to those around us.  So, remember to embrace laughter and find joy in the little moments. It has the power to uplift our mood, bring us closer to others, and make life a little more enjoyable. Laugh often, and spread that happiness wherever you go.

Once, a very long time ago I laughed very hard with a friend is when some kid hit the floor falling and started to cry. There was water on the ground and he was soaked. The janitor was wiping the floor with water. The kid was not paying any attention at all to the janitor. The janitor was also a mean person, he was mad at the boy for stealing stuff from the school janitor's closet. The boy was also mad because the janitor was mean to him I was in @NUM1 grade and I didn't know any better. I had to say that I was sorry because the teacher caught me and my friend laughing, and told me the boy was not mentally well or stable. I felt bad, and apologized right away. I told the kid that I didn't mean anything by it, that it was just a reaction. The boy was able to laugh at himself and he and I became friends. I feel that this small event in my life changes me for the better. I am not so quick to laugh at others misfortunes, people are stupid all over the world, no one is perfect. Everyone is different and unique in their own way. The world will never be as one, there will always be war all the time forever on earth.

A time laughter has been in one of my relationships, was when I was down in the dumps and my cousin made me smile. It was a rainy day and I just woke up, my dad had asked me to make him some breakfast; while I was making the hash browns, eggs, and toast I thought of how little time me and my dad spend together. I brought his breakfast up to him and proposed the idea of going to the movies. However, my hopes were crushed when he postponed our plans. Feeling disappointed, I turned to my cousin who never fails to make me laugh. He cheered me up with his silly antics and jokes, bringing a smile to my face. His ability to lift my spirits with laughter is something I am truly grateful for. My cousin is not only family but also my best friend, and his presence in my life brings me immense joy and comfort. Laughter truly is a vital aspect of any relationship, and I am fortunate to have someone like him to brighten my darkest days.

A time when laughter was one element was when my brother showed a youtube video to my family. The video was about a guy recalling his childhood experience of being sent to buy bread by his dad. To avoid trouble, his dad instructed him to go to a store across the street, warning him about some troublesome boys down the block. As the guy passed the boys, they stopped him, and more friends joined in, surrounding him. He managed to escape and sprinted home so fast that he joked about passing a car along the way. When he reached home, he told his dad about the incident, expecting concern, but his dad only cared about whether he got the bread. The humorous recount of the childhood memory had my family bursting into laughter, even though my brother had shown us the video the night before. The funny storytelling and relatable situations made us all chuckle and enjoy the moment together.

One day my friend and I were waking up late in the day and his brother came in screaming and yelling at the top of his lungs "bro bro"! This was the nickname he called him because he was only two years old, so my friend Spencer calmed him down and we started watching t.v. We were talking about what we were going to do for the day so, we started throwing out ideas till we made one where we were going to swim later and play some games now. Spencer's mom asked us when we were going to swim and that we had to take his little brother. So we went early so his little bro could swim and we could sit around and listen to music. Unlike everyone who uses an iPod I use my phone because then I can text and listen to music plus when someone calls it shuts off music so I'll know. It was a brand new phone too and I was loving every moment of having it. So when we dropped his little brother off we went back to the pool and sat in the hot tub for a while. I put my phone on my shirt and my towel over both so when Spencer got out to use the towel he jerked the towel out and my phone flew up hit the ground slid on the floor all the way to the hot tub. That moment I look down and see it and freak I took it out ripped the back off and dried the battery with the towel hoping it would still work and it wouldn't stop dialing zero and nine so I took the battery out again. When we got back to his mom's I plugged in the charger with no battery and Spencer kept saying sorry and I kept answering "its ok". The next morning his mom asked why we didn't use a pot of rice and we started laughing because we freaked out so bad over a phone. I forgot all about the phone after that just kept laughing and the phone worked it is one of the funniest stories.

@DATE1 What a night!! Me and my friends were going to a party at our dance coach's work. We had to dress up as elves and play with kids, which was fun. After the party, we changed back into our regular clothes and started taking all sorts of pictures - funny, cute, and weird ones. Wanting to prolong the fun, we decided to visit different places to take more pictures. Our first stop was a school playground, but we had to leave because it was late and we couldn't go inside. So, we headed to the discovery park where I let my friend drive around the parking lot. There were some scary moments, but we were all having a blast. However, things took a hilarious turn when my friend decided to change back, and ended up laughing so hard that she actually wet her pants! We still tease her about it to this day, and whenever someone jokes about peeing their pants, we all look at her and share a good laugh. It's a funny memory that we often recall and it never fails to make us chuckle.

For me laughter is a huge part of life. I cannot, nor wish to escape it. Laughter is fun in itself. It always makes tense situations become relaxed and enjoyable. No feeling is more perfect than falling head first into uncontrollable laughter. Laughter is the best way to unite people together and form memories and bonds. In my home and family, too many situations arise that cause the potential, and often result, of laughter. It is the same way with my distant families such as my friends at school. Life growing up with a brother, wonderfully fun neighbors, and cousins have produced most of my laughter memories. One such time, in which laughter flowed freely, happened rather recently. The situation began when my brother, "John," had to do a school assignment. "John" was assigned, by his history teacher, to write a diary entry as if he were a mountain man in the 1800s. I did not set out to help him with his homework, but considering the end result, I was thoroughly glad I did. It seemed so unlikely that this task would be so fun. I guess that just shows how laughter can crop up so suddenly and in such unpredictable places. I came into "John's" room and he told me what he was working on, so I leaned over his shoulder and helped him with a few ideas. We were making progress and once reaching a certain point, we both contributed to a subtle humorous comment we decided to add to the entry. Reading our creation, nothing less than an explosion of laughter was triggered. The noise poured out of "John's" room like lava from a volcano! My parents could hear us and likely thought we were crazy! Another person reading our literature might not have laughed at all, but to us it was hilarious. Being in a good mood, and considering "John's" history teacher said to make the entries creative, more humorous and quite witty sentences were added. By this time I was doubled over struggling to speak through all the laughter I was consumed by. "John" was hardly better. Homework had never been more fun. We finished quicker than if "John" was working by himself and came away with the greatest feeling. "John" ended up getting full points on the entry when he turned it into his teacher. This is just one example of thousands I could think of in which laughter fills the moment. This particular instance helped with work and yet made the work not a chore, but rather a tremendously happy event. Perhaps more laughter in the workplace would lead to better production. All things considered, laughter, in my opinion, makes for the greatest joy.

I believe laughter is an essential component of any relationship, whether it be with friends, family, or a romantic partner. My best friend, @PERSON1, and I share a strong bond that is built on laughter. Our friendship blossomed from the moment we met, as I made her laugh and we instantly connected. Our time together is always filled with joy and humor, even in challenging situations like when I injured myself during a fun adventure. Despite the ups and downs, we always find a way to laugh and lighten the mood. I truly believe that laughter is the key to forming lasting and meaningful relationships with others. It brings us closer together and creates special memories that we can cherish forever. So, remember to always find the humor in life and share laughter with those you care about, as it can strengthen your connections and make your relationships even more fulfilling.

Just One day ago, my friends and I, Sarah, Jake, and I, walk under the cover of the trees, we decided to stop by the lake, in our usual meeting place where we have a perfect view, to have a chat. Jake, who is six foot tall, has long raven-black hair that just barely tickles his chin, deep blue eyes, and is extremely attractive, plopped down in the wet green grass. But Sarah, who is six foot, has short brown hair, dark ocher colored eyes, chose to stand about ten paces in front of us. To any person strolling by, she would have looked as if she was just enjoying the amazing view of the crystal water, but to us, who knew her all too well, knew she was thinking about her brother, Alex, who was in the hospital. Alex had been in the wrong place at the wrong time, got in the middle of a homeless person's fight, not to mention the guy was drunk, and got stabbed with a rusty switch-blade. Sarah felt like it was her fault that this had happened, and this made her so depressed that she would not laugh at any of our idiocy, or even eat for that matter. Sarah's feeling that way made Jake and I feel completely horrible and there was nothing we could do to cheer her up. Sarah was usually the most exuberant out of all of us, and we did every single thing we could possibly think of to make her feel better, or, at the very least, get her to smile again. But not once could we budge her, or even get one little giggle out of her tightened jaw. Not one of our pathetic attempts even touched her eyes, but we never gave up, in fact, we tried for days on end to get her to smile again. We got to the point of desperation that we even dressed ourselves up as teletubies, went to Sarah's house, dragged her off of her couch, and took her downtown. Yet not one second of it did her mouth even twitch upwards. Although we did some of the most outrageous, unimaginably embarrassing things we could possibly think of, and trust me, we though about it for days. We got absolutely no response what so ever out of her, except, of course, her enormous yawns. Finally, about a week later, we got her to giggle, which eventually turned into a full on, body shaking laugh. You will never guess what finally got her to crack. A knock-knock joke. Of all the horrendously obnoxious deeds we had done, cheesy, idiotic knock-knock jokes are what got to her. Although Jake and I felt like complete idiots, we could not help but laugh with her. After that day it was no longer a difficult process for her. Sarah was almost, but not quite, back to her normal self. So our lives went on, and Alex got out of the hospital perfectly fine.

"Laughter" Have you ever felt it? The feeling of uncontrollable joy building up inside you? The one feeling you can never explain in any word but one. Laughter. This is a wondrous feeling, it can make you do so many things, like scream, and yell! Someone once said, Laughter, is the beauty of life. It helps us get out of hard times, and it always put a smile on our face when we feel down. It will make good times even better and never be forgotten. Laughter is something everyone needs. It helps us connect with people. It causes you to become one with another. This is the story of me. The story of how laughter caused me to meet the love of my life. How the connection of joy between us will last forever, and how the memories of his smile will last in me forever. It was the day I met him. It was a gorgeous day, snow was covering the ground for miles, and I was surrounded by my amazing friends. The feeling of boredom quickly flew over our heads. So we decided it was time to have some fun. We quickly put our snow clothes on and began running for the door. The moment we stepped outside everyone but me stopped. I kept going into the ice-cold air. I slowly began to realize they had stopped and I tried to come to an immediate halt. They all began to laugh as I laid on the icy ground holding my sore butt. I was so embarrassed, and so shocked by what had just happened that I didn't move, I just laid back and closed my eyes. As I was laying there I began hearing footsteps. I figured they were just my friends coming to help me. But when I opened my eyes, it wasn't my friends I saw. It was a handsome man, one I had seen a few times before in my high school. He leans down and asks me, "Are you okay?" I reply in a shy tone, "yes..." He smiles and reaches down to help me up. As our skin gently touches I get butterflies all throughout my body. I look at him and can tell he was getting the same feeling. As I stand to my feet we both smile and begin to laugh. I still to this day don't understand why we laughed... I am wondering a million things at once, but the first question that exits my mouth is, "What is your name?" He replies with a smile and says, "James and you?" "My name is Emily." I reply. I begin to thank him and ask if he would like some hot chocolate or coffee. He replies in a cute tone that sent chills up my spine. He says "I would rather take you to get a burger, will you come?" A huge smile washes over my face as I say "yes." He grabs my hand and walks me closer to my friends. They all began to smile and turn and walk away quickly into the depths of my house. James smiles and decides not to follow. We both begin to laugh as we run over to his car. I had heard a lot about James, my friends were always talking about how cute and muscular he is. The first thought that went streaming through my head was, I can't believe he wants to take me out to lunch! We sit awkwardly in the car all the way to a small diner called Charlie's. When we stop James jumps out of the car and rushes to my door to open it. James is such a gentleman I thought to myself. When we get to our table James orders for us both and asks me all sorts of questions. James kept me smiling the whole time! I don't think any boy has ever done that. After we ate and James drove me home we smiled and laughed as he told me joke after joke. When we reached my house James asks me a question. A question I will never forget. "Can I kiss you?" James asks. I do not answer but lean in and kiss him. We look into each other's eyes afterwards and begin to laugh... Why we laughed I still will never know. But at that moment I fell in love. At that moment I realized laughter will be the connection between us forever. The laughter is in remembrance of him. Rest in peace James.

In any relationship, things like physical contact, verbal conversations, or any kind of outward expression at all is very important. More particularly, laughing is key as well, to any kind of interaction with someone. Laughing says,"what you are saying is funny" or, I'm enjoying this". Laughing says a lot without saying a word. Think about someone you know very well. It might be your best friend, or it might be a family member. If you think about it, you can tell when they are mad, sad, angry, frustrated, just by looking at their facial expressions or looking into their eyes. When you see them laugh, you see happiness. Its so obvious, because their eyes sparkle, their face lights up, and you just know that they are cheery. Now think about when you are hanging out with your friends. Being with friends is always fun, and we love it. That's why we go do things with them right? And when we are with them, we laugh a lot. We tell funny stories, we share inside jokes, and fun memories that make us laugh, and we love that, we love the feeling we get when we are with them,and most of all, we love the moments that make us laugh. Maybe its a long car ride, a sleepover, or maybe its at a party or church perhaps. Have you ever noticed that when one person laughs, the rest of the group follows in unison? Laughter is contagious, making it hard to resist most of the time. Whether it be a joke that was told, or that someone made a fool of themselves, its always a favorite part of any gathering or party, or whatever it may be. Some people say that each time you laugh, a few seconds are added to your life. Im not so sure I believe that, but I do believe laughing is healthy. I know that when I laugh, i feel so much better. Whenever I get back from hanging out with my three closest friends, I feel great. It's like whatever else that was getting to me that week or day is just forgotten, and especially if we laugh a lot, it makes me feel good. When a friend or someone else we know is down in the dumps,what is the first thing most of us resort to? It's going to be making them laugh right? Because laughter is a big part of being happy. When someone laughs, they find it hard to resist being cheered up. For this reason, I believe that laughter is the best medicine of all. It's so hard not to feel better when laughing. Once again, I believe that laughter is important in any human relationship, because laughing shows that you are either enjoying their company, just like smiling at all the right moments, or making the right face when they are telling a story, and showing them that you are engaged in the conversation. If someone is telling a funny story, or a joke, laughing shows that you get the humor in what they are saying. If you are enjoying being with that person, laugh a lot. Show them that you love hanging out with them. People love making other people laugh. Whether you are laughing at a joke, a funny story, or a face they made, or all of the above, laughing is just as important in any situation. Just like the saying goes for smiling, everyone laughs in the same language. Laughter says the same thing all around the world. Laughter is is almost always a good sign, and means something is going right. Laughter truly is a universal language that connects us all and brings joy and happiness to our lives.

The power of laughter can have a lasting impact on individuals, shaping their self-perception and confidence. A childhood experience at a family gathering, where a young girl bravely took the stage to sing, turned into a moment of vulnerability as she faced laughter from the audience. This incident left a deep emotional scar, leading her to believe she had a horrible voice and avoiding singing in front of others. However, with time and understanding, she realized that the laughter was not meant to be hurtful but was a reaction to her adorable innocence and pronunciation. As she grows older, she learns to overcome her fear and embrace her passion for singing, determined to not let past insecurities hold her back. Through self-acceptance and positivity, she strives to regain her confidence and share her voice with the world, knowing that no laughter can dim the light of her talent.

I heard one true story about a normal businessman who wasn't in a high-level position in his company. However, he always greeted everyone with a big laugh. One day, the boss of the company asked who worked the hardest, but no one answered. When the boss asked for a recommendation for a promotion, everyone suggested this businessman because of his cheerful demeanor. He was eventually promoted to the highest level in the company, showcasing how his laughter made people happier and more connected. Laughing not only promotes a friendly atmosphere but also has numerous health benefits, including potentially increasing lifespan and improving mental well-being. This story highlights the power of laughter in building relationships and achieving success. Laughing often can truly make a difference in people's lives and bring joy to those around us.

Laughing has always been a big part of my life, and I believe that it plays a significant role in shaping who I am. Whether I am joking around, making funny faces, or laughing at my own clumsiness, laughter has always been a constant companion. It has helped me navigate through embarrassing situations, awkward moments, and even everyday challenges. My mom used to say that I was clumsier than a bull in a china shop, and looking back, she was right. But instead of feeling embarrassed, I have learned to laugh at myself and turn those mishaps into funny anecdotes.   One particular incident that stands out is when I fell down the stairs at an elementary school award assembly. Instead of being mortified, I chose to laugh it off and get back up with a smile on my face. This ability to find humor in the face of adversity has not only helped me cope with my own clumsiness but has also brought me closer to my family and friends. We often joke around and laugh together, finding solace and joy in each other's company.  Through laughter, I have learned to embrace my quirky, funny side and share it with those around me. It has become a defining trait of mine, and I take pride in being able to make others laugh and brighten their day. Laughter truly is a powerful tool that has shaped me into the happy and funny person that I am today.

It was my first year of high school and I was feeling pretty confident. I had great teachers and all the classes I wanted. My first day was going awesome! I had woken up on time, eaten a good breakfast, and I didn't even miss the school bus. My first few classes were fabulous and I was about to go to lunch. As the bell rang I hurried to the cafeteria to get a good spot in line. One of my close friends had called my name so I turned to wave and when I turned back I ran directly into a girl named Emily. We hit hard. I flew backwards dropping everything I was carrying. I tried to say I was sorry but all she did was glare at me and walk away. As I picked up my books I realized I didn't want anything to do with that girl and decided I'd just forget about what had just happened.   After lunch I had English. I was extra excited for this class because the boy of my dreams, Ryan, was in it. On my way there I made a quick pit-stop to the ladies room to make sure I still looked decent and then headed to class. As I walked in the room the first thing I saw was Ryan's beautiful blond hair and his dazzling blue eye. Then I registered the whole scene. Guess who was twirling her hair and batting her eye lashes at my dream guy! You got it, Emily. From that moment on it was war! As the year progressed Emily and I constantly strove to out do each other. We'd race each other to class to see who would get to sit behind Ryan. She always had to have the best hair. I would get a cute new hair cut and she would get high lights. I received a phone. So she went out and bought the latest and greatest phone with the built in music player. I remember getting to class early one day, so excited to show Ryan this new game I'd learned. But of course when I walked in the room Emily was already showing him the exact same game. There was one thing I always had over Emily, books. Both Ryan and I loved books. We would sit and talk about the latest and greatest books for hours. This always made Emily jealous. Our childish behavior went on like this for three or four months. One day at lunch I was just sitting, eating my food, and minding my own business. All of the sudden Emily appeared out of nowhere and spit soda at my face. That did it. This was the last straw. I grabbed my milk carton and dumped it on her head. The cafeteria went silent for about a minute. Emily and I stood there glaring at each other, rage searing from our eyes until some one broke the silence with a loud laugh. Soon everyone was laughing, including Emily and I. We realized just how stupid we'd been acting and for the first time we were laughing together not at each other. We both apologized and helped each other get cleaned up.   Eventually we became really good friends. To this day we still laugh about our ninth grade rivalry.

All the great memories that @LOCATION2 and I, spent and shared together when we were really good best friends. We were around @NUM1 years old and in @NUM2 through @NUM3 grade. Of course we got older as the years went by, but we had so many great times together. Whenever we hung out, we would always laugh about almost everything, and most of the time we would just never let a lot of stupid things get to us. Whenever I needed someone to talk to she would be the one. She went through a life that was almost the same as what I went through in life, and so she knows what I or even she needs to do or say. Even though we would always have lots of fun, we would have our moments and fight, but always work things out. We'd always have each other's back for everything. I guess what I'm trying to say is that two people who are close always have their great needs and feelings, and especially their laughter in the relationship.  I remember in @NUM2 grade, both of us would always try to hang out whenever we could. We were still young so it was hard to do be able to do anything because our parents wouldn't let us most of the time. Whenever we did though, we would think about random games, and go to different places just to have fun. As we got older though we were trusted more and could do lots more things, which was a good thing. Then I moved to @LOCATION1, not the greatest thing, but it was for love. What made it better was that she still came over all the time. We would go and pick her up on @DATE1 and then on @DATE2 my mom would drive to school because my mom still went to work there in Florence. Every night that she was there we would always stay up. I remember that I would always keep these little hot chocolate packages in my room and after my parents went to bed we'd sneak out to go get hot water for it so that we would have hot chocolate to drink. Some other times we would make coffee so that we could stay up longer. It was hard sometimes because my room was right across from my parents' room and at the time I had beads hanging from my door. Fun times trying to keep quiet and not get caught. Sometimes when she came over she would bring all her makeup and things so that we could dress each other up. One night we had blindfolds on and do each other's makeup.  Throughout all these memories and moments shared with @LOCATION2, laughter was always present. It was the glue that held our friendship together, even through the fights and disagreements. Our bond was special, and the joy we found in each other's company was truly priceless. These memories will always hold a special place in my heart, reminding me of the wonderful friendship we shared.

Laughing is a powerful tool that can help build friendships and create lasting bonds. It has the ability to bring people together, even in the most unlikely of circumstances. One example of this is a story about a group of friends who found common ground through humor and shared experiences. By sharing laughs and creating memories, they were able to form a strong connection that lasted a lifetime. Laughter truly is a universal language that can transcend differences and bring people closer together. So next time you find yourself in a new situation or meeting new people, remember the power of laughter in forging friendships that can last a lifetime.

Laughter, one of the greatest gifts in life. It's what helps you get through the day, the year and in the long term, your life. For me, many things can go wrong in a day. For example, I could forget about an assignment that ends up being a big part of my grade or just have a difficult day. All i need to make those bad things seem like old memories is to have a long and pleasant laugh. It is ten times better if that laugh is shared with someone else. That's why when i moved to @LOCATION1,@CAPS1 I tried to keep a look out for kids like me, who loved to laugh and make other people laugh. The first days were rough. I met a lot of new people that were all the same. Some just wanted to know my name and others to get to know me better, and that was fine. There was one person that I noticed was in multiple of my classes. So one day when our @CAPS2 teacher asked us to partner up and write a myth of creation or how something got to be the way it is. Quickly, I looked around to choose someone before every one would have a partner and I would be sitting there awkwardly without a partner. I asked a boy who was in few other of my classes. I had not really noticed or even heard him talk. He agreed to be my partner. We introduced ourselves and he told me his name was @PERSON1. He had a very quite voice. I had barely understood his name, so i had to read it from his paper. We had to work on the paper together but it felt more like if we were doing it individually. I began by throwing some ideas around. @PERSON1 would then say something and laugh but I could never hear what he would say. We worked on the paper for a couple of days, continuing to only interchange some words.  Meanwhile I was still trying to make at least one good friend. I thought maybe threw that friend i could meet some of his friends and in time I would have my own set of friends. In the meantime I ate lunch with my sister @PERSON2. You would think it would be slightly awkward or uncomfortable. It wasn't though, it was actually pretty nice because our bond had become stronger. That would work well for both of us until we made some friends. After some time she had made a couple of friends and was ready to move on. So one day while we were both eating lunch one of her new friends passed by and asked her to go sit with her. I hoped so bad that she would just say no or even say, maybe tomorrow, but no.  There I was sitting by myself in a lunch room full of eyes that were just judging who you were sitting with, if anyone. I began to eat my lunch faster than you could say sternocleidomastoid, and I was out of there. Panicking in the inside but completely calm on the outside, I paced the hallways looking for someone to hang out with. Then I saw "That @CAPS3" from three of my classes. I casually walked up to him and tried to start a conversation. For some reason i felt relaxed not as if I was trying to make a new friend but as if I was already talking to one.  In the beginning, we were just two guys that talked about classes and how this school was different from my previous. Then all of a sudden we began to talk about movies especially the resent more funny ones. We could not stop laughing in all of our classes, especially auto mechanics. We would use up all of our shop time just trying to remember all of the funny lines from the movies and trying to say them or act them out the best we could. Soon we also found out that we watched many of the same t.v. shows. We could make each other laugh with pretty much anything one of us said. I had noticed this special quality in @PERSON1 that made him extremely funny. I wasn't sure what it was,but with anything he said I would just laugh uncontrollably. We were laughing buddies, but soon we actually became great friends. We had really bonded in between the laughter. During that time we would find out new things about each other. That made us realize that we were a lot alike. Its been a few months and we have only become greater friends. I had made friends before by making them laugh or laughing at there jokes. I knew this was different tho. I had made the greatest friend I had ever had. Now I'm moving and that's the worst part. I know that with the bond of sharing some of the greatest laughs of my life we will continue to stay friends for a long time. Moving away is tough, but the memories of all the laughter we shared will always stay with me, reminding me of the amazing friend I found in @PERSON1

I have lived in my hometown almost my whole life, attending school from pre-kindergarten all the way up to 8th grade. However, halfway through my 8th-grade year, my mom dropped the bombshell news that we were moving. I was shocked and didn't know how to react - I didn't want to leave behind everything I knew. But my mom assured me that I would make new friends in our new home in Lebanon, where my cousin also attended school and could help me settle in. We packed up our things, cleaned the house, and said our goodbyes before embarking on the move.  Arriving at our new house, I was pleasantly surprised by how nice it was. My brothers were excited too, and we quickly chose our rooms and began unpacking. As the days passed, I got more and more nervous about starting high school in a new town. When the first day arrived, my cousin offered to show me around and introduce me to some of his friends, which eased my anxiety a bit.  Walking into the bustling school, I felt a mix of excitement and nerves. Throughout the day, I met new people, introduced myself in classes, and tried to find my way around the campus. By the time the school day ended, I was exhausted but relieved that it wasn't as scary as I had imagined. Back at home, my mom bombarded me with questions about my day, eager to hear all the details.  As I settled down for the night, I reflected on the whirlwind of a day I had experienced. Despite the initial fears and uncertainties, I was hopeful that I could find my place in this new chapter of my life. And as I drifted off to sleep, I knew that each day would bring new challenges and opportunities to grow in my new surroundings.

When we all get together on my dad's side, we just sit, laugh, and talk loud. I always say that we are one big fake family. All the aunts, uncles, and cousins come around my grandma's small kitchen table and talk. There are so many conversations going on, people talking loud and laughing, that it makes me feel like I'm at a home away from home. This was the case when some of us got together for a late birthday party for me in my grandma's kitchen. It was a simple gathering with my grandma, uncle, aunt, dad, my two cousins, and I; sitting around the kitchen table eating cake and talking. We were laughing and joking around, creating memories that will last a lifetime. Laughter is truly the best medicine, and my dad's side of the family knows how to have a good time together. I cherish these moments with my family, where we can be ourselves and share in the joy of being together. Family is not just about blood relations; it's about the bonds we create through shared experiences and laughter. I am grateful for my family and the laughter they bring into my life.

One time I was sick, and I told my mom "I need to get some ice tea" so I get up and go to the freezer. Suddenly my throat gets irritated and I feel the need to cough, so I do and instead of coughing on the side I do it right into the ice bucket. And it just so happens that my mom was standing next to me, and she says "Oh god! Son, what was that?" so we started laughing. It was ironic because the germs would be preserved in the icebox. It was funny that I was unintentionally keeping my germs alive in the ice, and my mom ended up using that ice. The situation turned out to be a humorous moment between us, despite the initial grossness of the situation.

It was a cold winter evening when I decided to go to the ice skating rink with my friends Jack, Sarah, Mike, Emily, and Lily. We had a ride to the rink and back so we rode along with Sarah's dad. On the way, we listened to some classic rock and Christmas carols (which I recommend to any music fans). Once we got there, I told a joke and we all laughed so hard that we couldn't stop. It was a night filled with joy and laughter, creating memories that would last a lifetime.

I always wished that I could go back in time and relive my childhood. Knowing that that was the time when I was most happiest and just living life with no purpose, no plans. Looking down on my little cousins or brother, I see joy, laughter, and silliness. I see innocent faces who have no idea nor understanding of what is going on around them. As I watch them slowly grow out of their unusual habits, I find myself back in the year I was a little girl, not in school yet, running in my grandmother's yard on a sunny mid-day. I remember playing hide and seek with my sister, giggling and pretending to be a pilot as we ran around the yard. Those carefree days were filled with laughter and fun.   Fast forward to a few days after a tragic event, everyone gathered at grandma's house. I was playing with my two youngest cousins when we discovered a small hole in the wall that gave us a glimpse into the room where the adults were. We had a great time spying on them, unaware that our uncle was watching us and eventually joining in on the fun. It was a moment of innocence and laughter amidst a difficult time.  Now, as a sixteen-year-old babysitting the younger kids in grandma's living room, I realize the importance of laughter and living in the moment. While there are serious times, laughter is a vital part of life. I reflect on my childhood with fondness, knowing that those carefree days shaped who I am today. Laughter has always been a constant in my life, a reminder of the joy and simplicity of childhood.

Thank gosh it was during the @DATE2 because me and him did it a few more times just too be brats too mom and dad. Lastly, I remember this one time in @NUM4 grade when my best friend @CAPS4 was moving. I cried for days and days. Laughter in life is a good thing to have, as it brings joy and happiness to our daily experiences. When I was younger, I had a beloved dog named Max. We enjoyed spending time together, whether it was going for walks, visiting the beach, or having picnics in the park. Max had a litter of puppies, each with unique names like Popcorn, Big Tail, and Mountain. Although I initially felt possessive of Max and didn't want him to have a family, I eventually realized that he deserved to have his own life and be happy.  The puppies, especially Popcorn, had their own quirks and behaviors that brought laughter into my life. They loved to chew on everything in sight and had a habit of nibbling on toes and hair. Despite the chaos they caused, their antics always made me smile. Max, on the other hand, had a fear of swimming but with patience and guidance, he eventually overcame his phobia. When I had to leave Max behind due to moving to another state, it was a heartbreaking moment, but I learned to cherish the memories and laughter he brought into my life.  In addition to dogs, I also had cats, each with their own unique personalities. From a wild kitty named Shadow to a speedy cat named Flash, they all added their own touch of humor and joy to my life. Laughter, I believe, is essential in relationships as well, as it can strengthen bonds and create lasting memories. It is a powerful tool that can help us navigate through life's challenges and find happiness in the little moments.  Having animals in my life has taught me the importance of laughter and how it can brighten even the darkest days. Whether it's through the playful antics of puppies or the quirky behaviors of cats, the joy and laughter they bring are priceless. Laughter is indeed a vital ingredient for a happy and fulfilling life, and I am grateful for the memories of joy and happiness that my furry friends have given me.

Have you ever had that one moment with someone that you'll remember forever and laugh about every time you think about it? I have, and I think that everyone should have a moment of laughter in their life. On a particular day, my boyfriend from out of town decided to take me out for an early breakfast. He called me at four in the morning, claiming he was starving and needed food in his stomach. So, he picked me up around five am, and we went to a local diner. After finishing our meal early, he suggested going for a drive around town, despite being unfamiliar with the area.  As we ventured onto gravel roads, we soon realized it might be time to head back. However, when he attempted to turn the car around, he mistakenly drove into a muddy field. Despite my warning, he insisted he could get the car out. After several failed attempts, he ended up covered in mud from head to toe. I couldn't contain my laughter, which only increased when he playfully smeared mud on my face, leading to both of us falling into the mud.  To add to the comedy of errors, I had accidentally left the car in reverse, causing the doors to lock automatically. It took us nearly two hours to unlock the doors and free the car from the mud. When I shared the story with my family, we couldn't stop laughing, and it has become a hilarious memory we continue to reminisce about. Laughter truly is the best medicine, and that day will always be a cherished moment of joy in my life.

Laughter is indeed a powerful tool that can bring joy and healing to individuals. In times of distress or sadness, a good laugh can work wonders in lifting spirits and making people feel better. As the writer shares their personal experiences, it becomes evident how laughter played a significant role in their life, especially during challenging times in foster care. The memories of their parents' laughter bring back feelings of happiness and warmth, underscoring the importance of humor and joy in relationships.  The anecdotes about the writer's mother and father highlight the bond created through laughter within a family. Whether it was playful antics, funny masks, or rollerblading adventures, the shared moments of laughter strengthened the familial connection and created lasting memories. Despite the hardships and separations the writer has faced, the value of laughter in bringing people together remains a constant source of comfort and joy.  In conclusion, laughter is not just a simple act of amusement but a vital component of human interaction and emotional well-being. It has the power to bridge gaps between individuals, foster positive relationships, and offer solace in difficult times. As the writer reflects on the significance of laughter in their life, it becomes clear that humor and joy can truly be transformative, serving as a beacon of light amidst life's challenges.

My grandfather always used to say, "life is like a kaleidoscope, you can keep turning and turning and it may seem like it is changing, but really it's just repeating itself." I have always wondered if the statement really applies to life, and if it does why would we want life to continue in the same pattern, if it isn't going like we had planned. When I was twelve, me and my two little sisters were split up and three thousand miles were crammed in between us. I was put here in a new location while they remained in our hometown, where I was born. At first, the pain of those three thousand miles was devastating. It was like I had two of my essential organs removed from my body. Eventually though time passed and the agony lessened its grip on our lives. It may seem cruel at times, but most of the time now the thought of them doesn't cross my mind. Maybe it's true what they say, "out of sight, out of mind."  It's sad to think of how close my sisters and I were before the change. We did everything together. We are very close in age, the youngest and I are only two years apart. I remember all the times we would spend outside on humid summer days. We would look as white as ghosts because of all the sunscreen my mother would generously apply to our skin. Times were different then, they were happy, I was happy. If I think really hard, I can see us sitting on the shag carpet in my room, playing with dolls until the sunlight melted slowly into darkness. If only I could have that moment again even for a second, then maybe I could feel that happy content feeling once again.  Although much time has passed since our separation, I still have those days when I feel that my world is caving in around me because they are so far away. I'll give them a call and the questions are always uncomfortable at first, like between strangers meeting for the first time. I can feel the three thousand mile scab on my heart reopen and it bleeds as though I am leaving all over again. I ask myself why do I bother to call if it hurts this bad? And then I hear it, like the beautiful sound of classical music to my ears, I hear them laugh. I have that feeling I needed all of a sudden, I am happy. With every small giggle, my smile grows because I know I have made them feel whole again and for a second I have let them forget about how far I really am. Their laughter makes those three thousand miles evaporate into the air. In those moments of laughter, I know that we are close again, that we are sisters, not strangers. It's true what my grandfather says, because no matter how my life changes, I will always have that feeling of total bliss when I hear the sweet laughs of my little sisters.

Many people think that laughter is not a big part of a relationship. However, I believe that having a good laugh with your partner is essential for a healthy and strong bond. I have personally experienced the positive impact of laughter in my own relationship with my girlfriend. We enjoy sharing jokes and making each other laugh, which brings us closer together and creates a positive and joyful atmosphere. In addition to my relationship, laughter also plays a significant role in my family life. My dad, in particular, has a great sense of humor and always manages to lift our spirits with his funny remarks, even after a long day at work. I have learned that laughter not only strengthens relationships but also brings joy and positivity to everyday life. Furthermore, laughter is also crucial in forming and maintaining friendships. When I spend time with my friends, we often share jokes and funny stories that create a sense of camaraderie and happiness among us. In conclusion, laughter is a powerful tool that can enhance relationships, bring families closer, and strengthen friendships. It is an essential element in maintaining a positive and happy environment in all aspects of life.

When I was a young boy I used to laugh at anything I could, but as a kid who didn't? As I got older and grew more, I developed a great sense of humor that to my advantage made me a young people pleaser. I grew more and more developing a stronger, more confident sense of humor. I could always remember making people laugh and loving the attention I received from humor.  As my body grew older and my humor grew more funny I had made myself more dependent on my people pleasing personality. In addition, I then taught myself how to alter my voice and change my tone for a more humorous effect. It was a step I knew was appropriate to advance my humorous personality. I had no intention of losing my humor, so I used it to my advantage.  I used my humor to boost my social status, to get attention from non-accepting peers, and to get the attention that I thrived on. I had begun to be accepted by higher peer groups that used to look down on me and it seemed as if I had a lot of the attention. Anything I could do to make my fellow peers laugh was a goal for me. As I advanced into high school, I knew my humor needed work to keep my peers still laughing, I just didn't know what kind of work I needed. That was when I started to ultimately lose my funny, humorous personality.  I had then dropped in the peer ranks, down to the kids I thought were once called strange. I was friends with people who didn't always keep their heads up and were constantly down and seemed never positive. I was letting people that I called friends drag me to the bottom when I knew I should be more at the top. This was my first major downfall in which I had successfully lost my humorous personality. One of my friends especially brought me down more than anyone else, down to a level of being unhappy. That so-called "friend" took me down so far that I needed therapy to help me get back up to a normal level of happiness.  I finally realized that it wasn't fun to be someone's friend who only drags you down. I finally broke free of that clutch when she moved, I wasn't mean enough to say I didn't want to be friends with her, it was just too hard for me. When she moved, it allowed me to heal myself and pay more attention to my humor. I had broken my dark days away and started back on my endless trail of humor. It was hard to accept the fact that I had lost my humor for what seemed to be forever, and lost my spot in the social bracket which would be hard to regain. But after a month of hard work and focus on both school and humor, I had got my personality back to normal!  Instantly after I regained my humor, I began to feel more happy. I received more attention and felt like I was back to where I should be, although I was just a little lower. Back in the saddle of humor, back to the laughs of my peers, back to the smiles, and most importantly back to the way I used to be. I had to regain all of my humor and personality, my tones, voices, and jokes but it was worth it, in a strange way. As I now continue my humor as a junior, and I have not successfully lost it yet, but there is always a future. I managed to turn the best thing I had to the worst I have felt in a matter of weeks, then right back up again. In the end, it's not what you have that matters, it is what you can do to please yourself and in the end, I would not change a thing!
